descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: JOUR 301, Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Law and Ethics for Today's Journalist: A Concise Guide by Joe Mathewson, ISBN 978-0-7656-4076-5; $54.82 new, $23.83 used, $16.99 Kindle

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course introduces students to creating and developing a visual response to communication problems, including understanding of hierarchy, typography, aesthetics, composition and the construction of meaningful images. Design is approach through giving equal attention to the written and visual aspects of journalism. Students become more visually observant and critical. Develop communication problem solving skills including identifying the problem, researching and analyzing, and finding a solution.

Finishing the quarter with the creation of a fully functional mobile phone app/story prototype using no code.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Adobe Creative Cloud $19.99 per. month membership https://www.adobe.com/creativecloud/plans.html

Small sketch book $ 2.99

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Static and interactive presentations of statistical data are transforming how readers experience the news. The best data journalism pieces engage readers by combining compelling narratives with interactive representations that make it easier to identify trends and make comparisons. Designing and assessing data representations for communication requires diverse skills, including knowing how to analyze and present data using available tools, being able to anticipate how readers will visually perceive and make inferences from data graphics, and recognizing where they may be prone to misinterpreting statistics. In this course, we will learn techniques and theory for analyzing, visualizing, and communicating structured data for journalism contexts. Students will be exposed to ideas and techniques from diverse fields like cognitive science, statistics, and perceptual psychology, and learn how to take an empirical approach to the design and evaluation of data representations like visualizations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Tufte, E. The Visual Display of Quantitative Data (2nd edition). Chesire, CT: Graphics Press, 2001. Hardcover $34.58 on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Visual-Display-Quantitative-Information/dp/1930824130

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a dive into the world of sports journalism and how sports reporters do their jobs on a daily basis, utilizing all the fundamentals of good journalism while recognizing that it is also a unique endeavor. In this class, you will learn how best to perform on deadline in the fast-paced environment of covering sports; how to craft daily game stories and features while also recognizing the importance and best use of social media as it pertains to sports journalism; how the most successful journalists in the business develop sources and report breaking news before their competition; and how to interview and interact with athletes and coaches in a way that gets the best results.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: For required reading (and podcast) material each week, I will try to provide free links or hard copy. You will, however, be expected to subscribe, if necessary, to the publication of your beat writer and if you have not already, you really should consider subscribing to The Athletic (through a Chicago story, please). We will refer to it often and it is the source of great work that in many ways reflects where the industry is today and where it is headed (student discount is $30 yearly).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Here are some other optional books you may find helpful in your career and for class (this is assuming you already have the AP Stylebook, either online or hard copy - you will be graded per AP Style).

-The Best American Sports Writing, 2019 Edition, Edited by Charles P. Pierce. A collection of outstanding sports stories by some of America's best-known sportswriters. (Kindle or paperback)
- Field Guide to Covering Sports by Joe Gisondi (paperback)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Advanced Photojournalism is recommended for students who are already familiar with DSLR cameras and have some experience using Lightroom/Photoshop. This class will review basic DSLR usage (Canon 80D), how to use Lightroom, composition, photojournalism ethics, but will primarily be a production and editing course centered around the creation of a story-driven character-based photo story. Students will pitch a photo essay project in week three and then will spend the rest of the course photographing these subjects to create the final project. Students will be expected to spend significant time with subjects gaining trust and access to tell their story. Emphasis will be placed on submitting the final projects for publication by professional journalism outlets, awards, etc.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar examines the changes and challenges shaping the state of press freedom around the world today. Journalists confront increasing legal, political and physical attacks, yet are also producing landmark stories exposing corruption, abuse of power and exploitation. They face efforts by political leaders to delegitimize the "fake" media and use existing or new laws and regulations to diminish their traditional watchdog role. Turbulent social media platforms present another threat, with news organizations caught in the crosshairs of controversies arising from distorted or invented content on the Internet. The press freedom landscapes of many nations, including the U.S., contain different and common threads of rising hostility toward the media, but journalists are finding new ways, including cooperation across borders, to stand against it.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to extend the lessons of foundational classes in narrative structure, reporting, feature storytelling, and magazine writing. The class, taught by the former editor of a national magazine, provides an opportunity to take a project already begun to the next level, with an eye toward publication. Perhaps you have a project from a reporting class, draft of a story you completed in another course, or an idea you developed during your junior- year residency program that you've been yearning to complete. Too often, the quarter system leaves promising work unfinished and unpolished. This is a new course created in order to allow you to re-report, revise, and prepare that work for submission. Taught in workshop style, using excellent contemporary narrative work as models, we'll create an environment for students who want to take the next step. The intention is to provide space and inspiration for you to take a run at producing a piece of journalism representing a capstone for your college portfolio. Online and multimedia projects welcome.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Seniors or by permission of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Investigative reporting holds a critical role in democracy: It sheds light on secrets and lies, exposes government malfeasance, tracks wrongdoing by lawmakers, corporate executives and power brokers and separates fact from fiction. Investigative reporting has changed broken laws, put corrupt politicians behind bars and brought down a president. In this course, we'll focus on the basics of investigative reporting that you can apply to any reporting course, as well as prepare for advanced investigative courses if you so choose. We'll explore the history, ethics, challenges and successes of investigative reporting and learn the tools used by top investigative reporters.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course expands the understanding of journalism beyond your own country's borders and experiences to examine the historical development, values and practices across regions throughout the world.

We explore how fundamental differences in cultural, political and economic factors led to diverse journalism models and expectations within societies. The findings are critical for understanding and evaluating how journalism is practiced in a digital age across national and regional borders.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Sophomore Standing

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class is for students who want to enhance their producing and reporting skills, especially for TV, Cable and Streaming audiences. Using CNN's Newsource and reporting in the field students will improve their writing, producing and execution/presentation skills for programs ranging from nightly news, cable politics and morning shows.

The course will include anchoring, field reporting or interviewing from the field, finding the right voice when tracking stories, doing stand-ups, live-shots/cross talk, and on-camera interviews. We will move our stories from broadcast/cable to the web and social media formats. Other topics of will include different writing styles depending on the types of news that is being reported. Body language, both as a presenter and as an interviewer. How to read your subjects body language and what they may be conveying when you are talking to them. We will also discuss current trends in the business and how to brand yourselves as you move into the job market.

Students are expected to follow local, state, national and international news and to find and produce original stories or interviews for the Chicago news market. You will be graded on how thoroughly you organize and execute your productions. The final exam will consist of a 30-minute news magazine style production that can include both in-depth magazine style stories or in-depth-interviews done in the field, by Skype or the studio.

The course will meet twice a week in the McCormick Foundation studio for three hours.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: Sophomore Standing; JOUR 312, JOUR 322, or instructor permission.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Sports Marketing provides an in-depth look at concepts and methods in marketing communications for brands within the sports environment. Sports marketing includes topics such as acquisition and retention of fans, celebrity management, event execution, crisis interventions, sponsorship and partnerships, ticket pricing, social media and digital innovation, tie-ins between teams and retail, and understanding the business of sports. Students will develop an understanding of how marketing works in sports through readings, guest lectures, case analysis and discussions. The course will have a television client building an audience and guest speakers. The course will help students understand how to make decisions in ambiguous marketing environments and understand more about the business of sports. If you are not a sports lover, then the marketing aspects may appeal so that you are well versed in areas of marketing that are helpful in many fields.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD, cost shouldn't exceed $10

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a dive into the ever-changing industry of sports journalism from both the reporting and audience perspectives. You will learn how sports reporters do their jobs on a daily basis by covering a beat, learning how the really good ones rise above the rest by studying professionals in the business. And in an industry that seemingly looks different every year, we will examine and analyze how it disseminates news. I will ask where you get your sports news and content beyond social media but more importantly, I will ask you to examine why and what you think about it. I will expect you to master the fundamentals of writing and reporting while you learn how best to perform on deadline in a fast-paced, often highly pressured environment; to craft original daily stories and features; to develop sources and break news and how to interview and interact with athletes, coaches, team execs, agents and media relations officials in a way that gets the best results.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: For required reading (and podcast) material each week, I will try to provide free links or hard copy. You will, however, be expected to subscribe, if necessary, to the website you are analyzing and if you have not already, you really should subscribe to The Athletic (through a Chicago portal, please). We will refer to it often and it is the source of great work that in many ways reflects where the industry is today and where it is headed. Sign up on theathletic.com/student for a student discount. Input account and billing info. An email will be sent to your student email to verify your student email account. (Amounts vary, but it should be no more than $30 for the year.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Photojournalists are reporters who communicate through pictures, and students will learn to think visually in order to create compelling, storytelling images. Photojournalism has the power to reveal the human experience, and this in-depth course will give students an additional tool in their reporting skill set. Discussions of historical and contemporary photojournalism, as well as ethics in photojournalism, will accompany weekly assignments and critiques. Students will also learn to edit pictures thoughtfully to enhance the power, nuance and clarity of the story. Medill cameras are provided for use in this class, and students will receive instruction on manual controls to attain a variety of photographic effects. Upon completion of this course, students will be comfortable approaching people and documenting a variety of news and feature stories.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the opportunity for students specializing in video/broadcast to advance their skills in reporting and production techniques by doing several stories on deadline. They will refine their craft in enterprise reporting, shooting, writing and editing through weekly assignments, culminating in a final project in a style best suited for of a news outlet of their choosing. The cumulative instruction and reporting work will prepare students for their fourth quarter project or practicum in video.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Adobe Creative Cloud Subscription

One external hard drive - 1TB, USB 3.0 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Note: You will be responsible for your own travel expenses to reporting locations, which may include taxis, rideshares, trains and other forms of transport other than your CTA card.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to give students news producing, interviewing and anchoring experience. You will learn how to "line produce" a traditional newscast with specialized software that television newsrooms use. In addition, you will get in-depth interviewing experience in the context of field and show producing. Excellent and ethical writing and editing will continue to be emphasized through the use of timely CNN footage.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to give students news producing, interviewing and anchoring experience. You will learn how to "line produce" a traditional newscast with specialized software that television newsrooms use. In addition, you will get in-depth interviewing experience in the context of field and show producing. Excellent and ethical writing and editing will continue to be emphasized through the use of timely CNN footage.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This advanced course will provide students with a comprehensive overview of HD video production (including 4k) specifically geared towards producing short documentaries that tell human stories. Emphasis is put on the use of character, conflict, drama and surprise in telling these documentary stories. We will also look at different documentary styles and how narrative structures like story arcs are implemented. Students will learn documentary production with a journalism focus: reporting, camera technique, lighting and sound recording in the field. Students will create a 7-12 minute documentary project in a group of 3-4. They will research and write a treatment, cast charismatic characters, get signed releases, shoot and edit the film. Documentaries created in this course have gone on to win National College Emmys and premiere at major film festivals like Cannes and Tribeca. These films have also premiered on PBS and on online outlets.? Documentary alums work at outlets like VICE, Discovery Channel, National Geographic, TIME, CNN Films, PBS Newshour, Kartemquin, HBO Docs, The Washington Post, The Seattle Times, Al Jazeera, The Today Show, etc.

www.medilldocumentary.com

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

name: Capstone: Embedded Reporting - Field Research Reporting

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Embedded reporting pairs students with global science field research teams to track the retreat of the glaciers in Mongolia, join doctors providing prenatal care in remote villages of Nicaragua, join NOAA's hurricane hunters and tornado chasers, and explore caves in the Yucatan that reveal clues to changing environments and ancient civilizations. This is a small sampling of assignments that Medill has offered. Students can identify their own embedded reporting assignments for Medill approval. Students produce blogs or multimedia bulletins while in the field and produce in-depth stories when they return. Stories completed for embedded reporting are pitched to major media where National Geographic, the Huffington Post, the Pacific Standard, Slate and other media have published or aired them in the past.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

name: Politics, Policy, and Foreign Affairs Reporting Project

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will delve deep into a particular politics and foreign affairs issue through an intensive multimedia reporting project on the subject. The reporting likely will include some travel. Students work closely with the instructors as well as professional media partners. It is the capstone for Medill's Politics, Policy and Foreign Affairs Journalism Specialization.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The stock market, global trade, money, technology, inflation, derivatives, personal finance. What happens on Wall Street impacts Main Street every day, and the best business reporters tell those stories in a compelling, understandable and engaging manner. This course will help you learn to write those stories, whether you're a novice or veteran to the business world. If you want to learn an area of journalism where jobs are plentiful, advanced business reporting is for you.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Building from a base of strong reporting, students will learn how to craft in-depth narrative stories. The class is two-pronged: careful study of outstanding feature stories and work on writing, reporting, and analytic skills. In the end, each student will produce their own substantial story suitable for publication. The course aims to encourage writing that is clear, graceful, and efficient. Students will also learn how to pitch stories and find suitable outlets for publication. Because virtually all media demand good narrative technique, the course is appropriate for students who are pursuing magazine, news reporting, documentary film, investigative, reported opinion, audio and interactive skills. Drawing on his own experience, the instructor, Dr. Thrasher, will teach readings and feature writing techniques which center and engage critical theory, LGBTQ journalism, social science, public health scholarship, the law, writers of color, podcasting, and literary journalism.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Building from a base of strong reporting, students will learn how to craft in-depth narrative stories. The class is two-pronged: careful study of outstanding feature stories and work on writing, reporting, and analytic skills. In the end, each student will produce their own substantial story suitable for publication. The course aims to encourage writing that is clear, graceful, and efficient. Students will also learn how to pitch stories and find suitable outlets for publication. Because virtually all media demand good narrative technique, the course is appropriate for students who are pursuing magazine, news reporting, documentary film, investigative, reported opinion, audio and interactive skills. Drawing on his own experience, the instructor, Dr. Thrasher, will teach readings and feature writing techniques which center and engage critical theory, LGBTQ journalism, social science, public health scholarship, the law, writers of color, podcasting, and literary journalism.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Want to work in magazines? Write narrative features? Successfully pitch to varied media outlets? Whether your goal is to be a writer, editor or publisher, in print or online, Magazine Editing delivers the skills to succeed in today's multi-faceted media world. Students will both read and analyze magazine-style stories and practice editing skills. The core concepts taught include finding story ideas; shaping narratives; improving sentences; and working with a writer to develop a story from idea to execution. The course will also offer insights into the business generally. Magazine-style writing has spread through virtually all media, and this course will prepare students for roles in a range of fields. ?

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Books TBD ? at most, less than $40 total and probably quite a bit less. (All books are also available at the library.)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Journalists increasingly rely on data to understand the topics they are covering, to find news and to present information to their audience. This class provides a foundation in finding, acquiring, analyzing and presenting data in a journalistic context. Students will learn how to identify data sources, evaluate the value and accuracy of data, and find newsworthy information in data. They will also learn to differentiate good and bad uses of data in journalism.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Advanced Social Justice Reporting course will help students develop professional-level reporting skills for in-depth projects, including investigative skills, interviewing skills and negotiating the ethical and pragmatic issues inherent in covering social justice topics. Classes will include discussions and presentations, and assignments will revolve around reporting projects that can be a continuation of work students started in prior quarters; new projects; or the work being done as part of the Professional Partnerships in the Social Justice-Investigative specialization. Possible subject areas include immigration, criminal justice, racial justice, LGBTQ+ rights, employment, health care, environmental justice and more. Students can use video, text, photos, graphics, audio or some combination of these media. By the end of the quarter, students will have projects that can form the foundation of their Q4 Masters Projects if they so choose. In other words, it will be a course with a lot of flexibility based on the interests and skill sets of each student in the class. There will be readings, but the focus of the class will be actual reporting including one-on-one coaching and group discussions about that reporting.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Minor costs for transportation, parking or other costs involved in reporting, depending on the project. Other materials will be available free and online.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Washington Reporting on Politics and Government provides students with a four-day a week reporting experience focusing on test but also including web video, graphics and photos. Students are credentialed Washington reporters covering Congress, the White House and federal agencies for media partners such as USA Today, Marketwatch.com, the McClatchy newspapers, USNews.com, and TheGrio.com. The course emphasizes enterprise reporting, visual journalism and computer-assisted reporting skills.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Washington Reporting on Politics and Government provides students with a four-day a week reporting experience focusing on video, Students are credentialed Washington reporters covering Congress, the White House and federal agencies for media partners such as KVRR-TV, WKBN-TV, the Illinois Channel, Great Lakes Public Media and others. The course emphasizes daily turns, enterprise reporting and producing a resume reel.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Two days a week of advanced journalism training at sites such as Military Times newspapers, USA Today, NPR Digital, SBNation, National Law Journal, etc.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Two days a week of research and observation at sites such as the ACLU, Street Law, the Cato Institute, Center for War and Peace, State Department, Canadian (or other) embassy, etc.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Your future involves leading in organizations, teams, non-profits, for profits, government, start-ups, and/or media companies. If you plan to be a reporter, your leadership skills are needed when you work with colleagues and the communities that you are a part of and report in. This class develops your skills in communication, coaching and nurturing talent, economic and financial literacy, and business planning while managing innovation. Media organizations need these skills to thrive in the next decades.
You will read relevant articles on management and leadership and comment on them on discussion boards; take an online course in economic literacy; watch some videos and listen to some podcasts. This class is meant to help you become the best leader you can be.

Leadership Strategies' goals include you learning how to
1. Demonstrate effectiveness in leading organizations
2. Prove leadership qualities through effective communications strategies
3. Show capacity for envisioning future directions
4. Coach talent and improve your economic and financial literacy

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD, cost shouldn't exceed $10

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Course meets remotely

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Each quarter, multidisciplinary teams of students, faculty, and professionals come together to collaborate in the Knight Lab Studio to produce cutting-edge digital work, research, and thought, innovating across every part of the media-making process. The Lab places students together on diverse teams to work on an important problem for the future of media, rapidly moving beyond conversation and hypothesis to well-reasoned action during the quarter. Our process combines user and audience research, design thinking, critical and analytical work, iterative building, storytelling, new technology, and a healthy dose of experimentation?often within the confines of a single, specific problem. Projects are open by application. Full project details and application available at studio.knightlab.com.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This short course will examine issues relating to the organization of the Internet and the United States government's response to cyber threats. Students will be introduced to concepts relating to the private sector and civilian government engagement in cyberspace. The course will also include an examination of the application of traditional laws of armed conflict to the new cyber domain. Students will also consider the role of the press in covering cyber issues.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introductory course in qualitative and quantitative audience research for journalists. Class blends background material from the behavioral sciences with techniques used in practice and focuses in three general areas: (1) the logic, implementation and analysis of primary research; (2) the ability to evaluate the quality, usefulness and appropriateness of research and results from other sources, and (3) the applicability of research to the practice of journalism. The class examines methods journalists can use to research audiences and understand their media behavior and preferences. Students learn a framework for analyzing audience behavior, focusing on audience insight. Topics include the cognitive, affective and behavioral processes underlying the choices audiences make (needs, perceptions, attitudes); descriptive audience characteristics (demographics, psychographics, VALS); and environmental influences on behavior (culture, family, economic situation). Students learn how to develop successful ideas for journalism content, products, and services by developing the skillset of audience insight.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The objective of this course is to familiarize students with digital tools that will become the frameworks with which they can approach multi-platform storytelling, emphasizing the use of structured data and the visualization of data. Students will learn how to report and produce engaging interactive graphics. The focus will be on immersive visual storytelling for the web and mobile devices. ?

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Narrative Structure in Storytelling is an immersive five weeks in the art of crafting stories for different media. Students will deconstruct, analyze, tear apart and re-shape stories in an effort to understand how good stories come to be. Each week the course will focus on a different medium, from narrative writing, to documentary film, to podcasts, to advertising messages and more, and identify the core components of storytelling and how that medium uses them well (think characters, leads, arc, plot, audio, etc.). Students will look at what all stories have in common as well as how mediums differ along with core tenets and when to break the rules. By the end of the five weeks, students should have a strong understanding of how to take a large body of information, organize it and then create meaningful, gripping narratives across mediums. Guest speakers may include NPR reporters, documentary filmmakers, digital editors, advertising creatives and long-form writers. Assignments include heavy reading, watching and listening to the year's best works, weekly story analyses, writing short narratives and possibly editing and reimagining stories across mediums.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials, readings, etc. Provided by instructor through canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Narrative Structure in Storytelling is an immersive five weeks in the art of crafting stories for different media. Students will deconstruct, analyze, tear apart and re-shape stories in an effort to understand how good stories come to be. Each week the course will focus on a different medium, from narrative writing, to documentary film, to podcasts, to advertising messages and more, and identify the core components of storytelling and how that medium uses them well (think characters, leads, arc, plot, audio, etc.). Assignments include heavy reading, watching and listening to the year's best works, weekly story analyses, writing short narratives and possibly editing and reimagining stories across mediums.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials, readings, etc. Provided by instructor through canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students work as a team to solve a problem, usually digital, for an actual media company while learning about the dynamic, 6,000-title-strong business-to-business (B2B) sphere. Previous classes have "consulted" on suggesting the best components for a web portal, live-tweeting for the country's largest exposition of drones and self-driving cars, making design suggestions for a major newsletter or reviewing video on platforms from print to Pinterest and Instagram for a major beauty publication. B2B reporters and editors furnish professionals and industry decision-makers with the highly specific, cross-platform knowledge that can inform and improve their work, even as consumer titles such as Vogue are now launching business analogs.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required materials. Professor will furnish readings

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
For generations, investigative reporting has proven to be one of the highest and most impactful forms of journalism. It sheds light on wrongdoing, exposes rampant incompetence and calls to account powerful people and institutions, from presidents to banks to schools. Over two quarters, you will focus on social justice reporting - exploring some of the policies, programs and public and private agencies that promise to provide a safety net to tens of millions of vulnerable Americans. You will study budgets, court cases, crime logs and government institutions, do interviews with powerbrokers and the constituents they are supposed to serve, probe critical data and trends and ultimately produce a groundbreaking investigative story from the ground up.

You are expected to work regularly outside of class. You will make cold calls, dig for information and cultivate sources and investigative findings.Consider your classmates team members and allies. Consider your instructor a collaborator, editor and guide.

Investigative reporting is hard. Expect to confront roadblocks and anticipate spinning your wheels. But along the way, you will learn to think, research and write like an investigative reporter. If you are successful, your work could potentially make a difference in the lives vulnerable people from coast to coast.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This five-week class is an introduction to effective and moving personal narrative storytelling. We will explore the complexity of memory and read, listen and analyze first-person pieces in an effort to help us find our own voices. Students will learn and practice pitching and producing stories, essays and multimedia pieces that incorporate reporting, experience, emotion, perspective and other important elements. Students will write/produce at least one piece targeted for a specific publication, website or broadcast audience.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course students gain the ability to analyze, interpret, recognize, appreciate and understand the messages conveyed in a visual format as well as the ability to create images with a clear message. These skills are increasingly valuable in a visually stimulated society no matter what field of study. "Visual literacy is based on the idea that pictures can be ?read' and that meaning can be communicated through a process of reading." I like to think of this as opportunity to learn how to see.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course students gain the ability to analyze, interpret, recognize, appreciate and understand the messages conveyed in a visual format as well as the ability to create images with a clear message. These skills are increasingly valuable in a visually stimulated society no matter what field of study. "Visual literacy is based on the idea that pictures can be ?read' and that meaning can be communicated through a process of reading." I like to think of this as opportunity to learn how to see.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Student completes an original reporting project that clearly demonstrates proficiency with journalism skills taught in preceding quarters, demonstrates the quality and quantity of work appropriate to the academic credit awarded for a master's project and is worthy of being the centerpiece of a professional portfolio. The project can be in whatever medium is appropriate (or multiple media). It may be a single story, or a group of related stories. Team projects are possible, but the per-person volume of work/involvement would not lessen. Faculty will remain open to suitable creative ideas that do not fall into the category described here.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The goal for each student in this course is to develop a distinctive voice that stands out from the cacophony of opinions in the sporting world, to create commentary that is informative, thought-provoking and entertaining and to adapt those messages for delivery across multiple media platforms: ?the written word, television, radio, podcasts and social media.

Sports are more than just home runs and touchdowns. Collectively, they're part of a $200 billion industry. And within this realm all of the elements of our society are displayed: heroism and failure, racial harmony and discrimination, drugs, religion and crime. That's why it's so important to be aware of and capable of weighing in on all current issues, not just the latest sports results.

Students will learn to coalesce their observations, opinions and experiences into compelling arguments that reflect the essence of the sports column: "I'm right, and this is why."

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: "The Cost of These Dreams" by Wright Thompson, $10.89 new paperback

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will receive instruction and hands-on practice in investigative practices including filing FOIAs, obtaining and analyzing public documents, finding and understanding data, backgrounding sources, covering courts, investigative interviews and developing investigative stories. Students will hear from guest speakers about their investigative work and will visit public offices. Investigative work done in this class may contribute to students' Masters projects. Assignments will relate to practicing different investigative techniques and will not involve completed stories, though extra mentorship is available to utilize the techniques for stories if the student chooses.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: IRE student membership ($25) is highly recommended. Other materials will be available free and online.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Back in the day, journalists focused on finding and telling great stories. It was someone else's job - say, the marketing or circulation department - to figure out how to reach and build the audience for the journalists' work. No more - we now need journalists to work in the emerging field of "audience development." That's the focus of our class: learning how to build an engaged audience to support and strengthen a sustainable business model. You will learn how digital publications reach and engage audiences, how web audience measurement systems work and which measurements are most useful to publishers. You will also gain practical experience using Web analytics by serving as audience consultants for a real digital publication. Students will gain a deeper understanding of the art and science of audience development, the ways publishers envision and measure their audiences, and the factors that contribute to building a successful media business.

In this course, you will:

Build your understanding of audience measurement and the behavior of digital audiences

Recognize which analytics are most useful for measuring engagement with online content

Gain an understanding of different approaches for building audience engagement

Build proficiency in digital audience analytics tools by using what you've learned to recommend better audience-engagement strategies for a real digital publication.

Learn about how audience engagement contributes to the business models that support media

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Daniel Hindman's The Internet Trap. $23 hardcover, $17 Kindle

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Podcasting is changing the face ? and form ? of today's journalism. This class is designed for fans of narrative podcasts who have a lot of passion, but little to no practical experience in audio. You'll learn not only how to plan, record, edit, and mix audio, but also how to find and shape the kinds of stories that you love so much on This American Life, Code Switch, The Daily, and other reporting-based shows, and how to produce them in your own voice.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Laptop, earbuds or headphones,

Out on the Wire: The Storytelling Secrets of the New Masters of Radio by Jessica Abel, $13.78 new

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this class, multidisciplinary teams of design and journalism students will imagine and prototype new approaches to local journalism. The big picture issue being addressed is that without robust local news, citizens will not have the information they need for their everyday lives about their community's government institutions, schools, businesses and neighbors. This is the second of a two-quarter sequence. Enrollment in the first quarter is not required. Students will begin from a research brief and concept developed in the previous quarter. In this class students will refine the concept and will be primarily concerned with user-experience and user-interface concerns. Students will build and test prototypes for the concept. They will test, iterate and refine those designs over the course of the quarter leading to a final UX/UI design artifact.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is intended to provide academic structure and guidance for professional internships. Students will meet weekly with the instructor and the other interns to connect their internship experiences to academic knowledge and broader career aspirations. We will do this as a class through sharing progress reports, questions, and concerns about work at various media-related jobs. Because these internships are linked to the students' academic progress, critical reflection on these work experiences is a necessity. Students are encouraged to explore the links and gaps between what they have learned in their classes and what they are learning in the workplace.

Note: interested students must secure an internship and submit an application through the EPICS office by the appropriate deadline to be enrolled in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students will be registered for this course by the Undergraduate Dean/EPICS Office.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will
? Gain a greater understanding of their professional and career goals through experience and exposure to the workplace
? Connect theory to practice under the supervision of industry professionals
? Develop skills, gain insight into typical workplace rules and engage in "hands-on" learning in a professional environment
? Identify a network of professionals to assist them in furthering their professional goals

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly response papers, informational interview write-ups, initial and final reflection papers, resume and Linked in assignments, class participation.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an in-depth study of the music and lyrics of Stephen Sondheim. Through in-class solo and group performances, listening assignments, and style comparison papers, the class will expand the student's knowledge of Sondheim's prolific catalog. All performances will be work-shopped on vocal technique and performance practice. The focus of this course is not audition technique, but rather establishing an in-depth knowledge of Sondheim's work.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Performance/Participation 20%
Listening Quizzes (4) 40%
Performance Papers (4) 20%
Listening Final 20%

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The first weeks are spent finding the right monologues for each student. We will search for 8 for each actor. After that the pieces are memorized and then worked on for presentation with the instructor. Each student will turn in a resume. A professional director will come in to look at the student's pieces.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Participation/Preparation and Resume.

name: Junior Tutorial
topic: Perf./Dramatic Lang of George Bernard Shaw

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This junior tutorial will explore Shaw's verbal stagecraft. How his use of dramatic rhetoric enabled him to convey his complex political ideas in a theatrical form in plays that continue to delight and entertain audiences today. This tutorial will focus on Shaw's own views on the actor's vocal craft using his writings and the recollections of professional actors and directors who worked with him. Students will work on the vocal rhetoric of Shaw's theatrical language through selected scenes and speeches from a variety of Shaw plays to explore how actors today can acquire the vocal ability to perform his work with skill and
professionalism.

The class will culminate in a performance of excerpts from scenes by George Bernard Shaw worked on in class for an invited audience at Northwestern.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Instructor Consent
Students will be registered for this class by the Undergraduate Dean's Office.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Punctuation and Attendance Mandatory
Grades determined by attendance, class participation, written assignment and final performance.

descriptions.value: This course teaches computing literacy to non-technical undergraduate students.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course teaches computing literacy to non-technical undergraduate students.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a general introduction to the social-scientific study of persuasive communication. The course focuses on alternative theoretical accounts of the processes underlying persuasion and on research findings concerning the effects of various factors on persuasive effectiveness.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: People who understand communication are uniquely positioned to solve health related problems, and their services are increasingly in demand. As such, this course is designed to familiarize you with the theory and research on communication in health and illness contexts, focusing on how messages from interpersonal, organizational, cultural, and media sources affect health beliefs and behaviors. We will explore communication in health care delivery, health care organizations, as well as health promotion and disease prevention. By taking this course, you will become a more mindful, educated, and effective health communicator.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: du Pré, A. (2016). Communicating about health: Current issues and perspectives, 5th ed. New York: Oxford University Press.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Theories and research relating to communication in small groups and group decision making.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines how power is created, sustained and challenged in entertainment media. Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. Lectures will give theoretical and historical context. This course is intended as an introduction to creative industries and first in a sequence before "Contemporary Television."

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: "This course is focused on processes observed in interpersonal disputes. Causes of conflict and methods of resolution will be discussed. Sources of information will include research and theory drawn from communication, social psychology, sociology, and organizational behavior. The course will include general models of conflict as well as material related to disagreements in specific contexts such as friendship, dating, and marriage. The primary method of teaching will be lecture and students are encouraged to ask questions and offer examples"

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Use of social network analysis to understand the growing connectivity and complexity in the world around us on different scales, ranging from small groups to the web. How we create social, economic, and technological networks; how these networks enable and constrain our attitudes and behavior.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to make the student aware of major theoretical perspectives of organizational communication. The student will be expected to exhibit understanding and retention of key concepts and theories. As such, the primary course content will come from social scientific theory and research. We will explore general perspectives of organizational processes as well as those focused on particular organizational problems.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is no textbook.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"How do elite chefs come up with new recipes? What makes blues authentic? What makes a model successful? What is the difference between art and craft? How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this?
This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced."

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the evolution of digital media and its effects on self and society, with a focus on the historical shift away from one-way mass media toward more customized, participatory digital media. Through readings, blogging, class discussion and a final project, students are encouraged to think broadly about how digital communication technologies are impacting politics, media, business and culture and what this means for us at the individual and societal level.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Adolescents coming of age in today's media-saturated world may be the most enthusiastic consumers of media. On the one hand, there are several potential benefits of media use in this developmental stage; meeting like-minded people, expressing oneself, etc. However, parents, educators, and experts are also concerned about the negative consequences associated with adolescents' use of media; associations with poor health, online bullying, etc. In this course, students will consider the wide spectrum of potential outcomes and develop their own argument about adolescents and media through the practice of reading (and writing) research on the topic. Throughout the quarter, students will explore media effects on adolescent friendships, romantic relationships, health, well-being, and more through weekly reading and writing exercises. At the end of the course, students will complete a fifteen- to twenty-page final paper on the topic of their choice.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This writing seminar will inspire students to think about the nonprofit sector, social movements and advocacy, and organization theories by drawing upon recent environmental issues. Students will formulate their research ideas and think critically about social movements and advocacy and use this class to write and present their thoughts in a research paper. The class will be geared towards developing writing, presentation, and peer-editing skills.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Strunk, W., & White, E. B. (2000). The elements of style. New York: Longman.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores how digital media has changed our writing practices and teaches students how to analyze and compose digital and multimodal texts. At the heart of this investigation is the concept of authorship, and how automation is transforming how we communicate with one another. In this course, we will connect contemporary scholarship on automation with digital writing theories, methods, and exercises. Each week, we will practice writing various types of digital texts (e.g., blogs, encyclopedia entries, news articles, and websites) and, over the course of 10 weeks, develop a 20-page research paper that explores the complex relationship between user-generated and automated content. We will approach the practice of digital writing and the topic of automation as a collaborative process, making ample time for peer reviews and group discussion.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

name: Communication Studies Research Seminar
topic: Designing Technologies for Health and Wellbeing

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We are increasingly using technologies for our health and wellbeing. Whether it's pulling up the notes app at the doctor's office, keeping track of daily step counts, or talking to a chatbot when feeling sad, these technologies continue to impact our daily life. In this course, we will explore how to design technologies that support humans in understanding, tracking, and managing their health and wellbeing.

This course will serve as an overview of the human-centered design process. Students will learn how to identify opportunities for interventions, recognize ethical challenges, gather user needs, translate needs into prototypes, and evaluate interventions. The course will be organized by modules, where each module represents a stage of the design process. Class activities will include a combination of lectures and discussions of relevant readings about digital health and wellbeing that correspond to the stage of the design process covered during that module. In parallel, students will follow the design process for their own digital health and wellbeing intervention. As the weeks progress, students will build upon their work and present their projects to the rest of the class at the end of the quarter.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course examines the effects of mass media on individuals and groups in society. Media content and effects are explored in various domains, including politics, violence, pornography, health, science, video games, as well as pro-social and environmental news media. The course begins with a historical overview of theory, methodology and research in the realm of media effects. The course continues with extensive survey of contemporary research about the role of media in facilitating changes in people and society, and consideration of possible explanations of how media effects occur. The course will conclude with discussion of possible ways to diminish socially undesirable media effects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Sparks, G. G. (2015). Media effects research: A basic review. (5th Ed) Boston, MA: Wadsworth.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the relationship between social media, technology, and mental health. Students will explore and critically analyze social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and blogs) and technology (apps, online therapy, video games) used to address mental health concerns. Conversely, students will scrutinize social media?Äôs and technology?Äôs impact on mental health and wellness, with special attention paid to topics such as social comparison and online self-presentation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In today's organizations, personality tests are often used to improve communication and relationships among employees. This course will provide an overview of research exploring how personality affects interpersonal communication in organizational contexts. Topics will include the influence of personality on social networks, leadership, and team processes, as well as the value and application of personality assessments in the workplace. Students will reflect on and integrate popular press pieces and scholarly journal articles.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Please note: students who have completed Comm_St 352: Social Network Analysis will not receive credit for this course. Introduction to Social Network Analysis is intended to lay down the foundations of network-thinking, and connect that with various topics of social sciences. It will not stick to any substantive area of inquiry or to any specific methodology, rather, it will give a broad map of substantive questions and approaches to answer them. As a consequence, actors and relations will be defined in many different ways ranging from friends and families, to groups, to companies, to social media and beyond. This class will teach you to see the world in a new way: using a network perspective. Together, we will examine how we create social, professional, and technological networks, and how these networks influence our behaviors, beliefs, and opportunities. The new theoretical concepts will be implemented using the statistical software R. No previous programming experience is required: familiarity with R and the relevant packages will be slowly built up through the course; however, an open mind, patience and willingness to make some intellectual effort will be key for this endeavor to be successful.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Christina Prell: Social Network Analysis - https://uk.sagepub.com/en-gb/eur/social-network-analysis/book231856

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Rhetorical analysis is a creative, pluralistic art. In this course we will investigate contemporary rhetorical analysis in two parallel ways. First, through assigned readings and class discussions, we will survey theories and practices of rhetorical analysis in the discipline of communication. We will read analytic works and discuss the perspective that scholars take in studying their chosen subjects. Second, through independent research projects, students will undertake the practice of rhetorical analysis for themselves. The class readings and the independent projects should inform one another; the readings should assist students in inventing their own perspectives and approaches, and students' ongoing independent projects should illuminate class discussion. Students who successfully complete this course should expect to be conversant in the disciplinary vocabularies of contemporary rhetorical analysis and should expect to have produced a critical work appropriate for conference or journal submission and/or for a thesis or dissertation chapter.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Cobb, Jasmine Nichole. Picture Freedom: Remaking Black Visuality in the Early Nineteenth Century. New York: New York University Press, 2015.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is constructed as an inquiry into the origins and history of the intellectual and political project that later came to be called "cultural studies." We will consider the historical conditions of possibility that led to the intellectual and political work that first gave rise to the creation of the Birmingham Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies and the early scholarship emanating from within it. This will necessitate close attention to post-war intellectual work in Britain, to the work of Raymond Williams, Richard Hoggart, and Stuart Hall, and to the various critiques of their work emerging out of feminist, post-colonial, and critical race theory circles.

descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The intent of the Musical Theatre Dance class is to further the skill set used in auditioning for and working within the context of the Musical Theater world by utilizing original choreography from shows chosen for their range of styles, in combination with technical exercises.

Smaller passages of movement, either original or in the style of the show will be combined with technical exercises in the Center in the beginning of class.

Longer movement passages will be used across the floor following the center exercises.

The vocabulary learned will be combined into a longer sequence at the end of class, employing staging and simple choreographic conventions.

Each class unit lasts 2 weeks, during which material will be explored and added. You will be videotaped at the end of each two week unit. This video will be available for online viewing, only to the class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Participation in a dance placement class during the spring quarter or Wildcat Welcome is required to take this course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The student will be expected to have an expanded scope of embodied possibilities relative to combining technical concepts, presence, and performative execution. They will be able to trace the arc of their progress through video viewings and written reflection.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Very-fitted, non-restrictive dance clothes and dance shoes. No sneakers.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore basic Contemporary and Modern Dance under the umbrella of Martha Graham, Katherine Dunham, Merce Cunningham and Garth Fagan technique, some of the historical context from which it developed, and is currently performed.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: $32.53 Books | Dancewear (appropriate shoes, leotard, tights, unitards, other form-fitting exercise wear will work, as well) $75-$100

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to provide students with basic vocabulary and to learn the proper execution of the steps of the classical technique. This course is designed to challenge the student both physically and intellectually.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Ballet Shoes $20
Ballet Attire $30
Performance Outing $50 (Tights and Leotards for female student | Tight or shorts and a T-shirt for male student)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Musical Theatre choreography. 3 goals are addressed. First, reviewing how to manipulate the concepts of space, time and energy in short movement studies. Second, creating a movement study in dramatic action that relies on manipulations of space, time and energy. Third, choreographing a short dance to music on other dancers using the preveious movement studies as guideposts.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prior experience in either choreography or staged movement. Open to aspiring directors as well as choreographers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Dancewear (appropriate shoes, leotard, tights, unitards, other form-fitting exercise wear will work, as well) $75-$100

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Department permission required. Instructor permission required for non majors.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is a level 2 technique class, designed to deepen the potential for expression in the moving body. Uniting function and expression using weight, space, time and intention, students will infuse personal, idiosyncratic, and technical movement with urgency, vitality and humanity, while exploring inner and outer focus to bridge improvised and re-membered movement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Dancewear (appropriate shoes, leotard, tights, unitards, other form-fitting exercise wear will work, as well) $75-$100

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to continue more advanced classical ballet with an emphasis on technical development. It is an extension of level one, emphasizing more intricate movement combinations, including the integration of vocabulary, concepts of dynamics, attack, musicality, alignment, lines, use of space, and artistry, while challenging the student physically and intellectually.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Ballet Shoes $20
Ballet Attire $30
Performance Outing $50 (Tights and Leotards for female student Tight or shorts and a T-shirt for male student)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The course explores the diverse objectives of Dance Improvisation for performance. Through rigorous movement laboratories, students will explore the process and role of improvisation in performance. The work is grounded in readings and class discussion. Topics include but are not limited to site specific work, contact, use of text, collaboration, and music. Designing and leading improvisations are also be covered.

Prereq: Dance 101-3

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will assess existing models of practice..
Students will develop a deeper understanding of the many structures, types and processes of dance improvisation in performance.
Students will apply their learning through performance experiences and demonstrate critical thinking and reflection on their work.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Designing and leading improvisation
Performance critiques
Performance

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Composing While Dancing: An Improviser's Companion $22 | Possible performance attendance $10

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor permission required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Dancewear (appropriate shoes, leotard, tights, unitards, other form-fitting exercise wear will work, as well) $75-$100

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Modern III classes will incorporate fundamentals of Modern Dance Technique and draw on foundational concepts from iconic choreographers such as Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Lester Horton, and Jose Limon and their evolution through the artistic filters of modern masters like Paul Taylor, Merce Cunningham, and Mark Morris. Focusing on dance's deeply-rooted connection to music and rhythm both qualitatively and dynamically, students will perform a daily warm up designed to enhance alignment, build core strength, increase somatic awareness. and move through to more extended movement sequences to challenge students' capacity to delve deeply into complex phrases and cultivate artistic autonomy. In Modern III we shall also explore compositional concepts utilizing longer repertory phrases throughout the semester to hone critical thinking, foster problem-solving skills, and increase the students' general understanding of dancing with others.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Dancewear (leotard, tights, unitards, other form-fitting exercise wear will work, as well) $75-$100. Performance outing $25-$55

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Jazz III is structured with technical exercises that begin class, exploring a range of Jazz movement and music styles, incorporating Modern principles of weight, fall and recovery, grounding, and release. Longer movement passages fusing technique with a range of stylized movement addressing turns, floor work, extensions and jumps complete the class.

The emphasis is on focus; specifically bringing the focus to transitions, and the idea that all mo(ve)ments are transitional. Transitions micro and macro, we use the micro lens of the focus on the local/personal movement/moment to affect not only the larger technical concept being addressed, but the global/spatial movement patterns and the performative aspect as well. We will address the idea of performing without grafting on any additional frameworks outside of spatial concepts, letting the clarity and truth of the movement concept project itself, finding the humanity in abstraction. Using total commitment to presence in the fully embodied execution of the moment at hand by integrating the ideas of total presence in repetition of learned material, and use of improvisation in technical exercises to infuse the material with vital energy and urgency, and aid in keeping the focus on the now.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The student will be expected to have an expanded scope of embodied possibilities relative to combining technical concepts, presence, and performative execution. They will be able to trace the arc of their progress through video viewings and written reflection.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Each class unit lasts 2 weeks, during which material will be explored and added. You will be videotaped at the end of each unit. This video will be available for online viewing, only to the class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The course is for graduating seniors pursuing the dance major and is intended to mentor the senior concert as well as prepare for entry into the professional world. The seminar provides opportunities for students to explore issues related to this important transition.


This class is offered in the Spring Quarter for one full credit. However, students must be enrolled in Fall and Winter for no credit.
