descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Marketing plays a crucial role in the success of creative enterprises. Without the engagement of customers, the creative product remains unappreciated and unfunded. Marketing a creative enterprise requires as much time, attention and toil as the core creative product, itself. It requires a blend of art and science: an appreciation for the fundamentals of consumer-centered marketing with an understanding of the special requirements of the creative enterprise itself. MSLCE 472 will introduce students to the most contemporary thinking related to consumer-centered marketing, known as IMC. The course is intentionally designed to blend theory with application both inside and outside of the classroom.

name: Understanding Media Markets: Users, Makers, and Metrics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Digital media create a marketplace where an endless number of options compete for a limited supply of public attention - an environment where building audiences is a prerequisite for making money or exercising influence. This course explains how the preferences and habits of media users, the strategies and constraints of media makers, and the growing prevalence of data and metrics form a dynamic marketplace that shapes public attention. Topics include theories of media choice, the role of social networks, sharing economies, audience-making strategies, bias in measurement, recommender systems, big data, audience fragmentation, and the marketplace of ideas.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Elberse, Anita (2013). Blockbusters: Hit-making, Risk-Taking, and the Big Business of Entertainment. New York: Henry Holt. ISBN: 0805094334

Webster, J. G. (2014). The Marketplace of Attention: How Audiences Take Shape in a Digital Age. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. ISBN: 978-0262529891

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is structured as a seminar, providing a learning environment devoted to i. exploring current issues in, or affecting, creative enterprises and ii. solutions to address them. Concerns about the lack of racial diversity and the varied perspectives on how to address those concerns are prominent matters within arts and cultural sectors. Therefore, the Spring 2020 seminar is focused on matters relating to racial diversity, inclusion and equity within arts and entertainment.

The seminar will be comprised of reflective discussion on course materials, insights shared by guest speakers, and personal insights. Ultimately, this course will help students deepen their understanding of racial diversity, inclusion and equity within the arts and entertainment sectors, and their insights on ways to address racism within these sectors at the organizational- and systems-levels. Grades are based on class participation, a series of short written reflections, and a final independent project in the form of a paper or podcast.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course provides fundamental tools from the behavioral and social sciences that will improve students' ability to analyze organizational dynamics and to take robust action. More specifically, students will develop their leadership skill-set and toolbox of strategies to be effective leaders of creative industries in general and teams in particular. Leveraging a combination of theory and practice, a hand-on applied teaching style will be used to prepare students to be able to support and lead high-performing, creative teams and firms.

In the spring 2020 quarter, this class will meet on five (5) Mondays only throughout the quarter: April 6, April 20, April 27, May 18 (9am-4pm), and June 1 (9am-1pm).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NUvention: Arts consists of ten classes, each in a three-hour session, created to help facilitate the creation, innovation, and organization of new ideas and companies in the field of the creative arts. The goal of this course is to help students understand that success in the arts is a function of passion, work ethic, talent, and entrepreneurial drive; and culminates in a term project that will help translate ideas into potential products or services related to the arts. While we will spend time studying traditional media companies involved in the arts, the goal of the course is to fuel the students' passion to become entrepreneurs in the arts and start a company.

This course is cross-listed with ENTREP476. MSLCE students taking the NUvention: Arts course will be enrolled in this course number by the program.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What is globalization? And how does it affect cultural production? How is it that the cultural products of some countries circulate easier than others? What is the relationship between place and cultural industries? What makes a city a cultural capital? And how is it that cities compete via culture to appropriate economic capital? This course will address these and other questions through an engagement with scholarship on a range of creative industries including fashion, television, music, movies, fine arts, and the high-end food industry. The course is designed to provide a historical and theoretical introduction to the intersection between globalization and cultural production and to allow students to apply that knowledge to a range of contexts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This elective provides an opportunity for MSLCE students to craft their own career development plan and execute that plan through the completion of a customized course comprised of professional development, industry-based learning activities, and reflection assignments. To earn course credit, students are required to attend and actively participate in the equivalent of 15.0 hours of activity comprised of a combination of events and sessions organized by MSLCE, School of Communication/EPICS Office, or other approved activities. This includes, but is not limited to, speaker events, site visits, career sessions, external networking events, informational interviews, and coaching. Students will also have the opportunity to reflect on their activities, efforts, and the insights they gain that are most germane to their own professional development through written assignments and the development of a career action plan. Note: This course does not have regular class meetings. All course communication and documentation will be maintained through the course Canvas site.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course takes up issues concerning evidence-based general claims about message effects. It addresses the design and analysis of primary research (e.g., case-category confounds, NHST and its discontents, the "replication crisis") and the pursuit of research synthesis through meta-analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"How do elite chefs come up with new recipes? What makes blues authentic? What makes a model successful? What is the difference between art and craft? How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this?
This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced."

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course examines the effects of mass media on individuals and groups in society. Media content and effects are explored in various domains, including politics, violence, pornography, health, science, video games, as well as pro-social and environmental news media. The course begins with a historical overview of theory, methodology and research in the realm of media effects. The course continues with extensive survey of contemporary research about the role of media in facilitating changes in people and society, and consideration of possible explanations of how media effects occur. The course will conclude with discussion of possible ways to diminish socially undesirable media effects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Sparks, G. G. (2015). Media effects research: A basic review. (5th Ed) Boston, MA: Wadsworth.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of class

The course studies the performance of poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction. It explores how performance helps the performer and audience to understand a text; it considers in what ways a performance can "match" a written text; and it examines the techniques of performance. Students write three critical papers and give three live, graded performances. There are some quizzes and workshops. The class is neither an acting class nor an English class, but it draws on practices fundamental to both. Much of class time will be devoted to performance of texts and rigorous critical discussion of the performances and the works on which they are based. Consequently, attendance is mandatory. It examines the role of the audience in the critical reception of the text. The course is designed for both students with little prior performance experience and those with considerable theatrical experience.

It is an excellent course for students to take who want to become excellent communicators; it hones your professional skills and gives you the poise and confidence to excel in the "real world."

descriptions.value: none

descriptions.value: materials will be made available to students on Canvas or at the library at no cost

descriptions.value:
Class Materials (Required)

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course asks the question: How are stories and storytelling central to our lives and to human communication? We will explore how storytelling performances reflect our families, communities, culture, and nation. To engage the power and significance of storytelling performance we will focus on three units: (1) Oral Narrative. Students will learn how to conduct in-depth interviews, on a particular topic, to gather oral narratives and their meanings from specific family, friends, or community members. (2) Myth. Students will read and discuss ancient and contemporary myths to unravel deeper questions about local and global experiences. (3) News Reports. Through guided instruction students will select a current news story, from electronic or newspaper journalism, they feel reveals an urgent issue they are compelled to share. Each of the three units will culminate in a performance: a solo performance of an oral narrative, a group performance of a myth and, finally, a multi-media group performance of a news story. The course is highly interactive and performance based. The unifying thread and overarching question for the course is: How does storytelling performance and creative communication help us better engage and illuminate our world and the world of others, e.g., identity, family, community, nation, social relations, political institutions and economic orders?

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: materials will be made available to students on Canvas or at the library at no cost

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Description and Purpose: To introduce students to a wide range of poetic voices and styles with a concentration on prosody; to cultivate the ability to attend to dense and sometimes complicated text with pleasure; to improve our ability to see, describe and respond to performance in a specific, astute and empathetic way; to bring to consciousness the relationship between form and content, image and idea; to develop performance skills and to engender or amplify a life-long love of poetry that may be of aid in the darkest hours.

Course requirements: Two short performances and one recital; a brief paper, a final paper, a scan of a poem, and a mid-term on prosody; two ungraded tasks (leading discussion on a poem and handing in a paragraph describing your recital); consistent class attendance and participation; reading of all assigned and performed poems.

Note: no electronic devices allowed in the classroom unless they are part of a performance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is an introduction to the history and practice of performance art. Drawing on myths, fairy tales, dreams and music, students will create three solo performances and collaborate in the creation of two group performances, all with specific criteria and parameters. Students will write short papers on each other's performances and a term paper. There will be a mid-term as well on the readings and classwork up to that point. The course is designed to tease out the elements of theatricality within performance: sound, light, image and movement; and to practice attending to performance in a highly detailed and focus way in order to understand how performance deploys these elements to create feeling, meaning and the ineffable.

Note: no electronic devices are allowed in class unless they are part of a performance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Goldberg, Rosalee. Performance Art: From Futurism to the Present, 3rd ed. Thames & Hudson. 2011. Two ISBN numbers: ISBN-13: 978-0500204047
ISBN-10: 0500204047. Widely available used and in pdf format online.

Course Packet at Quartet Copies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What is folklore and how have we come to understand it in relation to the idea of the nation? What have been the contributions and interventions by queer and trans populations in redefining nationalistic and gendered ideas of folklore? This course serves as an introduction to the study of folklore with a particular emphasis on the ways expressions of gender and sexual non-normativity have challenged heteronormative views of folklore as an ideology and narrative. Students will explore works from Folklore Studies and Queer Studies side by side to allow for the unusual conversation between these two fields. Particularly, students will develop skills in textual, visual, performance, and ethnographic analysis, which will enable them to theorize and define folklore in new ways. By exploring a wide range of performance practices such as patron-saint festivals, dance, carnivals, rituals, music, oral traditions, and performance and visual art, we will examine how concepts such as tradition, religion, race and ethnicity, class, authenticity, and indigeneity have played important roles in defining folkloric practices as such. In this sense, we will ask how queerness is represented but also serves as an optic to look at folklore in more expansive and inclusive manners. Students will engage in written assignments, autoethnographic exercises, and a short performance project. Although we will engage our conversations hemispherically and globally, most of the case studies will focus on folklore in the Americas. No previous performance experience or knowledge of Spanish and Portuguese are required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: materials will be made available to students on Canvas or at the library at no cost

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: SoulWork is a comprehensive method for making performance that includes acting, singing, directing, writing, ensemble-building and community engagement. Created by Dr. Cristal Chanelle Truscott from generations-old principles of African American performance traditions, SoulWork aims to create opportunities for connection and social and creative power for communities across race, class, gender and spiritual identity. SoulWork's practical techniques will be explored through an interactive blend of discussion, readings/viewings, workshops and training in SoulWork technique and participation in an ensemble performance sharing at the end of the course. This course will focus on an introduction to SoulWork's key principles of Cultural Conservatory, Call/Invitation, Living in Call & Response, Emotional Availability and Unending Climax. Students will be encouraged to bring the fullness of their identities to this practice - to investigate the creative power of culturally-specific and culturally-aware artistic methods/processes, to explore socially-conscious engagement with devising texts and ensemble-building, and to rehearse and perform with emotional flexibility and spontaneity.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: materials will be made available to students on Canvas or at the library at no cost

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course offers an introduction to theoretical debates on the engagement of performance as focus, critical framework, and as technique in curatorial practice as well as a practical workshop on the protocols of exhibition and programming development around contemporary performance. We will consider curation broadly to include the development of contemporary performance (theatre, dance, performance art) in museum and gallery settings and formal performance spaces. We will also engage more traditional exhibition contexts where the presentation of objects (artistic or otherwise) or the engagement with audiences (in art institutions or elsewhere) are conceptualized or intervened by means of performance. Through a series of case studies and site visits, workshops, and critical discussions and writing tasks, students will develop broad knowledge of the field as well as an individual curatorial project proposal.

descriptions.value:
This course offers an introduction to theoretical debates on the engagement of performance as focus, critical framework, and as technique in curatorial practice as well as a practical workshop on the protocols of exhibition and programming development around contemporary performance. We will consider curation broadly to include the development of contemporary performance (theatre, dance, performance art) in museum and gallery settings and formal performance spaces. We will also engage more traditional exhibition contexts where the presentation of objects (artistic or otherwise) or the engagement with audiences (in art institutions or elsewhere) are conceptualized or intervened by means of performance. Through a series of case studies and site visits, workshops, and critical discussions and writing tasks, students will develop broad knowledge of the field as well as an individual curatorial project proposal.

The class requires three site visits outside of the regular course schedule which will be arranged as group experiences.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will investigate the role of the body in the emerging field of Queer African Studies. Looking to performance, visual art, film, and literature, students will consider what it means to engage African studies through a queer optic, and examine how queerness has been discussed, theorized and articulated via the "African" body.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video exercises and will culminate in the production of group short films.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will have a working knowledge of the core components, both technical and theoretical, of creating media.

descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, lab, and screenings.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Projects will be evaluated on technical achievement (videography, sound, editing, lighting, and production design) as well as their ability to convey narrative. There will also be written and practical exams.

Each student must pay a $50 refundable equipment deposit to the equipment cage in Louis Hall by week 2 of the quarter. This is a pre-requisite for checking out the required equipment for class, as well as using the editing lab.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Through lectures, reading assignments, discussions, in-class screenings, and in-class workshops, this course provides a supportive environment where students are encouraged to take risks and experiment as they discover their narrative voice. Students will have opportunities to work both individually and primarily, collaboratively, in small groups. Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video assignments and will culminate in the production of group short films.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will attempt to account for major theoretical, industrial, aesthetic, and political developments in international postwar cinema. Contemporary and historical texts will be presented and discussed in class sessions to inform an understanding of critical issues in the evolution of narrative cinema from 1948-2000. Films from Alfred Hitchcock, Jean-Luc Godard, Agnes Varda, and Barbara Kopple, among others, will be screened. Readings include essays from Andre Bazin, Linda Williams, bell hooks, and Peter Wollen.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop methodologies for analyzing films, learn to present their analysis, and gain experience using scholarly texts to develop new insight.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class/Discussion Section participation, Team presentations, Final Project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings/films on Canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We know very well that media texts are collaborative projects: when we see the credits roll at the end of a major film for example, we see hundreds of names and numerous specialized tasks. And yet the idea of an individual creator still has a powerful hold over the way most of us think about and experience the media. What does it mean to be an "author" in the creative industries? What is the nature of creative work? How are artistic reputations constructed and understood? What role do critics and audiences play in that process? Why some media texts have authors and others don't? How does collaboration work in the creative industries? In this course we will investigate these and other questions through the analysis of the transmedia career of David Lynch.

Lynch's output covers a remarkably wide range of production contexts and media forms, encompassing visual art, film, television, photography, furniture design, popular music, online films, digital cinematography, and virtual reality. Lynch can be seen as the ultimate crossover artist: a cult filmmaker who went on to have a hit network television series ("Twin Peaks") the same year as winning the Golden Palm at the Cannes Film Festival. Starting his career as a painter, he emerged as an avant-garde filmmaker in the early 1970s. After his first feature Eraserhead achieved the status of a cult classic on the "midnight movie" circuit, Lynch jumped into mainstream filmmaking, and has become one of the rare directors to find success with general audiences, cult fans, and academics. Films such as Blue Velvet became touchstones for film theorists during the 1980s, and are still discussed in academic circles today. Lynch has never been without his critics, and his work has come under fire for its depiction of women, sexual violence, race, and class. Lynch has often had creative control over his projects, and yet his distinctive "Lynchian" signature was forged through long-standing collaborative relationships with a cohort of actors, composers, editors, and sound designers. Lynch is thus a remarkably fertile case study for a consideration of media authorship, modes of collaboration in the creative industries, the history of film culture since the 1970s, the various logics of film, television, and digital media, the importance of sound design in audio-visual media, the representation of race, class, and gender, and a range of other issues.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Think critically and comparatively about the production practices of various media industries;

- Analyze the relationship between media authors and their social, cultural and historical context;

- Create critical commentary about a prominent media creator in the genre of the videographic essay;

- Better understand the nature of creative collaboration in the media industries.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be assessed through: 1) a portfolio of short response papers; 2) three short videographic essays made using Adobe Premiere and clips from Lynch's oeuvre; 3) in-class reading quizzes; 4) a short critical review of the new "Twin Peaks" VR experience,

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Chris Rodley ed., Lynch on Lynch
Bernard Pomerance, The Elephant Man: A Play
Justus Nieland, David Lynch

Other readings available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class considers the pleasures and perils of the romantic comedy, organized in short units that highlight specific aspects of the genre. The first two units focus on common narrative devices that make the genre less than benign: deception and competition between women. The third unit considers a group of films that are barely rom-coms even as they conclude in the formation of romantic couples. We consider whether these ex-centric variations offer any respite from the perils of deceit and competitiveness. The final unit will be student-generated. (Time will be allotted within the class period for groups to meet, develop a short unit; half-way through the quarter, different proposals will be shared with the class which will, as a group, decide what the final unit will be.)

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance-participation; Notes on weekly reading assignments; short assignments to devise a final unit; two take-home essays.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: As described by critic Mark Fischer, "Capitalist Realism" describes "the widespread sense that not only is capitalism the only viable political and economic system, but also that it is now impossible even to imagine a coherent alternative to it." This course examines contemporary literature and cinema that addresses the styles and themes of "capitalist realism" as an aesthetic, as well as the affective dimensions of neo-liberal culture.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, students will pitch and create a half-hour comedy pilot for television. The emphasis
will be on developing a story's humor from the ground (or premise) up, creating compelling
characters, and developing our comedic voices.
There will be weekly assignments which include writing assignments, readings, and watching
half-hour comedies. Each student will be expected to develop a pitch for their original series,
write a first and final draft of a comedy pilot (25-30 pages), and engage in collaborative
workshop discussions.

Netflix.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class, students will create original stories for the stage and screen in which they may
choose to play a lead or major role. Inspired by the current trend in television ( Insecure, Atlanta,
Girls, Fleabag, Curb Your Enthusiasm ) wherein the writer-actor is also a series creator and star,
this course will explore strategies for writing great roles for actors and using a writer-actor brain
to develop characters and stories. Students will not be required to play a major role in their piece
and previous acting experience is not required.
There will be weekly assignments which include writing assignments, readings, and watching
television and film. Each student will write a first draft of a television pilot, one-act play, or short
film, and a final draft (25-30 pages). Students will engage in collaborative workshop discussions
of one another's scripts.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? Readings, episodes, and films available on reserve and online via CANVAS
Internet access, NU email/account, word processing program, and xeroxing of materials (scripts)
required for writing workshop and class discussion . Students will need access to Amazon Prime
and Netflix.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this class, we will utilize a variety of research methods as springboards for creating original content for the stage and screen. Through written exercises and field assignments we will explore ways to use facts and research to create compelling narratives that stick to the facts as well as stories and adaptations inspired by true events. We will study examples of plays, films, and television, which use research as jumping off points.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Weekly assignments will include writing exercises, readings, films, and television shows. Each student will be expected to complete two short (5-10 page) scripts and at least one complete one-act play, short film, or pilot episode, which totals 25-30 pages in length and is drawn from some kind of research.

? The Laramie Project by Moisés Kaufman / Tectonic Theatre (ISBN-13: 978- 0375727191)
? Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992 by Anna Deavere Smith (ISBN-13: 978-0385473767)
? Additional readings and films available on reserve and online via CANVAS

Internet access, NU email account, word processing program, and Xeroxing of materials required for writing workshop and class discussion

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The phrase "strong female character" is often used to describe women written for screen and stage, but often writers equate "strength" with male-centric attributes or one-dimensional perfection. This workshop-based class will examine gender bias in media's portrayal of women and the artists who are breaking these biases. We will explore the mechanics of writing dialogue, story structure and relationships for complex, female-driven narratives. The class will be structured through lectures, reading assignments, viewing of streamed films, discussion, in-class viewing of film clips and workshop of student writing assignments. By the end of the quarter, each student will complete a full first draft of an original female-centric screenplay or television pilot.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Sophomore year student.
Completion of RTVF 260 - Foundations of Screenwriting

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class will be structured through writing assignments, lectures, reading assignments, viewing of streamed films, discussion, in-class viewing of film clips and workshop of student writing.

In-class participation
Writing/Development Assignments
Script Outline
Final Scripts

Software: Screenplay/Screenwriting Software - Student's preference. Multiple options will be provided. Cost ranges from $0 to $129.99 for industry standard (Final Draft 10 - Student version).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Artists have the opportunity to grapple with the most complex problems facing our communities. Whether we define community in a local, national, or global context, climate change is radically shifting our world right now. How can the tools of dramatic storytelling be used to combat the issues of climate change? How can writers subvert binaries such as man versus nature or destruction versus salvation to create nuanced, riveting narratives on ecological themes? How can we interrogate concepts like solastalgia (mourning an ecosystem) and climate justice, and offer aesthetic antidotes to the "issue play" approach to climate change narratives? We will explore these questions using examples ranging from Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard to Pixar's WALL-E in conjunction with scientific, journalistic, and historical research as templates for our own dramatic imaginations. Through weekly labs and writing prompts, writers will generate material for a full-length work (play, screenplay, or pilot) focusing on a discrete aspect of climate change that speaks most directly to them.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, weekly writing assignments, final writing project of minimum 30 pages

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Laptop or tablet with a working internet connection and access to Google drive
The Cherry Orchard by Anton Chekhov (any translation/edition)
Wall-E (available to rent through a variety of online streaming platforms, $3)
Snowpiercer (available to rent through a variety of online streaming platforms, $4)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Leave No Trace (available to rent through a variety of online streaming platforms, $4)

All other materials will be provided electronically.

The approximate cost for required materials is $15 or less. Suggested materials are approximately $4.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The evolution of the current content landscape has opened up a swath of opportunities for short form content creators. Streamers, studios, OTT platforms, and traditional TV networks are not only purchasing short-form content, but they are developing it from within.

The digital series has reached a point in the marketplace where is no longer just a stepping-stone to larger episodic projects, but a commercially and critically viable medium of its own.

In "Writing the Digital Series" students will craft new work on original series concepts that are positioned to take advantage of these opportunities. The class will work individually and as a group to shape multiple episodes that would be consider ?ready for production' at the end of the quarter.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Sophomore year student.
Completion of RTVF 260 - Foundations of Screenwriting

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to do the following:

1. Develop an original creative idea specifically tailored for digital series/new media.
2. Convey the top level creative details of their concept in the form of a Series/Show Bible
3. Craft screenplays for multiple episodes of the digital series
4. Create believable characters, organic dialogue, and motivated action
5. Better collaborate with other writers in a writers room-style creative environment
6. Evaluate short form scripts for production and commercial viability

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Students can expect a combination of in-class lecture, outside reading and writing assignments, pilot screenings, and in-class writing workshops throughout the quarter.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

In-class participation

Series Bible
Episode Scripts

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will learn how to create a feature-length screenplay for a limited budget. By creating and workshopping a completed first draft of a script, students will learn about story structure, personal filmmaking, self-producing, creative casting and other aspects of putting together a micro-budget movie.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will have a working knowledge of and fresh empowerment to tackle the full-length micro-budget screenplay.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: In-class workshops and discussions, extensive talks, readings, guests, screenings.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based on writing progress and engagement with in-class discussions, screenings and fellow student evaluations.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an advanced-level writing course with a focus on creating original screenplays that students could potentially produce during their time in RTVF. We'll do multiple idea-generating exercises to help come up with topics for their films; workshop ideas and screenplays together as a class; and discuss ways to move these finished screenplays into produced films. This course will focus on the short screenplay, but all concepts and fundamentals we cover will springboard students into upper-level courses where they will pursue longer-form projects.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: RTVF 260: Foundations of Screenwriting

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, reading assignments, discussion, in-class screenings, and in-class workshop of student assignments.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Screenplays will be graded on their ability to creatively and effectively convey narrative, as well as professionalism.

name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will learn the fundamentals of film producing, from pre-production through distribution, primarily through the lens of independent/low-budget filmmaking. Emphasis will be placed on both applied research and hands-on practice through serving as producer on a student short film in pre-production or production during the quarter. Course guest speakers always includes local and nationally recognized film producers and filmmakers for real-world advice about the art of producing. You will be required to deliver an end-of-quarter pitch presentation supplying a detailed schedule and budget for the short film to which you are attached as a co-producer.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: RTVF 190

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Ability to evaluate, breakdown and budget scripts for production
- Articulate professional standards-of-practice for industry producers
- Learn the art of development pitching
- Learn how media works are monetized in the contemporary field of practice

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance/discussion participation, one short essay, one scheduling exercise and one final pitch presentation which includes a full shooting schedule and budget.

Additional screenings/readings assigned via Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Editing is considered by many to be the critical artistic expression of filmmaking; on par with dialogue, cinematography, even writing. In this class, you will take crucial steps towards your evolution as an editor of the moving image. We will do this by reading and discussing critical editing concepts, including the basic editing stages, practices and terminology. We will discuss how and why these different elements work to further the story and develop the vision of a film. We will watch also films and the discuss techniques employed, seeing the concepts we've discussed appear in film and analyzing their effectiveness. And, of course, you will be working extensively with hands-on editing in Adobe Premiere on several excercises and one main project: you will work with uncut footage provided by the instructor to increase your creative analysis and develop your own style and voice as an editor.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Texts:
1. Dmytryk, Edward: On Film Editing
2. Murch, Walter: In the Blink of an Eye

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Examine basic principles of the combination art and craft that is cinematography and produce work exploring those principles.

descriptions.value: Mechanix Safety Gloves

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in game production. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for game creation as well as how to choose an effective and meaningful tool to resolves a particular concept.

descriptions.value:

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class will introduce you to the art and skill of color timing, AKA color correction. The class will be a rewarding mixture of the artistic and technical, with a deeply hands-on workshop-type of approach.

Using Davinci Resolve, you will learn the fundamentals in primary, secondary, and effects color correction, as well as stabilizing and tracking. While the focus of the class will be on DaVinci Resolve, we will also explore the color grading capabilities in Adobe Premiere. You'll be evaluated through several in-class exercises and one main project. There will be a final exam that takes the form of a practical exam. We will attempt to visit a post-production facility each quarter and may host a masterclass with a Chicago-based professional colorist.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbooks or equipment are necessary.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What happens after your film is finished? How do you find an audience for your work? Do you need a distributor or can you tackle self-distribution? This course will explore how filmmakers can navigate the many potential pathways and platforms that are available in today's competitive distribution and exhibition landscape. We will discuss marketing, DIY and traditional distribution, festivals, audience engagement, and a range of potential outlets (online, broadcast, and brick-and-mortar) in order to help students develop a marketing and distribution strategy for their own non-fiction projects.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain a solid understanding of the distribution and exhibition phase, allowing them to navigate that landscape more successfully as media makers. They will be able to apply that knowledge to the marketing, festival and distribution strategies for their own films.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based on individual assignments, a marketing and distribution plan for their own project, as well as attendance and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No expenses for class materials expected. Readings will be provided by the instructor as PDFs or webpages. They will include the Doc Society's Impact Field Guide & Tool Kit, Sundance Distribution Case Studies, and a collection of articles related to festivals, marketing, and distribution.

RTVF 190.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
An introduction to various narrative forms (e.g. elliptical, minimalist, fractured, parallel, micro-fiction, episodic, environmental, ensemble, et al) that scramble notions of traditional "hero centered" three-act structure and posit alternate world views to narrative causality. The class will view and analyze a range of representative films with accompanied readings from a practitioners point of view (e.g. Wong Kar-Wai's In The Mood For Love, Julie Dash's Daughters of the Dust, Athina Tsangari's Chevalier, Chantal Akerman's The Meetings of Anna, Luis Bunuel's Un Chien Andalou, Lindsay Anderson's If?, Michael Haneke's Code Unknown, Jane Campion's Peel, Lynne Ramsay's Small Deaths, Apichatpong Weerasethakul's Tropical Malady, Akira Kurosawa's Roshomon, Souleymane Cissé's Brightnesss, Alain Rene's Hiroshima Mon Amour, Leo Carax's Holy Motors, et al). Students will then write and create final short film projects positing their own narrative strategies working either as individuals or in pairs.

Warning: Please research the list of sample films above. Most films screened are counter-cultural works which were created to provoke a strong emotional response. Many contain what might be for some viewers disturbing depictions of violence and sexual content. Most are chosen because they are recognized by the field as exceptional works for narrative experimentation. You are encouraged to respond and critique each filmmaker's approach to discover more about your personal voice as an artist.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Identify alternative narrative fiction film forms and analyze ways in which they posit oppositional "world views" to dominant restorative three-act structure

- Create an alternative narrative short fiction film based upon the student's own concerns as a media artist.

- Learn development and production techniques used by film artists interested in alternative narrative forms.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? Alternative Scriptwriting: Beyond the Hollywood Formula by Ken Dancyger and Jeff Rush, Focal Press, ISBN-13 978-0240522463 Edition 5

? Additional readings posted to Canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
A recent New York Times op-ed was cheerfully titled "The Darkness Where the Future Should Be." Climate change, political dysfunction, surveillance capitalism, online dating? things don't look great. (Sorry!) On the other hand, artists/writers/filmmakers have been rising to the representational challenge with creative depictions, warnings, and philosophical ruminations on human possibility, across a variety of genres (sci-fi, comedy et al). How will you rise to the challenge?


? All students will be shooting their final projects in this class. COSTS will vary according to the ambition of the project (there are small production grants available to the class).
? No late adds and you must be at the first class to hold your spot.
? We'll be pitching/brainstorming at the first class, details TBA.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of the class is to write and shoot a final project (6-9 min) from original or adapted material in which you explore some variation on this theme. You can work independently or in small groups. We'll be screening (outside class) a film each week; you'll do a class presentation on a dystopian novel of your choice; you'll script/shoot your own intervention. Though this process you'll explore this far-ranging topic, develop your directing/production skills, and end up with a solid rough cut (you can do more sound and post-production down the road if you choose).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: COSTS will vary according to the ambition of the project (there are small production grants available to the class).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Satire: The use of humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize the stupidity or vices of people (or society or institutions), particularly in the context of contemporary politics and other topical issues. It intends to improve humanity by criticizing its follies and foibles.

So here's the question: what do you care enough about to want to satirize it? A class on satire is a reverse way of discovering what you value. Additional challenge: It's easy to shoot fish in barrels, ie to ridicule the ridiculous. What about taking it to another level, ie being both satirical and subtle?

? All students will be shooting their final projects in this class. COSTS will vary according to the ambition of the project (there are small production grants available to the class).
? No late adds and you must be at the first class to hold your spot.
? We'll be pitching/brainstorming at the first class, details TBA.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of the class is to write and shoot a final project (6-9 min) from original or adapted material in which you explore some variation of these questions, themes. You can work independently or in small groups. We'll be screening (outside class) a film each week; you'll do a class presentation on a satirical novel of your choice; you'll script/shoot your own intervention. Though this process you'll refine your understanding of this genre, develop your directing/production skills, and end up with a solid rough cut (you can do more sound and post-production down the road if you choose).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will examine documentary practices and produce their own 6 to 8 minute short. The emphasis will be on watching and workshopping what students generate, as well as screening and discussing clips from a diverse array of filmmakers. Class participants will consider: What trends are cutting-edge in non-fiction filmmaking, and in what ways are these trends influencing the field? How can stylistic choice underscore content? Why do ethical considerations become paramount for many documentarians? How can filmmakers influence society, and what types of tools increase impact? What are the traditional versus alternative/emerging possibilities for financing and viewership?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
First class mandatory unless cleared by the professor
Students may either direct and produce individually or work in teams of two. Crewing for your peers is encouraged, but not required. As RTVF 190 is the prerequisite, students should arrive with a working knowledge of equipment and editing software. All students should expect to spend a substantial amount of time completing assignments outside of class.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By analyzing a variety of non-fiction films and creating a short, participants will gain a more sophisticated understanding of the documentary genre.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Still image assignment: 5 points
Soundscape project: 5 points
Pitch and written proposal: 10 points
Rough cut: 20 points
Final Documentary: 40 points
Attendance, participation, various written exercises, professionalism: 20 points

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. You will need a portable hard drive to store your footage and for editing-recommended: 1 TB. You will also need an additional backup method-I highly recommend a second portable hard drive. If cost is prohibitive, please see below.
2. To access RTVF equipment, you must have a $50 Cage deposit on file.
3. Media assignments are to be turned-in via private Vimeo links. However, arrangements may be worked out with the professor in advance of the assignment due dates, to eliminate costs. As of this writing, the price of a Plus account is $7/mo billed annually and limits your uploads to 5GB/week. A Pro account is $20/mo billed annually and limits your uploads to 20GB/wk.
4. Reading assignments will be available on Canvas or in class.

*Please note, undergraduate students enrolled in RTVF production classes who demonstrate financial need may qualify to checkout a 1TB external hard drive to execute their project assignments. Applications for the School of Communication RTVF External Hard Drive Program must be submitted using the SES One Form and can be accessed here: https://northwestern.academicworks.com/ Applications will be reviewed on a rolling basis. Students are encouraged to apply during the first week of the quarter. Once approved for this program, students can check out an external drive through the Cage's web checkout system as they would any other equipment: http://webcheckout.northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar examines the historical association between media and ghosts. We will examine both the "haunted" qualities of various media (radio, television, computers, etc) as well as the representation of haunted spaces through the media. Individual topics include seance technologies, movie ghosts, paranormal reality television, and digital discorporation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Reading materials will total less than $50

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores of the cultural, political, and aesthetic history of television. We will especially concentrate on US TV's "classic three network" period from the 1950s-1980s and trace changes in the medium up through TV's convergence with digital/streaming media. The class also considers broader theoretical and methodological questions about media history and culture more generally, and we explore the history of alternative television/video as well as TV on mainstream venues. Although the focus is on US TV, students may will write seminar papers on any national/transnational television system, and may also write about contemporary TV through a historical perspective.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required course reader (on blackboard)

Books:

Aniko Bodroghkozy, The Groove Tube (Minneapolis: U of Minnesota Press, 1994)

Anna McCarthy, The Citizen Machine: Governing By Television in 1950s America (New York: New Press, 2010)

Lynn Spigel, Make Room for TV (Chicago: U of Chicago Press, 1992) (Free copies available)

Gayle Wald. "It's Been Beautiful " Soul and Black Power Television (Durham, Duke UP. 2015).

Tan Lin. Insomnia and the Aunt (Chicago: Kenning Editions, 2011).

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar, first year MFA in Documentary Media students will build the foundation for their thesis project, which can either be a 10-20 min film or an interactive/new media project that they will complete during their second year of study. Students will generate ideas, delve into research, and explore various methods of approach for their project. Modeled after the pre-production phase of professionally produced documentaries, the course will guide students in developing a verbal pitch, written proposal, and work sample. Students will also learn about different film funding sources and how to envision their projects' potential audience and impact.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Completed work products: pitch, written proposal, and work sample. Students are expected to present their work in class and participate in class discussions and workshops. Readings and additional homework assignments are also required.

1. You will need a portable hard drive to store your footage and for editing-recommended: 1 TB. You will also need an additional backup method-I highly recommend a second portable hard drive. (All MFA in Doc students should already be equipped with both)
2. To access RTVF equipment, you must have a $50 Cage deposit on file.
3. Media assignments are to be turned-in via private Vimeo links. However, if the cost is prohibitive, alternate arrangements may be worked out with the professor in advance of the assignment due dates. As of this writing, the price of a Plus account is $7/mo billed annually and limits your uploads to 5GB/week. A Pro account is $20/mo billed annually and limits your uploads to 20GB/wk.
4. Reading assignments will be available on Canvas or in class.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a workshop that will explore the intersection between new media production and documentary practice. The course will approach interactive documentary as an emerging field. Students will study the history and theory of interactive documentary while actively contributing to field as it develops. The course will focus on unique aesthetics and affordances of documentary narratives when expressed through hypertext, interactive video, video gaming, as well as other hybrid genres. Students will develop their own interactive documentary projects with special attention to web publication. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior experience working with digital tools, but who are prepared to engage their own documentary practice with new media techniques at a graduate level.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in interactive documentary. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for expressing their own ideas through interactive documentary as an individual production practice. Students should also be able to discern what tool and approach is appropriate and effective for a given concept, as well as how to seek out additional resources on their own.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.
Twine (provided on computers in lab)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this final thesis track course, students will complete the post-production phase of their thesis projects, exhibit their finished works, and plan for their emergence into the field as media-makers. Post-production will include finishing steps such as sound mix, color correction and final digital file delivery. Exhibition will involve curating, planning and contextualizing the NUDocs show at Block Museum of their completed films or interactive media projects. Students will refine their artist statements, log-line and project descriptions in preparation of their MFA defenses and beyond. The course will also serve as an introduction to emerging into the field of documentary practice, including introduction to: curation, publicity, distribution, fundraising, festivals, and sustainability, culminating in reflection on individual career plans.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Students will acquire the necessary skills to take their thesis project through a series of finishing steps all the way to exhibition, outreach, marketing, and event production.
- Students will share knowledge as they survey the field of documentary practice, learning to construct a professional artistic plan

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, in class presentations, assignments, participation in event planning, and completed 10-20 minute thesis film or equivalent interactive project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Students are expected to own a portable hard drive for editing and budget their production grant award to cover any external costs (e.g. sound mix, graphics, and color correction). Readings will be provided via Canvas as PDFs or digital links.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this class, we will study the fundamentals of writing a teleplay from concept, logline, and treatment to story arc and season outline. Through reading assignments, viewing coursework, and written exercises we will explore ways to write TV episodes suited to a variety of interests, tastes, and aesthetics. We will study examples from TV of the past and present as well as more emerging web-based forms.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: There will be weekly assignments, which will include writing, reading, and viewing. Over the course of the quarter each student will be expected to draft a treatment, outline, and write an original episode of TV, which totals 30-60 pages in length.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? The Thirty-Six Dramatic Situations by Georges Polti (ISBN-13: 978-1585093731)
? Additional readings and episodes available on reserve and online via CANVAS

Internet access, NU email account, word processing program, and Xeroxing of materials required for writing workshop and class discussion

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
We know very well that media texts are collaborative projects: when we see the credits roll at the end of a major film for example, we see hundreds of names and numerous specialized tasks. And yet the idea of an individual creator still has a powerful hold over the way most of us think about and experience the media. What does it mean to be an "author" in the creative industries? What is the nature of creative work? How are artistic reputations constructed and understood? What role do critics and audiences play in that process? Why so some media texts have authors and others don't? How does collaboration work in the creative industries? In this course we will investigate these and other questions through the analysis of the transmedia career of David Lynch.

Lynch's output covers a remarkably wide range of production contexts and media forms, encompassing visual art, film, television, photography, furniture design, popular music, online films, digital cinematography, and virtual reality. Lynch can be seen as the ultimate crossover artist: a cult filmmaker who went on to have a hit network television series ("Twin Peaks") the same year as winning the Golden Palm at the Cannes Film Festival. Starting his career as a painter, he emerged as an avant-garde filmmaker in the early 1970s. After his first feature Eraserhead achieved the status of a cult classic on the "midnight movie" circuit, Lynch jumped into mainstream filmmaking, and has become one of the rare directors to find success with general audiences, cult fans, and academics. Films such as Blue Velvet became touchstones for film theorists during the 1980s, and are still discussed in academic circles today. Lynch has never been without his critics, and his work has come under fire for its depiction of women, sexual violence, race, and class. Lynch has often had creative control over his projects, and yet his distinctive "Lynchian" signature was forged through long-standing collaborative relationships with a cohort of actors, composers, editors, and sound designers. Lynch is thus a remarkably fertile case study for a consideration of media authorship, modes of collaboration in the creative industries, the history of film culture since the 1970s, the various logics of film, television, and digital media, the importance of sound design in audio-visual media, the representation of race, class, and gender, and a range of other issues.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students should be able to:

  • Think critically and comparatively about the production practices of various media industries;

  • Analyze the relationship between media authors and their social, cultural and historical context;

  • Create critical commentary about a prominent media creator in the genre of the videographic essay;

  • Better understand the nature of creative collaboration in the media industries.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be assessed through:

  1. a portfolio of short response papers;
  2. three short videographic essays made using Adobe Premiere and clips from Lynch's oeuvre;
  3. in-class reading quizzes;
  4. a short critical review of the new "Twin Peaks" VR experience,

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Chris Rodley ed., Lynch on Lynch
Bernard Pomerance, The Elephant Man: A Play
Justus Nieland, David Lynch

Other readings available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this seminar is to provide structure and support for students in the Sound Arts and Industries program toward the completion of their Study in Sound. This is accomplished through a participatory format of presentation, discussion, and critique supporting the formulation and incremental refinement of each student's capstone project. This process will culminate in the final presentation of Study in Sound, in whatever format best suits the work accomplished. The format, scheduling, and execution of the final Study in Sound presentations will be done as a class project.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The learning objectives of the course will be determined by each student, as they pertain to their individual goals.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be evaluated on the basis of:

  • their proposal of, and adherence to, a plan of work for the quarter

  • approximately 5 presentations on ongoing work over the course of the quarter.

  • active participation in class discussion and critiques.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course continues the study of film sound through an exploration of 5.1 recording and mixing techniques. We will look at various examples of surround sound mixing for film and discuss the technology's potential for immersion, presence and spectacle. The idea of surround sound will be broadened to include examples of multi-channel sound art, and studies of acoustics across built environments. Class projects will include 5.1 mixing for film sequences, ambience recording for surround, and site-specific sound installations. Students entering the class should have basic knowledge of Pro Tools and sound recording techniques.

name: Topics in Sound Production
topic: Creative Uses of Field, Found and Archival Recordi

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this project-based course, students are introduced to innovative conceptual and artistic production approaches for field recordings, "found" audio, and archival sound sources in contemporary art, radio, podcasting, journalism, and documentary practices. Students learn through listening examples and in-class discussion.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be encouraged to consider the cultural, historical, conceptual, ecological, and/or other meanings of the audio materials and production approaches in each project. These meanings might drive student working methods, or emerge as part of a class discussion while listening to projects after works are finished. The underlying concepts of the course are applicable to any type of audio-based project. We will consider various creative strategies. For instance, students are encouraged to be open to the possibility that the found or archival audio materials might shape the entire arch and framework of the project, or vice versa.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, 3 assignments, class presentation, final project, attendance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There are no required textbooks or items to purchase in advance. Listening and reading assignments will be available in electronic formats. If students need to use audio recording materials to prepare assignments, they can check them out from the RTF Equipment Cage (requiring a $50 refundable deposit for equipment and $100 for studio). The classroom will be set up for stereo audio and video playback. If a different playback setup is required to present an assignment, please contact me at least two weeks in advance.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Assignments and reading and listening/viewing materials will be available on Canvas or Google Drive. This course is focused on the conceptual strategies and aesthetic techniques related to sound production. However, class projects will require some knowledge of audio recording technology. A working knowledge of a DAW like Reaper or Ableton and portable recording device are encouraged. Due to the short duration of the course, we will not be reviewing technological tools.

Generally speaking, this is a lecture course. However, each student's interest and knowledge will inevitably shape the direction and emphasis of the course design. Each student's participation in the gentle and thoughtful critiques of peers and in class discussions will be crucial to the integrity of the group experience.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Sound Synthesis is a comprehensive introduction to the underlying principles and creative techniques applied to analog and digital synthesizers. The course will integrate sound physics, aesthetics, history, perception, theory, and practice using in-class demonstrations, tutorials, readings, and listening sessions. We will cover various methods of sound synthesis such as subtractive, amplitude modulation, frequency modulation, and more, as well as investigate unique approaches to sample based sound design. Our primary tools will be Max/MSP and an analog modular synthesizer that students will have access to out of class time for projects and assignments. Evaluation will be based on a combination of class participation, assignments, and a final project. No prerequisites necessary, however some prior experience with Max/MSP is encouraged.

name: Interdisciplinary Studies in Theatre and Performance

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course surveys experimental movement-based performance from the 1950s to the present in the U.S., Europe, Japan, India, West Africa, and South Africa. Starting with the Happenings at Black Mountain College, the course looks at Judson Dance Theatre, Butoh, Tanztheater, conceptual dance, black postmodernism, and contemporary dance in Asia and Africa. After situating each movement within the time and place of its initial formation, we'll follow its ideas and practices across national borders. Along the way, we'll discover surprising alliances?Katherine Dunham's impact on Tatsumi Hijikata, the interrelations between Judson and conceptual dance, and the mutual influences of Pina Bausch and Chandralekha. At issue is how to account for the power differentials between the Global North and Global South while also acknowledging the multidimensionality of global circulation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Coursepack at Quartet Copy for $50

descriptions.value: A combination of lecture, discussion, and production lab participation implementing the design and directing process of a theatrical production.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the connections between theatre, performance, and commemoration in the history of Western theatre through the idea of memorial mania, a term coined by memory scholar Erika Doss as "an obsession with issues of memory and history and an urgent desire to express and claim those issues in visibly public contexts." How does memorial mania manifest in the theatre? How do playwrights use historical settings to comment on their contemporary moment? How does performance act as commemorative practice? Are memorials theatrical? To explore these questions, we will examine plays that have dealt with commemoration, history, or memory in some way, read excerpts from Doss' Memorial Mania and from other scholars who examine theatre and memory, and consider why history has been used for centuries in drama.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Required: Students will be expected to spend no more than $25 total for theatre tickets. All other readings and media will be provided via Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course invites students to explore, think, and dance Blackness through engaging with the affect of scholarly texts that address Dance Studies, African American Studies, Post-Colonial Studies, Black Queer Studies, Afro-Caribbean Religion, and Black Feminist Thought; the majority of the texts authored by Black women. Students will conduct performance analysis, choreograph three dance pieces (two short performances and one final performance), reflect on readings weekly in a course journal, and complete a final research paper (5-7 pages) comprised of a performance analysis on a dance piece of their choosing.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Ticketed Performance; $10

name: Theatre in Context: Analysis & Research
topic: The City Space as Performance Space

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course engages with selected performance phenomena in the city space that draw on the specificity of sites, create spaces through performance, or re-articulate or re-signify places in the city space in order to further their goals. Therefore, we will investigate the relationship between bodily practice, social performance, and the production of (architectural) space. The class covers artistic, explicitly theatrical performances as well as processions and demonstrations. Some examples are historical, others contemporary. This juxtaposition enables us to explore in a multitude of research methods and methodologies. Insights gained from the research process of the historical inquiry will enable us to question our assumptions about the use of space in performance today and broaden our range of questions to ask of the performances and sources thereon.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None needed.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will explore the fundamental ingredients of a strong, healthy and sustainable voice. Classwork will lay foundational elements of vocal technique for performance through dynamic exercises related to the major elements of breath and sound production. Students will gain experience and understanding of their own individual voice through an introduction to warmup techniques that will lead to a personalized home vocal practice. Additionally, students will be introduced to the components of the International Phonetic Alphabet as they apply to the Standard American Dialect and in preparation for further voice and dialect study. Classical texts and poetry will be used as performance pieces throughout the course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Voice for Performance by Linda Gates $20.000 paperback $20.00 new, Cambridge English Pronouncing Dictionary (papberback) $22.00, Cats by T.S.Eliot $12.00 (new) $3.00 used

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of class

The focus of this class is on the development of vocal technique for the performer through work on relaxation, body alignment, breathing, vocal placement, resonance and exploration of the sounds of English using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet). Individual vocal problems are analyzed and remedial work prescribed. As vocal skills develop the focus will include connecting the speaking voice to the sounds of English and their relationship to meaning through the use of poetry and selected text. Final will consists on bringing all the elements covered in the class together for a group performance of selected poetry performed on the stage.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Voice for Performance by Linda Gates $20.000 paperback $20.00 new, Cambridge English Pronouncing Dictionary (papberback) $22.00

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Using exercises, outside assignments, observation of life, and improvisation you will be introduced to basic principles of acting. You will learn the fundamentals of creating character and a simple method to turn the written word into action. Finally, you will apply these principles toward scene work using simple "content-less" scenes and a scene from a play.

Although there are written components to the course, the essence of the class is in the DOING. You must come ready to risk, to play, to work, and to question. You must also spend significant time outside of the class working with scene partners.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Register through CAESAR

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
In this course you will learn how:

To INCREASE ATTENTION to human behavior and the world around you
To LISTEN and RESPOND spontaneously
To recognize how CIRCUMSTANCES influence your actions
To identify GOALS that will form the basis for clear ACTION
To apply the above skills to the analysis of dramatic literature and to the creation of CHARACTER

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Character improvisation, paired scene work

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentation of Scene Work

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Script $10 | Show tickets approx $20 | Printing $2

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: If you are an athlete whose sport is in season, please check your game schedule carefully before enrolling, as there is an attendance policy in this class.
