descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: GIS Level 1: This course offers an introduction to concepts underlying geographic information systems (GIS) and methods of managing and processing geographic information. The course is designed for students who have little background but want to learn the fundamentals and applications of GIS. Students will be exposed to both theoretical knowledge and technical skills in this course. Lab assignments and course project will promote students' application of concepts and skills in solving real-world problems.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: There are no prerequisites required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will recognize the fundamentals of geographic information systems.
Students will demonstrate the concepts and applications of geospatial technologies.
Students will apply basic skills of geospatial data processing using ArcGIS software.
Students will analyze and interpret geospatial data using maps for visualization and presentation.
Students will design project proposals using GIS concepts and techniques based on real-world problems.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: In the lectures, both theoretical and practical GIS processing and application cases will be introduced. The conceptual elements of several topics will be discussed including map projection, data models, spatial analysis of vector and raster data, GIS networks, cartography, etc. The labs are designed for students to obtain hands-on experience of ArcGIS software in data input, data management, data analyses, and result presentation in a geographical information system with specific instructions. Students are welcome to ask questions in and out of class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The course evaluates students' performance by three components. They are lab tasks, assignments, and project. Lab tasks are based on completion of lab exercises in each week. Assignments will be given to test technical aspects using software. Student will work on a project based on a real-world problem and complete it by the end of class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Online access will be provided to the following resource:
Krygier, J., & Wood, D. (2011). Making maps: a visual guide to map design for GIS. Guilford Publications. ISBN: 9781609181666
Purchasing this book is optional.

A portable USB flash drive will be useful to save your lab work from the laboratory computers.
ArcGIS Desktop software is suggested to be installed in personal computers to conduct lab assignments if necessary. Northwestern University provides ArcGIS software with license for students.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course offers digital representation and analysis of geospatial phenomena and provides foundations in methods and algorithms used in GIS analysis. The course is designed for students who want to get a comprehensive understanding of GIS and advanced spatial analyses. Each week we will focus on a specific topic and practice the skills in a mini-project. Course project will apply these skills in solving real-world problems based on students' interest of topics.

This course requires knowledge of GIS principles at an introductory level. Students are required to have taken ENVR_SCI 390 GIS Level 1, EARTH 390 GIS level 1, PBC 470 GIS level 1, or GEOG 343, or equivalent. The department will verify that this requirement has been met.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Required: Knowledge of GIS principles at introductory level. Students are required to have taken ENVR_SCI 390 GIS Level 1, EARTH 390 GIS level 1, PBC 470 GIS level 1, or GEOG 343, or equivalent. The department will verify that this requirement has been met.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will build maps effectively in conveying information and sharing with non-GIS users.
Students will become proficient in the use of GIS tools to conduct spatial analyses.
Students will know how to undertake new analyses using GIS and troubleshooting problems in GIS.
Students will use GIS analyses to address applied problems and/or research questions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: In the lectures, both theoretical and practical GIS processing and application cases will be introduced. The labs are designed for students to obtain hands-on experience of ArcGIS software with advanced geospatial analysis skills by applying into a mini-project in each week. Guidance of course project will be provided. Students are welcome to ask questions in and out of class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The course evaluates students' performance by four components. They are quizzes, lab tasks, assignments, and group project. Nine lecture quizzes will be given throughout the course to test conceptual knowledge. Lab tasks are based on completion of lab exercises in each week. Eight assignments will be given to test technical aspects using software. Student will collaborate with group members to develop a course project and present the contents in the class.

descriptions.value: Smith, Goodchild, and Longley: Geospatial Analysis (free online access)

descriptions.name: Class Notes

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Plant-Animal Interactions: This course will explore the diversity of interactions between plants and animals, including antagonistic interactions (e.g., herbigory), mutualistic interactions (e.g., pollination, seed dispersal and ant-plant associations), and interactions involving multiple species and across trophic levels.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students should be comfortable reading papers from the scientific literature. Students should be familiar with basic biological and ecological concepts.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Contributions to class discussion, exams, projects, and presentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: We will be reading many papers from the primary scientific literature. All reading materials will be posted on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: French 111-3 is the third quarter of Elementary French. Class meets four days a week. The aim of the course is to build skills in speaking, listening, writing and reading French through study, practice, and class activities.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 111-2 or department placement. No PN allowed. Attendance at first class is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Classes will include a variety of activities designed to help students acquire a knowledge of basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. Classes will be conducted in French except when explanation of grammar or other material may necessitate the use of English. Students are expected to prepare outside of class, to participate actively in class activities, and to work independently with the En Avant! listening program and Internet activities.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Final grades are based on class performance and attendance, homework and compositions, quizzes, 3 tests, and a final oral exam.

descriptions.value:

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: French 111-3 is the third quarter of Elementary French. Class meets four days a week. The aim of the course is to build skills in speaking, listening, writing and reading French through study, practice, and class activities.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 111-2 or department placement. No PN allowed. Attendance at first class is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Classes will include a variety of activities designed to help students acquire a knowledge of basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. descriptions.value: French 121-1 is the third quarter of a three-quarter course for students who have completed French 111-3 or have been placed in that course by the French department. The aim of the course is to develop students' communication skills and cultural knowledge. Class meets four times a week. No P/N allowed.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.value:
French 125-1 is the first quarter of a three-quarter course for students who have completed French 115-2.
The primary goal of this course is to strengthen oral and written communication skills by immersing students in authentic cultural contexts and language. A review of essential grammar will reinforce linguistic foundations. Class meets three times a week and will be conducted in French.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Through study, exercises, conversation and various class activities, students will review and practice basic grammar, while exploring contemporary French and Francophone cultures. Students are expected to attend class daily, to actively participate and to spend at least 2 hours of work outside of class for each contact hour. P/N not allowed.

descriptions.value: Class participation, homework & quizzes, three compositions, four chapter tests and end-of-quarter oral test.

name: Writing Workshop: Cultural Encounters in Contemporary France

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to develop and improve writing skills through a variety of classroom activities: discussion, writing, editing. Students will learn how to write a college-level analytical paper. Selected grammar points will be discussed in class, and course content will be provided by a novel and two films. Homework will include short writing exercises and compositions as well as the preparation of grammar exercises related to the writing objectives. This course serves as prerequisite for most other 200 and 300-level French classes.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 201, 203, or placement by the department.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: It is expected by the end of term that students will be able to: * Write up to 3 pages of French with ease, a certain degree of personal style, and few errors, * Produce a well-organized and well-conceived paper on a personal, literary or cultural topic, * Proofread their own work for the most basic errors made by Anglophones writing French

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: A collaborative workshop, with written and oral activities organized around communicative strategies.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on class participation, homework, compositions, quizzes and progress.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to build fluency in speaking and understanding French. Classes will concentrate on increasing listening comprehension through viewing of videos and films, building vocabulary and idiom use, and enhancing oral communication skills. One group project based on a play.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: French 125-3, French 201-0, or placement by the department.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Spoken activities in class organized around the communicative strategies needed to carry on a meaningful conversation. Students are expected to prepare at home for each class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: French 204, Acting French, brings French language and culture to life through drama and performance. Focusing on everyday language and situations, students will write and act in groups in order to enhance their proficiency and fine tune their understanding of the lexical and grammatical nuances of French language. Students will read and analyze contemporary French plays. Communicative activities and acting exercises will develop students' interpretive and interpersonal communication skill (listening, reading and speaking skills) while enhancing their intercultural competence.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
- Le dieu du carnage. Yasmina Reza.
ISBN-13: 978-2210755642
- Le Prénom. Mathieu Delaporte and Alexandre de la Patellière. ISBN : 978-2-7498-1223-6

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introduction to French culture through study and analysis of major themes, issues, and debates that characterize or preoccupy contemporary French thought and society, this course helps students understand French society and culture in today's world. We explore the challenges posed to the traditional republican notion of French national identity by colonial history, decolonization, immigration, and globalization by studying a wide range of documents, texts, and films that portray individual and collective experiences. Drawing on the notion of "la France en mutation / changing France," we study how historical events and French institutions (especially the state and the school) shape identities. Students gain an understanding of questions relating to social inequalities and diversities from a "French Global" perspective, while focusing on French definitions and experiences of (in)equality and diversity, and how these play out in terms of race and ethnicity, gender, class, and sexual orientation. Conducted entirely in French, this course is designed to increase students' ability to speak, read, and write in French, and improve their aural comprehension. Students also learn techniques of close reading and detailed critical analysis through class discussion and presentations, the creative/reflective assignment, the analytical essay, and the practice of annotation. This course is part of the pilot program for the proposed Social Inequalities and Diversities requirement in WCAS.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 202, AP score of 5, or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class discussion, oral reports, short lectures. Conducted entirely in French.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class offers a survey of lyric poetry in French from the Middle Ages to the twentieth century, placing special emphasis on the identification of genres, styles and poetic techniques in order to facilitate close-reading and analysis. Poetic movements studied include the medieval troubadours, the Pléiade, symbolism, modernism, surrealism, avant-garde poetry, négritude and francophonie. Readings, writing assignments, and class-discussions in French.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: French 210-0 or French 211-0, AP score of 5 in literature, or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Identification and analysis of poetic genres and forms

name: Advanced Writing: Finding Your Voice in French

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Perfect your written expression in French and learn to write in a variety of genres such as portrait, summary, review of film or performance, explication de texte, correspondence, interview, editorial, documentary research and creative writing. Practice is organized according to language functions (describing, summarizing, persuading, hypothesizing, etc.) and communicative needs. You will review vocabulary and grammar as needed and develop awareness of appropriate styles of writing, learning their characteristics by reading authentic material.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 202, French 301 or permission of the instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Through the regular practice of different types of writing coupled with watchful reading and review of grammatical concepts, you will acquire a much greater ease in writing, a greater accuracy and will develop a more French way of expressing yourself.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Careful guided observation of French texts will be used in order to help you develop a good sense of how to write in a French style for a variety of purposes.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Final grades will be based on weekly written assignments, the portfolio, attendance and participation.

descriptions.value: Guide du cours (Quartet Copies), Denise Rochat, Contrastes, grammaire du français courant (2nd. ed.), available at Norris, Micro Robert de poche (or a good French-French dictionary), available at Norris, Harper-Collins-Robert (or another large (over 250,000 words) French-English, English-French dictionary), available at Norris ($55 New/$41.25 Used)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is the development of oral proficiency through speech functions, conversational routines and patterns, so as to build confidence in the practice of the French language. In order to achieve this goal, emphasis will be put on extensive examination of French press and French television news, French movies, the reading of a book related to the author studied this quarter, and spontaneous expression through dialogues and discussion, and even debates. Special emphasis will be placed on group work and culturally appropriate usage. The students will participate actively in the choice of the materials.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: French 202, French 203 or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Audio-visual and spoken dialogic based on homework and lab preparations. Students will be expected to keep a "journal" with various exercises, articles, summaries, and their reactions to the class material.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on oral individual presentations and also on a group basis. There will be occasional quizzes to test the progress of the students. Preparation and participation will also be important parts of the final evaluation. Therefore regular attendance is essential. Two tests will test the oral comprehension of the students. Final exam based on group presentation and final individual interview.

2. Students will be asked to provide copies to the class for the ateliers (1-2 times during the quarter)
3. Good dictionaries are recommended: Harper-Collins-Robert French/English /English/French Dictionary, and French/French Dictionary (Micro-Robert)

name: French For Professions
topic: Introduction to Fundamentals of the French Busines

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Focused on seeking employment in a French-speaking environment, this course is designed to familiarize students with the business culture in France and in the Francophone world. The essential components of the course include acquiring knowledge of the economic sector, business structures and practices, business communication skills, as well as cultural competency.
In a student-centered classroom, students will practice their writing and speaking skills by way of reality-based and task-specific communicative activities. They will, for example, write a CV and a cover letter, conduct a job interview, respond to business clients, create and present a company. Upon completion of the course, students will have created a personalized and comprehensive portfolio of a French company that they can use as a model when entering the job market.

descriptions.value: Completion of French 302 or consent of instructor

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

name: Medieval French Narratives
topic: Defining Difference in Old French Narratives

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Defining Difference in Old French Narratives :
The Middle Ages are often perceived as a period of rigid and narrow attitudes, when dominant cultural institutions displayed little tolerance for diversity and difference regarding fundamental social categories such as gender, sexuality, race and religion. While this is true in many respects, the literature produced in Old French during the twelfth and thirteenth centuries also displays a persistent interest in questioning the nature of the human and the place of the individual in society. This course examines texts such as the Lais of Marie de France, the Roman de Floire et Blanchefleure, Aucassin et Nicolette and the Roman de Silence, which investigate the boundaries that separate humans from animals, Christians from Muslims, men from women, in each case providing surprisingly transgressive commentaries that not only challenge medieval norms and orthodoxies, but modern ones as well. Readings, written assignments, and class-discussions in French.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Robert d'Orbigny, Le Conte de Floire et Blanchefleure
Champion Classiques, 2003.

Aucassin et Nicolette,
Folio Classique, 1999.

Marie de France, Lais de Marie de France.
Le Livre de Poche; Édition : Le Livre de Poche, 1990.
M- « La damoisele qui ne pooit oïr parler de foutre » (pp. 89-106)

W- « Berangier au lonc Cul » (pp. 241-262)

F- « Le Sohait des Vez » (pp. 137-144) ; « Li Prestre qui abevete
Silence: A Thirteenth-Century Romance
Sarah Roche-Mahdi
Michigan State University Press, 1992.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Renouncing love in 17th-century literature: affects, gender and desire on the threshold of modernity:

Love is a pervasive theme in 17th-century literature, notably in the most fashionable literary genres at the?time: comedy, tragedy and the novel. The course focuses on the act of renouncing love in the writings of prominent 17th-century French authors such as Molière, Corneille, Racine, La Fayette, La Rochefoucauld and Pascal, and highlights how classical French literature contributed to redefining gender relationships and shaping new erotic and affective subjectivities on the threshold of modernity.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: French 271, 272 or 273 or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Short lectures, discussions in class, close readings

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Mme de La Fayette, La Princesse de Clèves, Paris, Garnier Flammarion, 2009 ; Jean Racine, Bérénice, Paris, Gallimard, Folio, classique, 2015 ; Corneille, Le Cid, Gallimard, Folio Classique, 1999 ; Molière, Les Précieuses Ridicules, Paris, Gallimard, Folio Théatre, 1998 ; La Rochefoucauld, Maximes et Réflexions Diverses, Paris, Garnier Flammarion, 1999.

name: Studies in the 17Th Century
topic: Gallantry, preciousness, libertinage: gender and d

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Gallantry, preciousness, libertinage: gender and desire in France in the Classical Age :

The course reads plays and novels written in the 17th and 18th centuries from the viewpoint of the history and theory of gender and sexuality, with a focus on social constructionism. Three endogenous categories will be at the center of our attention: gallantry, preciousness and libertinage.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Mme de La Fayette, La Princesse de Clèves, GF, 2009.
Guilleragues, Les Lettres Portuguaises, .
Bussy-Rabutin, Histoire amoureuse des Gaules, Folio, 1993.
Sade, La Philosophie dans le Boudoir, Folio, 2005
Choderlos de Laclos, Les Liaisons dangereuses, Folio, 1973
Crébillon, Le Sopha, GF, 1997.
Vivant Denon, Point de lendemain, GF, 2018.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Politics of Seduction:

In the era of #MeToo and #TimesUp, what is left of seduction? As its etymological derivation from the Latin seducere makes evident, seduction signifies the threat of being led astray, suggesting a problematic reorganization of boundaries, activity and passivity, power and weakness. To what extent does seduction affirm an unequal gender logic? Does seduction always imply violence? This seminar aims to confront these questions by revisiting primal scenes of seduction in a variety of literary, psychoanalytical, and philosophical texts. We will start by considering one of the central mythical figures of modernity, Don Juan, in Molière and Da Ponte's retellings of the story, where seduction takes the form of a gendered performance. Paying particular attention to the theoretical interventions of Shoshana Felman and Judith Butler, we will explore the imaginative links between gender, performance, and seduction.

Our reading of Choderlos de Laclos's Dangerous Liaisons will revolve around the question of how the narrative may be said to complicate or even reverse earlier cultural assumptions about gender and seduction. We then will investigate "The Diary of a Seducer" in Kierkegaard's Either/Or, which interprets seduction as the lynchpin between the aesthetic and the ethical, pleasure and the law. Finally, we will reflect in what ways the very history of psychoanalysis has been marked by the discovery of seduction?of a child by an adult?thus establishing a connection to trauma that Freud initially acknowledged and then denied. Through readings of essays by Freud, Ferenczi, Laplanche, and Masson, we will discuss how psychoanalysis has responded to the scandal of seduction by problematizing ethical, and normative solutions to the drama of dissymmetry and otherness and has regarded seduction as foundational in the development of the human subject.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Taught seminar style. Professor Isabelle Alfandary (Sorbonne Nouvelle, Collège Internationale de Philosophie) will co-teach with Professor Ricciardi the part of the course dedicated to psychoanalysis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation in class discussion (10%), 2 short papers-3 pages each- (20%), one oral presentation of 20 minutes (20%), and a final paper of 15 pages (50%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Works by Molière, Laclos, Mueller, Kierkegaard, Freud, Ferenczi, Laplanche, Masson, Felman, and Butler.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course offers an introduction to what was arguably the most long-lasting and widespread avant-garde movement of the twentieth century: surrealism. In addition to reading several of the most important figures of Parisian surrealism (Breton, Aragon, Artaud, Bataille), we will explore a variety of affiliated non-European movements in Latin America (particularly Mexico) and Japan, as well the Cairo-based Art and Liberty group and international négritude (in Martinique, Senegal, and Angola).

Our focus will be on manifestos and literary works, but we will also study their close relationship to the visual arts. Students will have the opportunity to develop a research project relevant to their field and/or national area of interest. In addition to our regular seminars, we will also have small-group meetings with several of the scholars whose work we will be reading.

name: Topics in Literary Theory
topic: On the Life of Images in the Digital Age

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
On the Life of Images in the Digital Age:

The aim of this course is to introduce graduate students to 20th- and 21st-century theories of visual culture, sound, and media, with special emphasis on the French and German contexts. Rather than attempting a survey, we will work around specific topics?labor, war, surveillance, migration?and trace the ways in which they have been explored by theorists and practitioners alike. We will focus on the relation between art and technology and the shift from analog to digital media as it affects the life of images at the level of both inscription and reception. While considering different kinds of media, we will read texts by Giorgio Agamben, Walter Benjamin, Jacques Derrida, Bernard Stiegler, and Byung-Chul Han, among others. We will also analyze films by Martin Arnold, Guy Debord, Walid Raad, Hito Steyerl, and Harun Farocki.

name: Modernism and the Avant-garde: History and Theory

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course offers an introduction to the literature of what was arguably the most long-lasting and widespread avant-garde movement of the twentieth century: surrealism. Although generally thought of as a Parisian movement whose influence radiated outward, both the origins and the travels of the movement as overdetermined as they were variegated. In addition to being historically important, then, the movement also provides a kind of test case for the global circulation of literary, artistic, and political ideas.

About the first third of the course will focus on the surrealism in Paris, from the 1924 manifesto through its early literary production, into the emergence of various "dissident" surrealisms as the group became increasingly politicized and fragmented in the 1930s. Our emphasis will be on what one critic has called "ethnographic surrealism": the movement's strong interest in non-Western art and culture, but also its auto-ethnography of French modernity.

The latter two-thirds of the course will explore a variety of non-European movements affiliated with surrealism: in Latin America (particularly Mexico), international négritude (Martinique, Senegal, and Lusophone Africa); the Cairo-based Art and Liberty group, and surrealism in Japan.

Authors will include Louis Aragon, Antonin Artaud, Walter Benjamin, André Breton, Alejo Carpentier, Leopold Senghor, Suzanne Césaire, Kitasono Katue Michel Leiris, Takiguchi Shuzo, and Ramses Younan.

Our focus will be on manifestos and literary works, but we will also study the close relationship of these writings to the visual arts and we will plan a group trip to the Art Institute of Chicago.

André Breton. Manifestoes of Surrealism. University of Michigan [0472061828]
André Breton. Manifestes du surrealism. Gallimard/folio [0801858305]

Louis Aragon. Paris Peasant. Exact Change [1878972103]
Louis Aragon. Le Paysan de Paris. Gallimard [2070367827]

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Global Avant-Garde and Modernist Studies Colloquium

The GAMS Colloquium is an interdepartmental, student-driven reading and discussion group focused on current scholarship and debates in avant-garde and modernist studies, with an emphasis on their transnational dimensions. The course will be run as a working group and is intended to foster an environment for intellectual exchange. The GAMS Colloquium is required of all GAMS cluster students, however students not affiliated with the cluster may also take the course.

Readings will in part be determined by the interests of students in the course, following the first meeting. In addition to our regular seminar-style meetings, we will have several visiting guest instructors from outside Northwestern, whose work we will read in advance: Sarah Townsend (Penn State) on theaters of the Latin American avant-garde; Elizabeth Harney (University of Toronto) on the art in postcolonial Senegal; and Lanie Millar (Oregon) on negritude in Angola and the Lusophone world. We will also make at least one visit to a local art museum.

Evaluation will be based not on a long research paper, but on a number of short writing assignments, active participation in seminars discussions, and several in-class presentations. Students with questions about the colloquium should feel free to contact the professor in advance: c-bush@northwestern.edu.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide and examines past and current efforts to address them. Taking an interdisciplinary approach, the course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices and forms of knowledge production characteristic of what we call "global health" today, and explores the environmental, social, political and economic factors that shape patterns and experiences of illness and healthcare across societies. We will scrutinize the value systems that underpin specific paradigms in the policy and science of global health and place present-day developments in historical perspective.

descriptions.value: Pre-registration for Global Health Studies Adjunct Majors and Minors only. Registration open to other students after pre-registration.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Global health is a popular field of work and study for Americans, with an increasing number of medical trainees and practitioners, as well as people without medical training, going abroad to volunteer in areas where there are few health care practitioners or resources. In addition, college undergraduates, as well as medical trainees and practitioners, are going abroad in increasing numbers to conduct research in areas with few health care resources. But all of these endeavors, though often entered into with the best of intentions, are beset with ethical questions, concerns, and dilemmas, and can have unintended consequences. In this course, students will assess these ethical challenges. In so doing, students will examine core ethical codes, guidelines, and principals - such as solidarity, social justice, and humility - so they will be able to ethically assess global health practices in a way that places an emphasis on the core goal of global health: reducing health inequities and disparities.

name: Qualitative Research Methods in Global Health

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to provide global health students with the tools they will need in order to design, revise, conduct, and write up current and future qualitative research projects relating to global health topics. This course is experientially driven, allowing students opportunities to actually "do" research, while providing careful mentoring and engaging in in-depth discussions about ethical and methodological issues associated with qualitative approaches and with working with living humans. Students will learn methods such as: writing research proposals, research ethics, writing ethnographic field notes, doing qualitative interviews and focus groups, analyzing and writing up data.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Oftentimes we hear of research done on communities. Community-based participatory research (CBPR) is a research paradigm that challenge researchers to conducted research with communities. In this reading intense discussion-based course, we will learn the historical and theoretical foundations, and the key principles of CBPR. Students will be introduced to methodological approaches to building community partnerships, research planning, and data sharing. Real-world applications of CBPR in health will be studied to illustrate the benefits and challenges. Further, this course will address culturally appropriate interventions, working with diverse communities, and ethical considerations in CBPR.

name: Special Topics in Global Health
topic: Native Nations, Healthcare Systems, and U.S. Polic

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Healthcare for Native populations, in the what is currently the U.S., are an entanglement of settler colonial domination and the active determination of Native nations to uphold their Indigenous sovereignty. This reading-intensive, discussion-based seminar will provide students with a complex and in-depth understanding of the historical and contemporary policies and systems created for and by Native nations. We will focus on the legal foundations of the trust responsibility and fiduciary obligation of the federal government outlined in the U.S. Constitution and Supreme Court decisions. To gain a nuanced perspective, students will study notable federal policies including the Snyder Act, the Special Diabetes Programs for Indians, Violence Against Women Act, and Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA). Additionally, state policy topics will include Medicaid expansion and tobacco cessation and prevention.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No freshmen. This course is open for pre-registration to Global Health Studies majors and minors only. The course will open to all other students during regular registration.

descriptions.value: All course materials will be available through Canvas

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: No freshmen. This course is open for pre-registration to Global Health Studies majors and minors only. The course will open to all other students during regular registration.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The first objective of this course is to introduce students to the many ways that water impacts our world. We will discuss what the international recommendations for safely managed water are and the health and social consequences of water insecurity. The second objective is explore why there is such variety in water insecurity worldwide. These discussions will be guided by the socio-ecological framework, in which dimensions ranging from the individual to the geopolitical are considered. Influences on access to water will be broadly considered; we will draw on literature in global health, ethnography, the life sciences, and public policy. The third objective is to develop critical thinking and writing abilities to reflect on the multi-dimensional causes and consequences of water insecurity and the appropriateness of potential solutions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No freshmen. This course will be open to Global Health Studies majors and minors for pre-registration. All other students may register during regular registration.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1. Understand and articulately discuss the social and health impacts of water insecurity.
2. Identify and critically analyze key actors, institutions, and policies that influence water insecurity.
3. Recognize, critically assess, and communicate the value of qualitative and quantitative data for understanding causes and consequences of water insecurity.
4. Evaluate interventions to achieve safely managed water from anthropological and public health perspectives.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course will be oriented around the socio-ecological conceptual framework(s). We will begin with an introduction to the ecological framework and the basics of water and sanitation, including the consequences of water of inappropriate quantities and quality. For the rest of the course, we will will focus on the multiple determinants of water security through a combination of lectures, case studies, movies, and possibly a field trip. Simultaneously, you will be applying this knowledge to real-life case studies of water insecurity to identify optimal solutions to these challenges by incorporating perspectives of different stakeholders.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Most readings will be available through Canvas; Drinking Water: A History by James Salzman (978-1468307115)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: No freshmen. This course will be open to Global Health Studies majors and minors for pre-registration. All other students may register during regular registration.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to ideas and concepts of health care and social protection during socialism and post-socialism in Eastern and Southeastern Europe. The course will explore systems based on the principle of "health for all" and their transformation during the so-called post-socialist transition from state-planned to market-oriented economies. Taking an interdisciplinary approach, we will examine the complex relationship between socialist heritage and the influence of neoliberal policies on health care systems in former socialist states, with a special emphasis on the former Yugoslavia. Key course topics include: socialist governance and health care policy; the politics of post-socialist "transition;" the neoliberalization of health care and social protection policies; patients and their rights in the new order; informal economies and clientelism; and challenges in access to healthcare for marginalized social groups. Throughout the course, students will be encouraged to think critically about the political-economic, ethical, and cultural complexities of health care under socialism and the neoliberal transition.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No freshmen. Pre-registration will be open to Global Health Studies majors and minors only. The course will open to all other students during regular registration.

name: Residence-Linked Seminar - III (Social & Behavioral Sciences)
topic: Discovering a Foreign language: an introduction to

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The main purpose of this course is to offer the students the possibility to compare the system and some sociocultural uses of the languages they speak or know with the languages that their peers speak or know. Students will teach and learn from each other and share their discoveries on certain linguistic and pragmatic aspects of their languages. They will have an idea of a different language system as they deepen the knowledge of a language system that they already know. We will cover linguistic patterns of sounds (the alphabet: pronunciation of consonants and vowels) and grammar (gender, plural forms, word order); meaning in idiomatic expressions; and pragmatic patterns in language functions such as greeting, requesting, accepting, or rejecting. This course will analyze some language functions in society. How one language user greets or requests a favor, or how he or she responds to an invitation is intrinsically related to the social behavior of the speaker. As we compare different languages, we will explore ways of using these languages according to social interaction and meaning.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• Identify and compare patterns of sounds in the alphabet (consonants and vowels) in their own language and the equivalent patterns of sounds in a new language

  • Identify and compare grammatical patterns related to gender, plural and word order in their own language and the equivalent grammatical patterns in a new language

  • Describe and interpret the meaning of specific idiomatic expressions (food related) in their own language and equivalent idiomatic expressions in a new language

  • Interpret and compare the usage of certain language communicative functions (such as greeting and requesting) in their own language and the equivalent language communicative functions in a new language

  • Understand the usage of some linguist rites in their own language and compare them with equivalent rites in a new language

  • Draw some conclusions on language use and social perceptions

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, class discussions and presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
• Homework and Class participation: 20%. This course will be based primarily on discussion, and all students are expected to be prepared for it, by reading from book chapters, selected articles, and other online materials. Students should be very active in class, engaged in discussions.

  • 4 group presentations: 40%. There will be 4 group presentations (10% each). Students, with their pairs, will present their discoveries about the topics on the languages they are comparing. 1) Sounds of the language; 2) Grammatical patterns on gender, plural and word order; 3) Idiomatic Expressions; 4) Some Language Communicative Functions

  • 2 Written Exams: 40% Midterm and Final (20% each). There will be 2 written exams where the students will demonstrate their knowledge and perceptions about the languages they are comparing. They will also give their own insights and perspectives about other languages presented in class.

name: Residence-Linked Seminar - VI (Literature and Fine Arts)
topic: From Hamilton to 'Hamilton': Race, Gender, and Gen

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Taking the hit musical Hamilton as its launching point, the course will examine a broad set of contemporary and historical examples of adaptation in popular culture, with a focus on meaningful shifts in race, gender, and genre across original and adapted versions of a given story or work.

In 2009, Lin Manuel Miranda performed what would become the opening number of Hamilton at Barack and Michelle Obama's Whitehouse Poetry Slam. At the outset, he told the audience that U.S. founding father Alexander Hamilton embodied the spirit of hip-hop?everyone laughed. But by the end of Miranda's performance, they stood and cheered.

Why did they initially laugh? What changed their minds? What made the musical an instant national sensation when it premiered in the summer of 2015, on the cusp of Obama's final presidential term? And how has its social meaning changed since the November 2016 election?

These are the types of questions we'll ask in this course. As we encounter a variety of cultural forms?stage performance, music, literature, film, and more?we'll also tackle broader questions such as: Why do we conventionally associate certain artistic genres with certain social groups? How are these conventions maintained, manipulated, and/or challenged through practices of adaptation and appropriation? How can creative expression communicate different social meanings depending on the generic tropes it draws on, on who is producing it, on who is reading, listening to, or viewing it, on social context, on historical significance, and on a number of other variables?

Throughout the course, students will develop skills in cultural analysis, exploring theoretical frameworks via examples of popular adaptation that we discuss in seminar. Students will also develop descriptive and analytical writing skills as they make observations and draw conclusions about cultural texts and performances. The course will culminate in an essay-length paper that considers the cultural, social, and/or political significance of one or more instances of adaptation in popular culture.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students should be able to show they can:

  • Students will gain a basic theoretical vocabulary for discussing the formation and performance of social categories.

  • Students will learn to identify and articulate how norms of race, gender, and genre are performed, shaped, exploited, and contested through popular adaptation.

  • Students will learn to apply close reading skills to diverse media forms.

  • Students will gain descriptive and analytical writing skills.

  • Students will gain research skills such as developing a question, performing content analysis, and marshaling secondary and primary evidence toward a claim.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class format lecture/discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
• Class participation (15%): Students will be expected to come to class with ideas and questions about the reading & viewing materials; they will also frequently be asked to come with examples from popular culture that demonstrate themes in the reading.

  • One vocabulary quiz (5%): Students will take a quiz on basic theoretical vocabulary (i.e. "appropriation," "ideology," "performativity," etc.)

  • Research topic & questions (5%): Students will identify their research materials for the final essay and pose three substantive questions about these materials.

  • Short essay 1, internal analysis (4-6pp, 20%): Working toward the final essay, students will offer a detailed description and close reading of their research material, advancing a preliminary argument or interpretation based on evidence and patterns they observe.

  • Short essay 2, contextual analysis (4-6pp, 20%): Likewise working toward the final essay, students will determine and critically examine the contextual backdrop(s) that will help them explore their initial research questions; in other words, contexts that will help them and their reader make sense of their research material in a specific way: key historic events or figures, biographical information, literary/musical/dramatic/film/etc. traditions or conventions, key audience characteristics or ideologies, reception histories, other adaptations or appropriations of the same source, etc. As with the internal analysis, this paper should make an argument, even if it is not the same argument eventually made in the final paper.

  • Project presentation (10%): Students will each present on their research material.

  • Final essay (8¬-10pp, 25%): Students will complete a polished analysis of their research material. The essay should advance a clear interpretive argument, integrating the internal and contextual analyses through a critical perspective.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: There is no course offered like at all like this at NU. Contemporary singing style is coveted and far reaching. But most students have been taught to sing (if at all) in a choral, classical model. This class will make everyone involved better singers regardless of aptitude. But it will also reveal and experiment with the de-mystification of singing popular music in both technique and style. To survive and excel in today's performance industry, actors need to be increasingly multifaceted. Singing is becoming a necessary skill set, not only for those actors interested in Musical Theatre, but for those actors who do not consider themselves able to carry a tune. Integrative theatre such as Goodman's A Christmas Carol, Mary Zimmerman's A Jungle Book, Once, The History Boys, etc. all require singing of their actors. However, singing is often times intimidating to those who haven't been raised with formal training. Non-actors find themselves in situations where singing is inescapable as well. The onslaught of singing-driven reality TV (American Idol, The X Factor, The Sing off, The Voice) has revived the Karaoke sensation. Musicians in pits and orchestras are finding voice to be an integral part of new compositions. Due to budget cuts and the movement of Arts Integration, elementary school educators are incorporating music into the general classroom curriculum, and the singing voice will necessarily become the instrument of choice, since every child has one, and instruments remain expensive to purchase. For the painters, sculpters, and arts aficionados, well "Happy Birthday" is sung around dinner tables on a regular basis, and children will always want a lullaby sung to them at bedtime. There are ways to feel comfortable, confident, and competent while singing without years of training. This course will REVIEW and SOLIDIFY singing fundamentals, vocal health, and then delve into contemporary singing styles.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• Posture for Singing

  • Breathing for Singing

  • Resonance for Singing

  • All above specifying Pop registration and stylings (Vocal Fry Breathy Onset), Rock (lower register, false vocal fold growl) R&B (riffing, Tongue positioning) Country (Twang, Cry) Singer Songwriter Folk (Yodel Flip, Straight Tone, Blowing register, Diction)

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, Group Singing Participation, One on One Evaluations, discussion, performance and analysis of outside performance. Writing Several journal entries, song preparations, Cumulative notebook (consisting of class hand outs, journal entries, repertoire book and practice exercises, and 1 paper, 2-3 pages in length.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the geography of the United States and Canada, beginning with Newfoundland and Atlantic Canada in the first week and finishing with the Pacific Coast and Hawaii in the ninth week. The course material is grouped by regions which offers a comprehensive way of understanding geographical differences from place to place. The natural environment, settlement history, cultural patterns, and economic development are studied in each of the regions as we move from east to west. The course is designed to give a general knowledge of the two countries' geography and to improve one's "mental map" of where things are and why they are there.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Midterm and final. Exams are multiple choice and short answer format

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: John C. Hudson, Across This Land: A Regional Geography of the United States and Canada, 2nd ed. Johns Hopkins University Press, 2020. ISBN 13: 978-1-4214-3758-3

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Principles of Cartography covers basic concepts of cartography and their use in map making. Coordinate systems, land survey systems, spherical distance computation, and other measurement concepts are developed in the first part of the course. Roughly half the course is devoted to map projections: their history, development, application, and current availability in digital format. Students choose a particular projection and do a short research project on its history and application. Other assignments include in-class exercises and homework assignments. Math through trigonometric functions is mandatory background. Reading materials will be handed out in class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Math 224-0 and junior or senior standing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Much of the class is involved in "how to do it" instruction. Class attendance is expected.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be two exams, one short paper, and weekly assignments. The first exam deals with coordinate systems and distance computation; the second covers map projections; these will be scheduled following completion of the relevant topics. Assignments, approximately one per week, will involve computation, use of data, some drawing, and interpretation of maps.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the third quarter of a three-quarter sequence of Intermediate German. Students will continue to increase their proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing German. We will read and work with Ferdinand von Schirach's story "Notwehr" (Self-Defense) from his book Das Verbrechen (Foul Play). We will also watch the film adaptation by Oliver Berben (2013).
To conclude the year we will again turn our attention to the recent developments in Germany.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the Nazi Olympics, held in Berlin 1936, in relation to religion, race, and politics. We show how the Nazi Olympics appropriated themes from the ancient Olympics in Greece in order to create a new religious, aesthetic, and political ethos. We also look at the legacy of politics in the Olympics of Mexico City in 1968, with a focus on Black activism in contemporary sports.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
"The student will become familiar with the history of the Nazi Olympics (Berlin 1936).
The student will be able to analyze the dimensions of religion, race, and politics in the contemporary Olympics.
The student will learn how to write two short thesis-based papers."

name: Intensive Beginning German through Musical Journeys in Vienna

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course is intended for students from all disciplines who want to develop basic German language skills! The goals of the course include the acquisition of speaking, writing, reading, and listening skills in German, the building of a general vocabulary, and a foundation in grammar. Students in the course will also become acquainted with the rich musical culture of the European metropolis Vienna. Activities will draw on the lives and works of classical as well as contemporary and popular composers, including Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, and Falco. Besides discussing excerpts from musical works such as Die Zauberflöte by Wolfgang Amadeus, Mozart, Die Fledermaus by Johann Strauss, Jr., Lieder by Schubert and selected popular music, we will read short biographies, letters, poetry and prose, study maps and paintings, watch the film Amadeus and videos, and learn about historical events, art, and culture in Vienna and German-speaking Europe!

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to enhance the aural/oral skills by training students in listening comprehension and speaking. The question "What is German?" is a starting point for discussions about identity, beliefs and cultural understanding. America in the German imagination will continue the conversation. Students will work collaboratively in class to draw conclusions via the articles and podcasts that make up the cultural content of the syllabus.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: An intermediate level of speaking and understanding or the completion of German 102-1 is a pre-requisite for this course

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students are challenged to find their voice in German through a variety of target language activities: classroom discussion, small group work, short oral presentations and a final podcast project.

Students can expect to improve their fluency, pronunciation and aural comprehension at the intermediate level.

Students will learn to understand, summarize and critique German newspaper articles, podcasts and short videos. During group work, students will practice expressing and defending opinions, and leading discussions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course you will acquire business-related German language skills and attain a cross-cultural perspective of German and American business practices. The emphasis will be on communicative situations such as oral and written contact with customers, sales dialogues, business travel, and internship applications. This course integrates the study of the German language, cross-cultural awareness, and business-related professional interaction and is designed to prepare you for professional activities in and with German-speaking countries.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: One 200-level course taught in German, or strong performance in German 102, or the instructor's consent

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: You will learn and practice German vocabulary used in business and professional situations. In addition, by increasing both your understanding of German grammar and structure, you will continue to develop your linguistic skills pertaining to everyday life in the business world through contextualized exercises and readings. By the end of the course you are expected to know how to deal with situations such as looking for an internship and working in Germany and how to converse about topics such as product sales, advertising, or marketing. You will also have your business card, resume, and letter of job application prepared in German. In addition, you will gain a knowledge of the current economic situation and important business-related issues in Germany.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will take a look at the life and work of the groundbreaking Viennese psychologist Sigmund Freud from a comparative and interdisciplinary angle. Almost 80 years after his death, Freud's legacy continues to be controversial: some claim that his theories are no longer relevant in the light of new research, whereas others defend his theories and/or expand upon the implications and influence of his ideas, in the realm not only of psychology, medicine, and neuroscience, but also in the fields of sociology, cultural studies, philosophy, literary studies, criminal justice, queer and gender studies, communications, and many more. What is certain, however, is that, one way or another, Freud's theories and ideas have marked the world for all time. This class will read fundamental texts from Freud's body of work in dialogue with texts by Freud's near and distant predecessors and followers, both to situate Freud in his historical and cultural context, and to think through the many different kinds of questions that Freud's work addresses.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- To become familiar with the basics of Freud's theories and body of work
- To understand Freud's work in its historical context and cultural milieu, and to analyze its impact on a variety of fields, disciplines, and aspects of life
- To deepen understanding of interdisciplinary analysis and influence and to think with and across disciplinary boundaries
- To enhance critical thinking and analytic skills in relation to scientific and literary works

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: When the 16th-century Catholic friar, Martin Luther, stood up for his convictions before pope and emperor, the history of the West was changed forever. In this course we will study the powerful impact that Luther had on the West, both its history and aspects of its culture. Themes addressed are: the secularization of the modern West, economics, political theology, philosophy of religion (Kant and Hegel), anti-Semitism, reason and the will, modern subjectivity, the arts. The course aims to show how religion and theology are related to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be able to define basic terms in the study of religion and theology (for example, subjectivity, freedom, experience). Students will become familiar with the basic concepts of Luther's theology that influenced the making of the modern West (for example, biblical interpretation). Students will also be comfortable with the broad intellectual contours of the modern West from the 16th century to today, with exposure to major thinkers in each period: Enlightenment (e.g. Kant), modernity (e.g. Hegel), 20th century (Martin Luther King Jr.).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this class we will try to catch up with what is currently in the center of discussion in German media (this includes print, TV, and social media). One big topic will be politics: The era of Angela Merkel is coming to an end and her would-be successors are already getting in line, and the German party system has been thoroughly transformed by the arrival of a new right-wing party, the so-called Alternative für Deutschland. Other than politics, we will also discuss current developments in culture and media. Last but not least, there will be ample room for students' suggestions as well as for current events which are not yet foreseeable.
The class also aims to give students an overview of the German media landscape in general: Which newspapers and TV channels are suited to fulfill my information needs, and what else can I do to follow current developments in Germany?

Class taught in German

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- get acquainted with the German media landscape and with the topics that are currently in the center of attention
- develop/strengthen the ability to read German-language media articles and to discuss them in class

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Composers, performers, and musical institutions in Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia underwent profound and even traumatic transformations. In this course we will examine the effects of these changes on musical life from the 1920s through the aftermath of World War II. Special topics to be covered include the crackdown by the Soviet government on Sergei Prokofiev and Dmitri Shostakovich in 1936 and again in 1948, the Munich exhibit of "Entartete Musik" (Degenerate Music) in 1938, music in concentration camps, the concept of Internal Exile ("Innere Imigration"), and the controversial careers of figures such as Richard Strauss, Wilhelm Furtwängler, Herbert von Karajan, and Elisabeth Schwarzkopf. In addition to Soviet Russian and Nazi Germany, we will also cast a sidelong glance at other European nations, including fascist Italy.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The principal goal is familiarity with the music of an important historical period in political history.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
EVALUATION is based on attendance (10 pts.), two written assignments (worth 20 pts. each if submitted on time, worth half credit if submitted late but within one week of the due date), a research project culminating in a term paper of 8-10 pp. (worth 30 points if submitted on time, with same penalty as the shorter assignments if late) due for submission on the last day of class and serving in lieu of a Final Examination) on a topic approved by the instructor no later than Week 4 of the quarter, a brief oral report (5 pts.) accompanied by a handout (5 pts.) including the title and bibliography, on the same topic as the research project, and class discussion (10 pts.). Students who submit a concert report of a live musical performance which includes repertoire relevant to the course may earn up to 10 extra credit points, provided that they have secured prior permission of the instructor and agree to follow the guidelines provided for such cases.

Final Exam - Take Home

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Germany is often regarded as being at the forefront of European developments concerning issues such as climate change and recycling, transport and renewable energy sources. This class will trace the scientific, political, philosophical, and aesthetic history of Germany as a ?green nation` from the 18th century until today. What are the roots of the ideology of environmentalism as it is represented in concepts like environment, ecology, or sustainability, which were all invented or popularized by German scientists (von Uexküll, Haeckel, von Carlowitz)?

Ability to write short essays in German.

name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
topic: The Plague ? In and around Literature

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will investigate texts - literary, historical, critical - which respond to the terrifying effects of the plague. Going back to the Old Testament, on the one hand, where the plague is portrayed as divine punishment, and to Greek tragedy and history,, on the other (Sophocles, Thucydides), the ways different cultures confront the threat of decimation and death will be studied in a variety of texts including Boccaccio's Decameron, La Fontaine's Fables,, Defoe's "Journal of the Plague Year," Kleist's unfinished "Tragedy of Robert Guiscard," Poe's "Mask of the Red Death," Artaud's "The Theater and the Plague," and finally Camus' novel, "The Plague".

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The learning objectives include acquiring an awareness of how societies confront mortal threats to both their individual members and to the collective, when the very procedures that constitute social life become instruments by which the danger spreads. Literature emerges as playing a privileged role in the response to the plague, from the story-telling of the Decameron to Artaud's "Theater of Cruelty" and beyond. Through a study of the historical response to the plague, light can be thrown on its more recent manifestations, made possible by the very technologies that also seek to control and eradicate it.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This quarter is the second quarter of the two-quarter sustainability Research Seminar started in the winter 2020. During this quarter, students will create digital stories based on their research topic and the material collected during their trip to Hamburg, Germany. The final shape of the online documentation will be discussed and developed together with the students but it will contain a variety of media, artistic and journalistic forms, and narrative styles including digital material such as for example pictures, video, and audio recordings from native speakers. Students will present their research projects to the German faculty and students in the department sometimes at the end of spring quarter.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn how to document in a web project how Germans approach sustainability in their daily life. Their digital stories will be based on the material they researched in Hamburg. We will discuss methodological approaches in the digital humanity field as well as explore appropriate technological approaches and skills.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"The history of theater is marked by a lacuna. While Aristotle's contributions to the theory of tragedy in his Poetics are widely recognized, the field of comedy is - apart from some passing remarks - missing from this foundational work of aesthetics. Recently Giorgio Agamben defined his philosophy as a process of "Taking Leave of Tragedy," thereby returning to Aristotle's lost origin. The idea of comedy represents a poetic mode of reflection which offers - in Agamben's view - a liberation from concepts of history and politics based on human suffering and guilt. While tragedy leads from a happy beginning to a catastrophic end, comedy reverses this schema and ends with the restoration of happiness.
This class will trace this taking leave from a tragic paradigm in philosophy, ethics, and aesthetics by focusing on the notion of comedy. We will discuss the anti-tragic turn by bringing into conversation the poetological discourse on the relation of tragedy and comedy (from Aristotle to Hegel, Benjamin, and Agamben among others) with close readings of several comedies from the canon of European literature (Aristophanes, Calderon, Kleist, Tieck, Nestroy, Jarry, Hofmannsthal among others). How would a (post)-modern comedy look like, capable of overcoming a purely tragic view of modernity? What is the emancipatory potential of comedic genres like the commedia dell'arte, the farce, or the puppet play diverging from the Aristotelian opposition of tragedy and comedy?"

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
"Knowledge of key terms in aesthetics
Knowledge of the history of poetics"

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
A century ago, in the winter of 1920/21, Walter Benjamin penned his essay "Critique of Violence," which has lost none of its fascination today, despite (or perhaps because of) its apodictic style, its opaque use of metaphor, and its erratic argumentation. During the last 30 years, it has become a common point of reference for an array of disciplines that are concerned with scope, shape, and function of the different forms of violence associated with the modern nation state. In this class, we will carefully examine Benjamin's original text, explore its philosophical and literary context, become familiar with the major positions of the reception of the essay, and discuss its political relevance today.

Reading might include, among others, authors such as Benjamin, Cohen, Kafka, Kant, Landauer, Sorel, Agamben, Derrida, Hamacher, Butler, and Menke.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of the seminar, you should
a) have gained a deep understanding of one of the canonical texts of continental social philosophy and literary theory;
b) have gained an overview of different accounts in critical theory of state violence and legal criticism;
c) be able to identify cases of state inflicted violence and evaluate them using the critical framework acquired in this seminar;
e) have improved your analytical and hermeneutical skills.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class introduces students to a variety of philosophical problems concerning gender and politics. Together, we'll read classic and contemporary texts that examine questions such as: what is gender - and how, if it all, does it relate to or differ from sex? What does it really mean to be a woman or a man - and are these categories we'r e born into or categories that we become or inhabit through living in a particular way under specific conditions? Human history all the way up to the present seems to be rife with asymmetrical relations of power that relegate those marked out as women to a subordinate position - what explains this? What would it mean to over turn this state of affairs - and which strategies are most likely to accomplish this task? And to what extent is it possible to grapple with all of the above questions - questions of gender, sex and sexuality - without also, at the very same time, thinking about how they relate to questions of class and race? Readings will include selections from Simone de Beauvoir, Iris Marion Young, Sandra Bartky, bell hooks, Patricia Hill Collins, Judith Butler, Talia Bettcher, and others.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An exploration of the role that gender plays in the language of and about men and women, focusing on gendered speech as part of social practice in local communities. Topics include identity categories and labels, ?reclaimed epithets' (e.g. bitch and slut), gender vs. sex vs. sexuality, the contested notion of ?political correctness', sexist/misogynist language, and linguistic prescriptivism. GNDR_ST 234/LING 223 satisfies the WCAS Area III Distribution Requirement in Social and Behavioral Sciences.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
To develop a deep understanding of current issues in gender studies from a linguistic perspective, specifically:
? To think critically about gender, sex, and language - and about the relations among them;
? To identify, analyze, and provide a theoretical framework for gender differences in language;
? To explore the role of language in constructing gender in our society; that is, how children and adults learn (and often are explicitly taught) to produce what is considered gender-appropriate language;
? To examine gender stereotypes from a linguistic perspective with an eye to increasing awareness of and sensitivity to gender bias in language;
? To underscore the importance of gender studies within the broader field of linguistics.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is a survey of U.S. women's history from colonial settlement through 1865. It focuses not only women's experiences and activities in the past but also on how constructions of gender have been critical to American political and economic development. As we march through time we will survey not only different ways
of thinking about women and gender in the past, but we will also pay attention to how the category of "woman" has been fractured by the differences in status and experience that result from divisions of class, race, region, religion, and ethnicity.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the history of homosexuality as a legible social and cultural category; of lgbt individuals and communities as self-aware social and political actors; and of lgbt/anti-lgbt politics as arenas in which modern Americans have debated fundamental questions about human rights, personal autonomy, and citizenship. We will map the frameworks within which individuals have sought out, enjoyed, and understood sexual activity with others of the same sex; trace the growth of gay and lesbian communities over the course of the twentieth century; and survey the dramatic shifts and turns from the emergence of an organized gay and lesbian political movement to the traumas of the AIDS epidemic and the increasingly bitter fights over lgbtq citizenship and personhood of the last few decades.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should be able to: ? Summarize the major arguments surrounding the history of same-sex desiring individuals and communities and explain the significance of choosing one over another; ? Critically analyze primary texts related to the history of sexuality using one or another of the scholarly arguments presented in the course; ? Identify key figures and moments in U.S. gay and lesbian history and explain their significance; ? Explain how gay and lesbian history maps onto the history of other social categories such as race, gender, and ethnicity?and vice versa; ? Locate contemporary issues and debates in the broader context of U.S. gay and lesbian history and American history generally.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How and when did the identities that we know today as "straight" or "heterosexual" come into existence? And how have those identities differed across time and space? Drawing on the academic literature and representations in film and other popular media, we will examine the "invention of heterosexuality" and its transformation and diversification over the course of the 20th and 21st centuries. By paying attention to multiple definitions of heterosexuality?including those that coexist within a single historical moment and location?we will problematize the notion that heterosexuality can be simply conceived as a single, unitary sexual identity. Among other topics, we will discuss the increasingly blurring boundaries between heterosexuality and other sexual identities; heteroflexibility, sexual fluidity, and other challenges to conventional definitions of heterosexuality; the power associated with heterosexuality, masculinity, and femininity; the effects of sexual inequality; contemporary problems and issues, including hookup culture and definitions of sexual consent; and imagined futures of the notions of sexual identity and sexual orientation.
