Ba Jin, Family.
Edgar Snow, Red Star Over China.
Liang Heng and Judith Shapiro, Son of the Revolution.
Peter Hays, China's New Nationalism.
Plus Readings posted to Canvas. Recommended (not required) textbook: Jonathan Spence, The Search for Modern China.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Food in United States History

What role does food play in U.S. history? What can something so seemingly mundane tell us about our past and present? It is a crucial part of life for all people, but it can also function as a strong marker of distinctive identities. In other words, food reveals much about cultural attitudes, practices, and values, and is a powerful lens through which to explore larger issues like industrialization, urbanization, race and ethnicity, migration, and the environment.

This course considers the development of a broadly "American" food culture from the colonial period to the present as a story of industrialization and globalization. Readings and discussions will examine topics like plantation slavery and factory farm labor, industrial food processing and technological innovations, the political economy and ecology of global commodity chains, nutritional science and reform movements, and the emergence of restaurants, supermarkets, fast food, and slow food.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance and participation 20%; Primary source analysis (2-3 pages) 25%; Article analysis (2-3 pages) 25%; Op-ed assignment (4-6 pages) 30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There are no required textbooks for this course. The readings for this course consist of articles, book chapters, and other items that have been put on Canvas and are also available on reserve at the library. Some of the readings can also be found online (links will be provided on Canvas).

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: The World in A Year

What do Gandhi's assassination, the start of apartheid, the first Kinsey report on sexuality, a town-destroying flood in Oregon, the founding of the Israeli state, and the invention of the modern frisbee have in common? They all happened in 1948. This class will explore what the seemingly unrelated events of just one year can tell us about global environmental change, imperialism, social hierarchy, nationalism, and other themes of the modern era. Each week will focus on a single event of 1948, its history, and its consequences. We will reevaluate familiar episodes from standard modern global history courses and have the opportunity to learn about lesser-known, but no less significant, events. This unconventional approach will give us the opportunity to consider that there are different ways of doing history, and how the kinds of histories we tell (and don't tell) can influence our understanding of the world today.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. Evaluate a diverse array of primary sources
2. Identify how the main themes of environmental change, imperialism, social hierarchy, and nationalism manifested themselves in 1948 and articulate their importance to the modern era
3. Weigh arguments for and against using a global historical perspective and a single-year approach to understand "the American century"
4. Articulate how power - in society, in popular memory, and in the archives - shapes our understandings of the past
5. Discuss complex topics in a collegial and precise manner

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, quizzes, papers, and a timeline project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course reader from Quartet Digital Printing

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Global

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Blood Libel

In Late Antiquity, Jews and early Christians were accused of murdering and eating young children during their initiation rites. In the Middle Ages, whole Jewish communities were routinely massacred in response to accusations of ritual murder and cannibalism. In the modern period, similar accusations have been leveled, with catastrophic results, throughout Europe, the Middle East, and even the United States. Why did belief in religiously inspired ritualized cannibalism, murder, and torture gain and maintain so much traction over such a wide expanse of time? How did accusations against Jews relate to similar charges against heretics, witches, satanic cults, and other marginal groups? This course will trace the origins, diffusion, and surprising persistence of the "blood libel," and will survey historians' attempts to make sense of this phenomenon. We will analyze a wide array of ancient, medieval, and modern sources (all in English translation), and discuss the continued impact of the blood libel motif on contemporary political and theological discourse.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn different historical methodologies, and practice reading primary and secondary sources with a careful and critical eye.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class Participation: 30% 2 Response Papers: 10% Primary Source Analysis: 30% Book Review: 30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course readings will be posted online.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: European

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Empires, Borderlands, Nationalisms

What does ?nationalism' or ?national belonging' look like at the frontiers of a sovereign state instead of its political center? How have expressions of political authority and national belonging changed with global shifts from sovereign imperial polities to sovereign nation-states carved out of former empires? And how do shifts in state authority shape notions of belonging among imperial subjects and national citizens inhabiting frontier territories? This seminar is an opportunity to reflect on these complex and topical questions. We will adopt a historical and comparative approach to analyze frontier regions spread across South and Central Asia, Eastern Europe, and North America. In doing so, we will take border regions and peoples seriously, instead of dismissing them as ?peripheries' of various imperial and national states. We will learn the stories of communities that inhabit such regions as they moved from imperial subjecthood to national citizenship?a process that happened more than once for some of them. Putting these stories in conversation with inherited cultural and scholarly knowledge about nationalism, we will discover what makes a region a borderland, and the extent to which frontiers are central to the formation and perpetuation of sovereign states.

This seminar is divided into three parts. Part I focuses on theoretical understandings of nationalism and borderlands. Part II examines imperial borderlands ranging from the Mughal empire in South Asia to the many frontiers of the British empire. Part III focuses on international borders of the post-colonial era. Key themes will include: sovereign power and its relationship to territorial borders; the politics of belonging among borderlands populations; disputed frontier regions; the seemingly eternal marginality of some borderlands.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
In this course, students will learn to
1. Locate and analyze primary sources
2. Read secondary literature and evaluate scholarly arguments, developing their own positions in the process
3. Use primary and secondary sources to arrive at their own historically informed arguments
4. Refine their writing skills and produce cogent, coherent essays
5. Reflect on the instability of nationalist narratives

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: participation, oral presentations, 3 papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Africa/Middle East, Asia/Middle East

name: Approaches to History
topic: Oral Hist & Terror Archives in Latin Amer

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TOPIC: Oral History and Archives of Terror in Latin America

This course will help students understand oral history as a political battlefield constructed by survivors of violence and terror to denounce, confront, and heal the wounds of state-led violence, dictatorship, genocide, and paramilitary or guerrilla warfare.

The course is divided into three sections. In the first part, we will unpack the concepts and practices of oral history by discussing the theoretical and methodological challenges that professional historians and social scientists identify when doing oral history in Latin America and beyond. In the second and third parts, we will study the "archives of terror" of Latin American Cold War, in which various forms of orality (i.e. testimony, life histories, journalistic interviews, documentary filmmaking, and truth commissions) helped victims of violence to confront trauma, and intervene in the peace processes and/or democratic transitions seeking justice, reparation, truth, and reconciliation.

We will do so reading books and essays, watching movies and documentaries, and bridging the two forms of expression and analysis.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The overarching goal of the course is to understand oral history as a prism that reflects and refracts oral and written forms of making sense of the past, and to understand why it has played such a fundamental role in the definition of the "historical truth" in the turbulence of Latin America at the end of the twentieth century.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Close reading of essays and book chapters, discussions, one oral presentations per student, active watching of documentary films, 3 papers of 5 double-spaced pages each, and a take-home final exam

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None. All essays and book chapters will be available in PDFs in Canvas, as well as documentary films.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: "Gender and Race in the Holocaust"

The aim of this seminar is to introduce students to the history and historiography of race and gender during the Holocaust. As in many historical contexts, race and gender interacted dynamically and created the particular context of Nazi-occupied Europe, which was a place where Jewish men and women suffered in particular ways, German men and women participated in particular ways, and other racial groups - men and women alike - were targeted, collaborated, resisted and rescued. We will read a variety of texts that explore the influences that shaped the behavior and response of an array of people during the Holocaust. Racism sat directly in the center of the Nazi world view. Once the Nazis got into power, they sought to translate ideology into policy. Still, their racial policies evolved over time, spurred by opportunism, innovation, and war. And too, Jewish men and women responded in ways similar and divergent to the Nazi onslaught. Sexism was also seemingly an important aspect of the Nazi perspective. While they indeed embraced an anti-feminist stance, the Nazis nevertheless sought to incorporate "German" women into the national community and women participated actively in the implementation of Nazi racism.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
(Content)
? Identify key concepts related to race and gender during the Holocaust
? Understand societal and personal contexts with regard to race and gender that shaped individual experience and decision-making during the Holocaust
? Understand that the Holocaust was a major event in world history

(Skills)
? Strengthen critical analysis and communication skills (written and verbal) through readings, responses, discussions, and learning portfolios
? Develop group facilitation skills through classroom assignments and student-led discussions

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, Presentation, Papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Matthew Stibbe, Hodder Education, Women in the Third Reich, 2003, 978-0-340-76104-5, Paperback
Marian Kaplan, Oxford University Press, Between Dignity and Despair, 1998, 978-0-19-513092-8, Paperback
Thomas Kuehne, Yale University Press, Genocide and Belonging, 2010, 978-0-300-19828-7, Paperback
Wendy Lower, Mariner Books, Hitler's Furies, 2013, 978-0-544-33449-6, Paperback
Gisella Per, Lexington Books, I Was a Doctor in Auschwitz, 2019, 978-1-4985-8392-3, Hardcover

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: European

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Holocaust Trials

After the Second World War the victorious Allied powers and the liberated peoples of Europe engaged in an unprecedented attempt to bring Nazi war criminals and domestic collaborators to justice. Courts throughout the continent tried and punished hundreds of thousands for having worked with and for Germany and the Axis powers. By and large, however, those trials concentrated on crimes of political collaboration and paid little attention to what is now accepted as the Nazis' greatest crime: the genocide of European Jewry. Although courts did punish some architects of the so-called Final Solution, thousands of Europeans who had organized, perpetrated or otherwise contributed to the Holocaust escaped with minimal penalties or no punishment at all. Over the subsequent decades individuals, organizations, and states have sought to redress the failure to seek out and punish those perpetrators at war's end. Lawyers have prosecuted and defended accused war criminals before courts. Historians have documented the development and execution of genocide, while others have sought to deny the very murders themselves. Through the examination of a series of trials, the first half of the course will discuss both the struggle to bring perpetrators to justice and the efforts to obscure the crimes that had been committed. We will consider the prosecution of war crimes and genocide in the context of the development of international law and historical knowledge over the decades from the Second World War to the present day. For the second half of the course students will concentrate on individual research papers based on primary sources (for example, the records of the Nuremberg Tribunal or Eichman Trial).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course's objective is to examine postwar attempts to employ legal proceedings before courts to seek justice for the crimes committed during the Holocaust of European Jewry and for attempts to deny genocide afterwards. Students will gain an understanding of the potential and limits of various juridical approaches to righting collective and individual wrongs. Students will also practice how to read and analyze primary sources, including trial documents. The primary goal of the course is to write an original research paper.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation, 1 short paper, project presentation, research paper

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Douglas, Lawrence. _The Memory of Judgment: Making Law and History in Trials of the Holocaust_. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001. ISBN-13: 978-0300109849
2. Kaplan, Alice. _The Collaborator: The Trial and Execution of Robert Brasillach_. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2000. ISBN-13: 978-0226424149

name: Research Seminar
topic: Abolition & Equality: 19th Cent. Black Activism in

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Abolition & Equality: 19th-century Black Activism in the Midwest

This digital Humanities course has two areas of focus, one historical and one technological: 1) We will research and write about how African Americans in the Midwest, particularly in Illinois, mobilized for freedom and equality in the 1840s and 1850s. Many of the historical themes we'll examine - including forms of racial inequality in a post-slavery society, African Americans' strategies for social and political mobilization, and Black activists' relationships with white allies ? are enduring topics in U.S. history and resonate with present-day questions and challenges. 2) We will participate in a major collaborative digital humanities enterprise, the Colored Conventions Project. This means exploring practices of digital history, conducting basic work with digitized documents, and designing a web-based exhibit. Prior experience in digital Humanities is not required, but patience and curiosity are.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students who take this class 1) will become familiar with key principles in digital Humanities, particularly those that highlight how people use the digital environment to draw attention to heretofore marginalized voices and histories; 2) will develop skills in public-facing writing and online exhibit design by helping to create an online exhibit where their research will be displayed; 3) will discover and analyze primary sources in African American history; and 4) will better understand African American life and community in the antebellum Midwest and connect the lives of the people they study with contemporary questions of racism, inequality, and anti-racist organizing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, presentations, papers, collaborative projects

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Coursepack and online readings

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a full-year course for students writing a senior honors thesis in history. In the fall quarter, the class will meet as a seminar to discuss issues relating to the writing of history, how to organize a thesis, how to evaluate evidence, and the use of primary and secondary sources. In the winter quarter, students will finish researching their thesis and write a first draft. Then in the spring quarter, students will complete their thesis. Throughout the year, students will meet with their thesis advisers and the 398 seminar leader to work on proposals, outlines, and drafts, and to discuss their progress toward completion of their thesis. In order to graduate with honors in history, students must successfully complete their thesis and have it approved. However, it is possible for students to complete the three quarters of this course with respectable grades but not be awarded honors.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Departmental permission

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Completion of thesis

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Provided via Canvas or by instructor

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Honors students only

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Microhistory

In recent years historians have developed a new technique called microhistory for capturing the lives of the people who have been lost to history?peasants, heretics, poor women, gays, and con-conformists of all sorts. These were the people who because of their low social status, rural origins, illiteracy, or unpopular beliefs were ignored, despised, or persecuted by the dominant society. Microhistory is a method of investigation that usually relies on the evidence from judicial trials of otherwise obscure people who found themselves in trouble with the authorities. The method gives a voice to those who otherwise left no written record of their lives. The result of the studies has been a remarkable re-evaluation of the experiences and beliefs of the common people of pre-modern Europe.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of the course is to acquire command of the theory and methods of microhistory that can be applied to any time or place in the past.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion and three papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Carlo Ginzburg, Clues, Myths, and the Historical Method, paper, ISBN: 0-8018-4388-x

Edward Muir and Guido Ruggiero, eds. Microhistory and the Lost Peoples of Europe, paper, ISBN: 978-0801841835

Carlo Ginzburg, The Cheese and the Worms: The Cosmos of a Sixteenth-Century Miller, paper, ISBN: 978-0801843877

Natalie Zemon Davis, The Return of Martin Guerre, paper, ISBN: 978-0674766914

Natalie Zemon Davis, "The Silences of the Archives: The Renown of the Story," pp. 77-96 in Historical Knowledge: In Quest of Theory, Method and Evidence, ed. Susanna Fellman and Marjatta Rahikainen (Newcastle upon Tyne, 2012), available on Canvas

Steven Bednarski, A Poisoned Past: The Life and Times of Margarida de Portu, A Fourteenth-Century Accused Poisoner, paper, ISBN: 978-1-44260477-3

Simon Schama, Dead Certainties, paper, ISBN: 9780679736134

Richard White, Remembering Ahanagran, paper, ISBN: 9780295983554

Richard Price, First Time: The Historical Vision of an African American People, paper, ISBN: 978-0226680606

Amy Stanley, Stranger in the Shogun's City: A Japanese Woman and Her Worlds, in page proof, available on Canvas

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas, European, Asia/Middle East

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Gender History as Global History

In the past few decades, scholars in the field of global history have challenged others to move beyond the framework of the region or the nation-state. But as many have argued recently, scholars invested in "thinking big" about history sometimes have difficulty addressing people who did not move across political boundaries, and they have typically neglected small, ordinary stories and domestic spaces. Since these have been the traditional interests of women's historians, the fields of global and women's history often seem irreconcilable, especially in the era before the twentieth century. One possible solution to this impasse is to deploy the analytical category of gender, which should be able to speak to both fields and across long spans of time. How have historians done this? What does gender history look like on a global scale? In this seminar, we will consider these questions, reading recent work that combines global and gender history in the early modern and modern eras.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: how to think about and discuss the fields gender history and global history and their relationship to one another

descriptions.value: Seminar

name: General Field Seminar in American History

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces graduate students in history and adjunct fields (they are encouraged to take this class) to major themes in modern US history and its historiography. It selectively examines established scholarship, recent work seen as on the cutting edge, and challenges of practice in the discipline. It also helps prepare students for exams and teaching, and for those specializing in the 20th century, to identify topics they may wish to research further.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will be expected to know the basic contours of modern U.S. history and a variety of ways that scholars have approached it.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.value:
(tentative; in some cases only selections will be assigned; and with some articles/essays added)

George Chauncey, Gay New York: Gender, Urban Culture, and the Making of the Gay Male World, 1890-1940 (1994).
Kevin Boyle, Arc of Justice: A Saga of Race, Civil Rights, and Murder in the Jazz Age (2004).
Daniel T. Rodgers, Atlantic Crossings: Social Politics in a Progressive Age (1998).
David Kennedy, Freedom from Fear: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945.
James T. Sparrow, Warfare State: World War II Americans and the Age of Big Government (2011).
Nancy MacLean, Freedom is Not Enough: The Opening of the American Workplace (2008)
Beth Bailey and David Farber, eds., The Sixties: From Memory to History (1994)
Philip Jenkins, Decade of Nightmares: The End of the Sixties and the Making of Eighties America (2006).
Jefferson Cowie, Stayin' Alive: The 1970s and the Last Days of the Working-Class (2010)
David Harvey, A Brief History of Neo-Liberalism (2005)
Daniel Rodgers, Age of Fracture (2011)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: History Area of Concentration: Americas

name: Field Seminar in Modern European History

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Cosmopolitanism and Public Cultures in Post-Enlightenment Europe

Alarmed by the often Abanal@ globalist imaginary that envisions capital integration as an irresistible force, twenty-first-century intellectuals have turned to cosmopolitanism for an ethics of common community to ground mutual respect and new human solidarities. While debates over the value and dangers of the concept look back to the Greeks, the prescriptive claims of our century take for granted the institutional, technological, political, spatial, and communicative developments associated with the rise of public cultures since the eighteenth-century. Historians in this conversation tend to focus on the processes of contact (between cultures, goods, and peoples) with an acute attention to power. For Europeanists in particular, modern cosmopolitanism has lived in the shadows of imperialism and the nation-state. Hence, while sharing the aspirations of cosmopolitan ideals, historical research typically introduces skeptical caution. This seminar will bring together the historical research that have both directly and indirectly this question in critical conversations with philosophers and political theorists of the new cosmopolitanism like David Held, Martha Nussbaum, Kwame Anthony Appiah. Some historical themes to be examined include: capitalist connoisseurship, worldly citizenship in revolutionary transformations, anthropological knowledge, the technological and commercial developments of mass information and entertainment, searches for colonial exoticism/erotic diversity/sexual dissidence in metropolitan cities, diasporic displacements and de-colonization.

descriptions.value:
Discussion, Presentations, Short Book Reviews, Final Essay.
Tentative syllabus available by request

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Enrollment in The Humanities Plunge is by application only (the application deadline of January 27, 2020 has passed.)

The Humanities Plunge is an "alternative spring break" designed to immerse students in the cultural riches of Chicago with the guidance of experts from the university and the community. This course provides undergraduates with a serious intellectual framework for analyzing what they see or hear when they attend a play or go to a museum and to discuss such endeavors in a structured environment. During a scheduled week of performances, walking tours, museum visits, and other events in Chicago, experts will introduce students to new forms of cultural production and encourage them to think in meaningful ways about the arts and humanities.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Enrollment in The Humanities Plunge is by application only (the application deadline of January 27, 2020 has passed.)

name: Humanities in the Digital Age
topic: Abolition & Equality: 19thC Black Activism in Midw

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Aboltion & Equality: 19th Century Black Activism in the Midwest

This digital humanities course has two areas of focus, one historical and one technological: 1) We will research and write about how African Americans in the Midwest, particularly in Illinois, mobilized for freedom and equality in the 1840s and 1850s. Many of the historical themes we'll examine ? including forms of racial inequality in a post-slavery society, African Americans' strategies for social and political mobilization, and Black activists' relationships with white allies ? are enduring topics in U.S. history and resonate with present-day questions and challenges. 2) We will participate in a major collaborative digital humanities enterprise, the Colored Conventions Project. This means exploring practices of digital history, conducting basic work with digitized documents, and designing a web-based exhibit. Prior experience in digital humanities is not required, but patience and curiosity are essential!

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students who take this class 1) will become familiar with key principles in digital humanities, particularly those that highlight how people use the digital environment to draw attention to heretofore marginalized voices and histories; 2) will develop skills in public-facing writing and online exhibit design by helping to create an online exhibit where their research will be displayed; 3) will discover and analyze primary sources in African American history; and 4) will better understand African American life and community in the antebellum Midwest and connect the lives of the people they study with contemporary questions of racism, inequality, and anti-racist organizing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Group project: Collaborative projects
PresentationsClass participation: Discussion
Papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Coursepack and online readings.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Information Overload! From the Printing Press to the Smartphone

This course explores the anxiety, exhaustion, and unease brought on by information technologies. We will trace emotional responses to technological change, from the shock of the printing press to the malaise of the present "information economy." How did new text technologies reshape language and society? Who is permitted access to certain kinds of information and why? We will take a hands-on approach to these questions by pairing literature that addresses the anxieties of technology, like the scifi linguistics of Arrival and the postapocalyptic Shakespeare of Station Eleven, with book history and digital humanities techniques designed to manage information. Students will learn how books are made, how search algorithms work, and how to analyze text with code.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will:
? understand current debates about emotional and intellectual responses to information overload
? put those debates into context with the long history of information technology
? learn analog and digital strategies for managing large amounts of information
? interrogate their own emotional responses to the information overload in their lives as they relate to the larger cultural conversation

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Online work: Using online research tools and resources
Class participationWriting assignments: 1 midterm paper, several short responses
Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: PresentationsClass participationProject, finalPaper, mid-term

descriptions.value:

Ben Jonson, The Staple of News (PDF provided);
Emily Dickinson poetry (excerpts provided);
Safiya Noble, Algorithms of Oppression (ISBN 1479837245);
Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Americanah (excerpts provided);
Emily St. John Mandel, Station Eleven (ISBN 0804172447)

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: City of Women: Race/Class/Sexuality in American Wo

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This seminar, which plays on Federico Fellini's film of the same title, and the famous 13th century Italian feminist poem "The Treasure of the City of Ladies," explores the variations across positionality, time, and space in women's American urban experiences. We will establish some basic urban-studies concepts and, with a special focus on Chicago, will then read together literary work, historical and social science studies, and contemporary journalism in order to consider misogyny/racism/xenophobia/classism and their effects on women's lives, and issues of women's employment, reproductive rights, sexuality, and violence against women. And, of course, women's own agency in attempting to live their urban lives, pursue their goals, and claim their equal rights and pleasures. We will also consider common representations?and misrepresentations-of varying women's urban lives.

American women live in cities, work in cities, but have had to wage a fight that is by no means over to be accommodated in the urban world. From hostile built environments (e.g., lack of sufficient public women's bathrooms), ongoing lower salaries than men's, to the lack of subsidized childcare, to omnipresent harassment and sexual violence at work, at home, and in the public world, American cities are far more challenging environments for women than for men.

We are living in a strange new cultural and political-economic arena, in which daily horrific racist/misogynist attacks and policies, from the White House down, jostle up against vibrant, active backlash and organizing by grassroots and other feminist and antiracist movements. I encourage students who are interested in unpacking the present to choose some element of the current national conjuncture and gender to research as your topic.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: We will run as a seminar, with all students responding to all readings for 5 weeks. Each student will co-facilitate a discussion of readings one meeting, and will turn in a 3pp paper, in response to a prompt on readings and lectures, April 23rd. The paper is to give me a sense of your abilities and interests, and to give you a sense of how you're doing in the course before the drop date. I will give a number of mini-lectures on key topics, and will take student backgrounds/interests/needs into account in composing them. Then we will move to research mode: students will choose research specific topics/questions relevant to course concerns. [mdl will help with refining the question and resources] They will present their research to classmates in the last two seminar meetings, and we will work together on formulating seminar findings. Final research papers should be ca. 10pp [ca. 2500 words].

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Books, at Norris and on hold unless otherwise noted.
Gina Pérez, The New Northwest Side Story. California. 2004, ISBN 0-520-23368-9, pbk [Amazon has used copies for v little]
Sara Paretsky, Wildcat: V I Warshawski's First Case. [not on hold, but available for $1 as an e-book on multiple platforms]
There is also a course Reader,* available at Quartet Copy, 328-0720

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: Earth Politics and Poetics: Knowing, Shaping, Imag

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Earth Politics and Poetics: Knowing, Shaping, and Imagining the Planet

"Planet Earth" has a political and social history. The Copernican turn and geological notions of deep time, for example, radically shifted understandings of the Earth, time, and humans' relationship to them. Whole Earth images first generated by the Apollo Space missions in the late 1960s and 1970s have been the characteristic form of planetary imagination during the late twentieth century. Earthrise and The Blue Marble images enabled humans to imagine the planet as an interconnected whole against the backdrop of the Cold War and environmental disasters. They have been crucial to the emergence of a "global consciousness" and became famous icons of the global environmental movement, depicting the planet as the common home of humans as one species. The power of these images has not decreased, yet other forms of representation and imagination have emerged as well. The development of Google Earth or advanced climate modeling systems, for example, mark a different notion of Earth, characterized by dynamic, heterogeneous, and open systems. This course examines such shifting notions of the Earth by tracing how practices and discourses of geopolitics, political theory, cartography, population studies, climate modeling, deep ocean sensing, outer space exploration and mining, and science fiction literature, have come to sense, know, represent, and imagine the planet since the 18th century. In doing so, this course also surveys shifting socio-political currents, from the intersection of the military-industrial complex and technoscience to how climate crisis, Anthropocene debates, and Earth Systems analysis reflect further shifts in the ways the planet is understood today. Tracing these shifts in planetary representation and imagination is also crucial to understanding how core concepts such as "humanity" and "species" are made and unmade. Understanding the deeply mediated processes behind planetary depictions is not only central to making sense of contemporary politics and policies that propose to shape the future, but also to imagining alternative worlds and futures beyond our grim ecological predicament.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Chapters will be assigned from the books listed, and most will be in PDF format. (There will also be article assignments.)

Ursula K. Heise, 2008, Sense of Place and Sense of Planet: The Environmental Imagination of the Global (ISBN 9780195335644)

Casper Sylvest, 2018, The Politics of Globality since 1945 (ISBN 9781138477605)

Jan Zalasiewicz, The Earth After Us: What Legacy Will Humans Leave in the Rocks? (ISBN 9780199214983)

Lisa Messeri, 2016, Placing Outer Space: An Ethnography of Outer Worlds (ISBN 9780822362036)

Bruno Latour, 2017, Facing Gaia: Eight Lectures on the New Climatic Regime (ISBN 9780745684345)

Paul Edwards, 2013, A Vast Machine: Computer Models, Climate Data, and the Politics of Global Warming (ISBN 9780262518635)

Jennifer Gabrys, 2016, Program Earth: Environmental Sensing Technology and the Making of a Computational Planet (ISBN 9780816693122)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This courses is approved for credit in the Science in Human Culture major/minor.

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: Red Power: Indigenous Resistance US & Canada

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Red Power: Indigenous Resistance in the U.S. and Canada, 1887-Present

In 2016, thousands of Indigenous water protectors and their non-Native allies camped at the Standing Rock Indian Reservation in an effort to block the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline. That movement is part of a long history of Native activism. In this course, we will examine the individual and collective ways in which Indigenous people have resisted colonial domination in the U.S. and Canada since 1887. In addition to focusing on North America, we will also turn our attention to Hawai?i and the U.S. territories. This course will highlight religious movements, inter-tribal organizations, key intellectual figures, student movements, armed standoffs, non-violent protest, and a variety of visions for Indigenous community self-determination.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: One final essay (35%)
Class participation: Discussion participation (25%)
Papers: Two short papers (20% each)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Nick Estes, Our History Is the Future: Standing Rock Versus the Dakota Access Pipeline, and the Long Tradition of Indigenous Resistance (Verso, 2019), ISBN: 978-1786636720

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Archaeology and Nationalism

Archaeology and nationalism have been closely intertwined at least since the idea of the nation-state emerged following the French Revolution. Archaeology offers nationalist agendas the possibility of filling in national historical records and extending the past far into prehistory. Its results can be displayed in museums, occupy entire sites, and be readily accessible online ?thus potentially reaching many new audiences beyond traditional print media. In turn, nationalism has contributed significantly to the development of archaeology as a modern discipline.

Drawing on new critical approaches and examples selected from a wide geographical range, this course explores the role of archaeology in the creation and elaboration of national identities from the eighteenth century to the present day. Issues include the institutionalization of archaeology; the development of museums and practices of display and interpretation; the creation of archaeological sites as national monuments and tourist destinations; cultural property legislation and repatriation of artifacts; and archaeology and monuments under totalitarian regimes.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will be available through CANVAS and the Northwestern Library.

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: What's "Love" Got to Do With It? Desire and Power

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will focus on five plays by William Shakespeare: As You Like It, The Merchant of Venice, Othello, Antony and Cleopatra, and The Winter's Tale, to explore a recurring theme across Shakespeare's works: how desire, power and control intersect in "romantic" relationships. Through close reading, we will examine the strategies Shakespeare created to represent "love" as a crossroad where eroticism, obsession, politics, economics, gender hierarchies, racism, and anti-Semitism meet. Amongst these strategies: cross-dressing, gender switching, interracial marriage, and pivotal roles for female characters with agency to impact the outcome of the plots set in motion in each play.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
? Students will develop deep familiarity with five of Shakespeare's plays drawn from across his production and seen through the specific framework of the complex dynamics between female and male characters.
? They will be able to identify, analyze, and reflect on Shakespeare's strategies for shaping a range of "love" relationships and to articulate what is at stake for the characters in each of the plays.
? Insights developed during class discussions will offer opportunity to apply the Bard's perspectives to the contemporary world and to students' own lives.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Readings: Students will read 5 of Shakespeare's plays
Class participation: Class grade will, in part, be determined by participation
Writing assignments: Students will complete 3 short papers
Discussion: Class is entirely discussion based

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Attendance: As class is discussion-based, attendance will be weighted in the final grade
Class participation: 40%
Writing assignments: Three assignments at 20% each; a total of 60% of final grade
Contribution to in-class discussion and completion of 3 insightful written assignments based on close readings of the texts.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
NOTE: There are numerous editions of Shakespeare's play with many ISBN numbers. Students may use any edition they wish.

Class materials are five plays by William Shakespeare:

As You Like It
Merchant of Venice
Othello
Antony and Cleopatra
The Winter's Tale

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Animated Documentary

Animation and non-fiction filmmaking seem contrary to one another, though relationships between animation and documentary practices date all the way back to the origins of cinema. This course will trace the history of that interplay, focusing on aesthetic interventions in animated documentaries, especially over the last twenty years (Waltz with Bashir, Persepolis). Parallel examples of non-fiction themes in comic art and video games will also be considered. These forms will be considered alongside readings that explore the rhetoric of design, aesthetics, semiotics, and anthropology. Through these readings, screenings, writing assignments and class discussions, students will explore the contours of this emerging genre.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: A broad historical understanding of animated documentaries.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
LectureReadingsClass participationWriting assignmentsFilms / videos: Screenings
Discussion

name: Special Topics in International Studies
topic: Fall of the USSR and Rise of Russia

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
American Diplomacy: The Fall of the USSR and the Rise of Russia

This course will examine the roots and the drivers of Putin's foreign policy. It will look at the factors leading to the USSR's disintegration and resulting ethnic conflicts, the security issues requiring responses from the U.S., and the decision-making processes in responding to these challenges.

The disintegration of the Soviet Union was the twentieth century's last in a series of collapses of multinational empires, and it presented the U.S. with the most difficult security challenges. In the immediate aftermath, U.S. policy makers were faced with not one but four nuclear powers (Russian Federation, Kazakhstan, Ukraine, and Belarus), thousands of under-secured nuclear weapons and under-paid nuclear scientists, and several armed secessionist conflicts in the Caucasus and Moldova.

The course also will examine the security environment of the post-Cold War world, with a focus on Russia's efforts to assert what it sees as its right to a sphere of influence. The collapse of the USSR meant the end of an uneasy, but by and large consensual, international security system. Russia has shown a willingness to reject that consensus. It has proven deeply skeptical of Western support for the democratic aspirations of former Soviet states, willing even to use military force to deny countries like Ukraine and Georgia their sovereign rights to join NATO and the EU. Closer to home, it has employed various direct and indirect efforts to undermine Western solidarity and confidence in the liberal democratic system.

As a final project, students will propose possible U.S. responses to a resurgent Russia.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be required to write a midterm book review of one of the required books, and, as a final project, they will propose possible U.S. responses to a resurgent Russia

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
One of the following:

A World Transformed, by George Bush and Brent Scowcroft
At the Highest Levels, by Michael R. Beschloss and Strobe Talbott
The Last Empire: The Final Days of the Soviet Union, by Serhii Plokhi

All other readings will be on Canvas.

name: Special Topics in International Studies
topic: Transnational Americas: From Migrantes to Latinx

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TOPIC: TRANSNATIONAL AMÉRICAS: FROM MIGRANTES TO LATINX

DESCRIPTION: Migration is not just a movement across borders, it is a process of becoming. By examining trajectories of intra- and inter-national migration within and out of Latin America, this course will explore the social, cultural, economic, and political histories that reveal relationships between migration and larger global and postcolonial socio-economic forces. We will reflect on the reasons why individuals choose to become mobile, as well as the structural conditions that might compel them. Specifically, we will look at disparities between urban and rural populations, clashes over ownership of job markets in urban settings, and the formation of individual and collective migrant identities. The course will begin by studying how waves of migrants (within and across frontiers) after independence shaped contemporary ideologies of race and belonging in Latin America, and end with a reflection on what these trajectories can teach us about studying Latin American migrants in the "Global North" today. Furthermore, the course will investigate how migration pathways challenge accounts of unified Latin American and Latinx "identities," yet also allow for diasporic coalitions. Course materials include canonical readings from anthropology and history, along with media texts such as films and other visual media.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Mallon, F. 2005. Courage Tastes of Blood: The Mapuche Community of Nicolás Ailío and the Chilean State, 1906-2001.
978-0-8223-8726-8

Rosa, J. 2018. Looking Like a Language, Sounding Like a Race
978-0190634735

name: Integrating Project Seminar
topic: Everyday Life in Global and Comparative Perspectiv

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How can we make sense of the daily, the mundane, the ordinary, in a complex and changing world? In this integrating project seminar, we will capture the complexity and heterogeneity of everyday life across societies, and uncover the cultural, demographic, social, economic, legal, political, and institutional forces that shape it. For these purposes, we will borrow from several theoretical, disciplinary, and interdisciplinary perspectives (including sociology, history, anthropology, cultural studies, health sciences, economics, law, and political science). We will investigate the tensions between the individual and the group; the idiosyncratic and the shared; the local and the global; the national, transnational, and international; the context-bound and the universal. We will identify - and learn how to avoid - such common pitfalls as stigmatization, stereotyping, miserabilism, romanticization, and exoticization. All along, students will develop research skills and pursue their own research paper addressing issues of everyday life. This paper will comply with rigorous standards of research, and involve passion, creativity, and personal meaningfulness. I hope you will enjoy the journey!

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
You should expect to come away with:
-A (scholarly!) understanding of everyday life
-Key research skills
-An understanding of the ways in which the global and the local shape each other
-Critical and intercultural reading, thinking, discussing, and writing skills
-Practice with an interdisciplinary approach to international studies
-Practice with reading diverse genres in the global humanities and social sciences
-Intellectual and professional collegiality with your fellow IS majors
-Intellectual tools for lifelong learning and professional development on international issues
-A rigorous, proud, and publishable research paper

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials for this course will be made available on Canvas - no purchase necessary.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
According to the UNHCR, the world is witnessing the highest level of forced displacement on record in the last three years. Insecurity and daunting scarcity of physical and legal resources are ever more parts and parcels of displaced communities' lives. Health disparities and death rates are particularly high among these communities and have long-term social and psychological effects on the lives of the survivors. This course focuses on health disparities and differentiated mortality rates in order to tackles issues of (il)legality, citizenship, and integration among contemporary displaced communities around the world. It proposes to investigate people's lives and deaths in times of displacement and indeterminacy to ask: What legal and political constraints reinforce health disparities and social inequalities among displaced communities? To what extent refugees' appeal for rights to citizenship and to health can go beyond the conventional forms of sovereign state power? What are the benefits and limits of (non)governmental organizations' services for displaced communities? Knowledge of these efforts calls attention to the achievements and shortcomings of humanitarianism, the lesser-recognized ways that displaced communities heal and survive political and environmental instabilities, and the possible approaches that governmental authorities and the international community could implement in their agenda for the global displacement crisis.

This interdisciplinary and research-intensive course uses ethnographic studies to model successful qualitative research designs for students. Further, by familiarizing them with the main theoretical approaches in ethnographic research, it helps them develop a critical lens towards the current national and transnational regimes of care in relation to displaced people. It has large implications for students who are interested in global health, physical and mental health disparities among migrant communities, international legal frameworks, human rights and humanitarianism, and national laws and citizenship status. Key topics of the course will include: national and international policies to the current displacement crisis, humanitarian interventions, legality and transnationalism, the global economy of care, and human rights in theory and practice.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students will be equipped with:
? A broad knowledge of social, economic, and political determinants of ongoing displacement crisis and health disparities among displaced communities
? Main theoretical and methodological approaches in ethnographic research
? Research proposal writing and revision
? Critical evaluation of scholarly works

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course will use lectures, class discussions and debates, class presentation, and research proposal writing and peer-review exercises.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the basis of regular attendance, active participation in class discussion, 2 rounds of research project submissions, class presentation, and a peer review exercise.

descriptions.value: All course materials will be available on Canvas - no purchase necessary.

name: Climate Change and Sustainability: Ethical Dimensions

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is about our ethical responsibilities in the face of anthropogenic climate change. The course begins with an introduction to philosophical ethics, the scientific evidence in support of an anthropogenic role in climate change, and some advanced technological approaches to mitigating the effects of climate change. After these introductory sessions the class is split into two parts. We will begin with an exploration of how far reaching our ethical responsibilities are by questioning which things matter morally: are future-human beings, non-human animals, and ecosystems morally important? How do they compare morally to humans alive today? In the second part of the course we will focus on how individually specific our ethical responsibilities are. We will focus on a range of common behaviors relevant to climate change and ask whether and how we can ethically justify our individual participation or lack of participation in these behaviors. We will conclude the course by asking how our moral responsibilities with respect to climate change fit with our other moral responsibilities.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Fulfills Area V Weinberg Distribution Requirement

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This course will give you a detailed introduction to central themes in the ethics of climate change, and their application to a wide range of real-world issues concerning climate change. First, you will learn about the three fundamental approaches to ethics and you will develop your own arguments using tools from these approaches throughout the course. Having done this, you will be prepared to enter any ethics class with a detailed familiarity with the basic concepts of philosophical ethics. Second, you will be introduced to a very important and broad research project in ethics by engaging directly with literature about our moral obligations to "distant" individuals and situations such as persons living in far away countries, persons not yet born, and future disasters. This will give you the tools to analyze many issues that are unique to climate change. And third, throughout the course you will examine contemporary real-world choices we face collectively and individually. In doing so, you will hone your understanding of the ethical approaches we discuss as well as your skills of argument analysis, and you will sharpen your own views on many practically important issues.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: There is no discussion section.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Italian 101-2 is the second in a three-part sequence for beginning students of Italian.
At this level students work on the three modes of communication while discovering Italy and its people. At the end of full-year Italian 101 sequence, students will be able to ask and answer simple questions in Italian, write a grammatically correct sentence, and follow the drift of a simple conversation. Students will gain knowledge of fundamental aspects of Italian culture, history, and geography. The emphasis is on interpersonal communication. We build grammar skills by working on simple situations that grow in complexity as we proceed: greetings, talking about ourselves, asking others, performing tasks. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian and are very lively, with lots of give-and-take among participants.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 101-3 is the third quarter of the year-long Elementary Italian course sequence. Students enroll in 101-3 after having completed 101-1 and 101-2 or by demonstrating equivalent proficiency through the online placement test. This quarter emphasizes verb tenses such as the imperfect in relation to the passato prossimo, the future, the conditional, and an introduction to the subjunctive mood. Cultural topics include the school system, social issues, cultural and ethnic diversity, the world of work, and vacations. At the end of full-year Italian 101 sequence, students are able to ask and answer questions in Italian, write grammatically correct sentences, and follow conversations of various degrees of complexity. Students will have gained knowledge of fundamental aspects of Italian culture, history, and geography. Lessons are conducted almost entirely in Italian and are very lively, with lots of give-and-take among participants.

descriptions.value: completion of Italian 101-1 & 101-2 or equivalent proficiency as demonstrated by online placement exam & oral interview

descriptions.value: quizzes, writing assignments, listening & dictation exercises, final oral exam

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Italian 102-3 is the third part of the intermediate sequence. Intermediate Italian continues and completes the two-year sequence in Italian language. At the end of the full 102 sequence (102-1,2,3), students will be able to create with the language, talk about familiar topics, comprehend the main ideas and some supporting details of articles, stories, and other texts dealing with topics of a concrete nature, and write grammatically correct paragraphs. Students will significantly increase their knowledge of Italy's history and culture. Having completed the entire sequence of Italian 102, students will be eligible to study in Italy and will be ready to embark on the minor or major in Italian. The second-year Italian course sequence completes the two-year WCAS language requirement. The classroom is very lively, with lots of conversation, partnering, and small group exercises. Students will be nurtured toward independence, posing and solving language problems on their own and in collaboration with classmates. While speaking and listening continue as the center of class activity, they will focus more intensively on reading and writing Italian.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the role that exhibitionism and the logic of spectacle have played in Italian culture from the years of Fascism (1922-1943) to Silvio Berlusconi's rise to power in the 1990s and our current predicament. As the flip side of our desire to see, exhibitionism manifests the desire to be seen, to expose oneself to the look of others?to turn oneself into a spectacle? in both the private and public spheres. While drawing from the fields of cinema and media studies, we will analyze how film, television, and social media have simultaneously reflected and constructed our desire for self-display. We will pay particular attention to questions of gender and sexuality and to the ways in which spectacle and politics have joined forces at different junctures in Italian history. Among the films we will study are Luchino Visconti's Bellissima (1951), Federico Fellini's La dolce vita (1960) and Ginger and Fred (1986), Erik Gandini's Videocracy (2009), Matteo Garrone's Reality (2012), and Paolo Sorrentino's La grande bellezza (2013).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: none

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To develop an understanding of the notion of exhibitionism and the role it has played in a specific cultural context

This double course completes the WCAS two year language requirement in one academic year. At the end of the full-year 133/134 sequence, the student will be able to ask and answer detailed questions, read and discuss brief articles and stories in modern written Italian, and compose a grammatically correct paragraph in Italian.

Students will significantly increase their knowledge of Italy's history and culture. Having completed Italian 133/134, students will be eligible to apply to the BCSP year-abroad programs at the University of Bologna and the University of Padova.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is dedicated to the analysis of wonder in Italian literature, understood within the more general
framework including marvel, miracle, admiratio and mirabilia. Plato' discussion in the Theaetetus -
where Socrates links wonder to the beginning of philosophy - and Aristotle's famous definition in his
Metaphysics - pointing to man's basic drive for learning and truth and thus calling attention to the
capacity for wonder built in human nature, are fundamental to understand wonder and its development
across the centuries. The course follows the ramification of the idea of wonder covering Italian literature
from the Middle Ages to Modernity

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Dante's Divine Comedy: To Love through Justice
Professor Nasti

Refashioning the conventions of poetry, Dante (1265-1321) used the account of his presumed journey through the three realms of the Christian afterlife - Hell, Purgatory and Paradise - to explore the world at the close of the Middle Ages. The poem is both an adventure story and an exhaustive, assessment of the state of politics, society, religion, literature, philosophy, and theology at the beginning of the fourteenth century. This course examines a selection of cantos Dante's Inferno and Purgatorio in its cultural, social and political context. In particular we will explore how the underground world imagined by the poet relates to late medieval urban life and culture. A guiding concern of the discussion is to assess the ways in which Dante changed our understanding of the relationship between the human and the divine, justice and love, will and reason, happiness and knowledge, literature and the Bible. Political turmoil, philosophical and theological paradigms social and religious conflict all converge in the making of Inferno and Purgatorio and will thus form crucial elements of our investigation.

A reader of the selection of cantos we will be reading will also be available for students. Students can therefore buy as much or as little as they see fit as long as they can access the online text with ease.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Japanese I (JAPANESE 111-1, 2 and 3) is a yearlong course that covers the first half of college level elementary Japanese. In Japanese I, students will build a solid foundation while developing the four skills of speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Students will also learn various aspects of Japanese culture and society through in-class activities, written assignments, and video viewing. Students are encouraged to identify and self-correct errors in their language use to become independent learners. The instructor will assist in this learning process through oral and written feedback. Careful and thorough review and preparation for each class session are required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Except for JAPANESE 111-1, students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of Japanese I is to bring students' overall Japanese proficiency to the Intermediate-Low level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines. Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, the students will be able to greet, introduce themselves, describe their families and friends, discuss their daily routines and experiences, and write letters to teachers and friends. ??

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course is conducted mostly in Japanese, and class hours are spent mainly on oral proficiency development. Written assignments are given for reading and writing proficiency development. ??

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation and performance; assignments; quizzes; oral and written examinations??

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Japanese II (JAPANESE 121-1, 2 and 3) is a yearlong course that covers the second half of college level elementary Japanese and prepares students for intermediate Japanese (JAPANESE 211). In this course, students continue developing the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) through readings, video viewing, written assignments, and in-class activities. The emphasis will be on developing the skills necessary to use auxiliary verbs and complex sentences to express subtle differences in meaning and accuracy appropriate to the given contexts. Student will also practice describing their experiences and summarizing a story that they heard, read, or watched in an organized manner. Careful and thorough review and preparation for each class session are required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, students will be able to handle various types of more complex daily conversational situations and passages. The year-end proficiency goal of Japanese II is for the students to reach the Intermediate-Mid level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course is conducted mostly in Japanese. Class hours are spent mainly on oral proficiency development, and written assignments are given for reading and writing skills development. Useful expressions in daily life and social and cultural aspects in modern Japan are introduced through a series of videos.

descriptions.value: Class participation and performance, assignments, quizzes, oral and written examinations, and essays

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Japanese III (JAPANESE 211-1, 2, 3) is a yearlong course, sequel to Japanese II (JAPANESE 121-1, 2, 3), that covers college-level intermediate Japanese. In Japanese III, students will continue developing the four skills of speaking, listening, reading, and writing, and learning various aspects of Japanese culture and society through class discussions, written assignments, TV drama viewing, and a research-based interview project. The casual speech and formal writing styles are introduced, and students will become familiarized with different language use for different settings. With consistent oral and written feedback from the instructor, the students will also continue learning to identify and self-correct errors in their language use to become independent learners.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, the students will be able to 1) describe and narrate daily events and personal experiences in an organized manner, 2) summarize the main points of what is read, seen, or heard, 3) use approximately 500 basic kanji characters in context, 4) comfortably and appropriately handle daily situations 5) use various speech and written styles, and 6) communicate with native speakers on familiar topics in informal settings. The students are also expected to 7) deepen their understanding of customs, culture, and social phenomena of contemporary Japan, and 8) learn to study independently. The year-end proficiency goal of Japanese III is for the students to reach the Intermediate-High level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Few literatures can have been more isolated and isolating than Modern Hebrew Literature in its formative years in Europe in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Young Jewish men are afforded a glimpse of the intellectual vistas lying beyond the stifling confines of the traditional Jewish shtetl. Reviled in these traditional communities as "heretics" they sought refuge from ostracism, persecution, in the tenements and boarding-houses of the metropolises of Europe. Umbilically attached to an unspoken language these outsiders wrote in full awareness that their potential audience consisted largely of each other. This "imagined community" was an exclusively male domain; the handful of female Hebrew writers in the Europe constituted an absolute anomaly.
It was in the erotic realm that this isolation reached its fullest literary summation, especially in the figure of the "Talush" ("the uprooted man") which placed center stage effeminate, masochistic Jewish men often subordinated by ruthless gentile women. This literature breathed of sexual anxiety.
The course aims to explore the poetic, the ideological and the gender implications of the interwoven themes of eros and isolation in Hebrew Literature from the turn of the 19th century to the present day. In doing so, we shall study the migration of these themes along with Hebrew Literature itself from Europe to Palestine and ultimately the State of Israel. Has the rebuilding of the national "Home" brought the uprooted man his long lost masculinity? And how did the female writer incorporate/become incorporated by the "Talush" narrative? How do we account for the longevity of this sad and pathetic figure? This course provides an excellent introduction to Modern Hebrew Literature per se: we shall read classic texts by M.Y. Berdichevsky, Y.H. Brenner, S.Y. Agnon, alongside excerpts from contemporary bestselling Israeli novels by Amos Oz, Ya'akov Shabtai and others.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Co-listed with History 200-0-28

Title: Leisure and Popular Culture in 20th Century Palestine/Israel.

This course focuses on leisure and popular culture in Palestine and later Israel during the 20th century. Looking at both Jewish and Arab societies, this course examines cultural changes unfolded in various cultural arenas such as: cafes, cinemas, beaches, nightlife, theater, sports, radio, drug and alcohol consumption and more. Using leisure as a useful lens for historical analysis, the course sheds new light on broad local and global events which shaped the daily life of ordinary people. We will examine how leisure and popular culture were influenced by broad processes of modernization, urbanization, the emergence of national identities and the evolving conflict between the Arab and Jewish communities. The course combines wide range of primary sources as well as cultural production of Jewish and Arabs writers, movie makers, and artists.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Be familiar with the cultural and social history of Palestine and Israel.

- Better understanding of the complex and multi-faceted relationship between the Jewish and Arab communities based on cultural perspectives.

- Make informed historical judgments upon a contested historical period and encourage critical thinking in relations to it.

- Encourage active participation in class discussions and in critical evaluation of primary and secondary sources.
