name: Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course aims at introducing students to major themes in the modern history, politics and so­cieties of the Arabian Peninsula, which is an often neglected but increasingly pivotal region of the Middle East. The first half of the course will concentrate on state formation and the politi­cal, economic and ideological forces that shaped the Peninsula until the British withdrawal. The second half of the course will be more thematic and will address some of the most important challenges that the region has faced since the 1970s. Because of its undeniable regional importance and influence, Saudi Arabia will receive particular attention throughout the quarter, though lectures and readings will cover other emirates of the Gulf as well as Yemen. The course combines lectures and some discussions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Madawi Al-Rasheed, A History of Saudi Arabia, 2nd ed. (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2010).

name: Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Archaeology and nationalism have been closely intertwined at least since the idea of the nation-state emerged following the French Revolution. Archaeology offers nationalist agendas the possibility of filling in national historical records and extending the past far into prehistory. Its results can be displayed in museums, occupy entire sites, and be readily accessible online ?thus potentially reaching many new audiences beyond traditional print media. In turn, nationalism has contributed significantly to the development of archaeology as a modern discipline.

Drawing on new critical approaches and examples selected from a wide geographical range, this course explores the role of archaeology in the creation and elaboration of national identities from the eighteenth century to the present day. Issues include the institutionalization of archaeology; the development of museums and practices of display and interpretation; the creation of archaeological sites as national monuments and tourist destinations; cultural property legislation and repatriation of artifacts; and archaeology and monuments under totalitarian regimes.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will be available through CANVAS and the NU Library.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The MENA Colloquium is designed to encourage dialogue between students across disciplines who share interests in Middle East and North African Studies, to offer a space to develop extended papers and research reports, and to foster discussion between Northwestern MENA students and faculty. Students begin by enrolling in MENA 412-1 followed by MENA 412-2 as zero credit courses. Upon successful completion of MENA 412-1 and 2 students may enroll in MENA 412-3, completion of which earns one course credit. Students taking the three part MENA 412 sequence must present their work at a MENA colloquium at least one time per academic year, pre-circulate their paper to other members of the seminar, make one formal response, attend all MENA colloquia plus selected invited speakers, and actively participate in breakfasts/lunches with select speakers and faculty. In order to obtain a Certificate in MENA Studies, students must enroll in three quarters of MENA 412 (one course credit) and three quarters of MENA 415 (which meets at the same time as MENA 412, and is otherwise identical, but does not require a public presentation or comment and bears no credit). Attendance at the colloquium is open to the public, although pre-circulated papers are only accessible to students enrolled in the MENA 412 sequence.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Pre-req: MENA 412-1. Open to students in any graduate program at Northwestern whose work intersects with study of the Middle East and/or North Africa. Students affiliated with the MENA Cluster or pursuing a MENA Certificate are automatically eligible. Others may inquire of the MENA Program Director.

15 minute presentation based on the paper, ideally with visuals and/or handouts. One formal five-minute response to another student presentation. Active participation in the colloquium. Note: MENA 412-1, 2, 3 is normally completed in a single academic year, but can also be spread over two academic years, with consent of MENA director. Please note: this is a three quarter long sequence bearing one course credit.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To provide a forum for presenting, developing, and responding to research on the Middle East and North Africa from a variety of disciplinary perspectives; to enable conversations across disciplinary methodologies which both sharpens students' sense of their own discipline and develops ability to communicate across those disciplines; to foster dialogue among graduate students working on MENA studies and members of the faculty.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Presentations, faculty response, and group discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students enrolled for credit are evaluated based on their public presentation, and their responses (both written and oral) to the papers and presentations of other students enrolled in MENA 412 for credit.

name: Master's in Science in Neurobiology Laboratory Research

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores current understanding of the organization and function of the mammalian central nervous system. Topics will include basic neuroanatomy, sensation and sensory perception, motor control, and higher cognitive functions including decision-making. Time will be devoted to presentation of essential knowledge from each area as well as to a discussion of key experiments that have contributed to our understanding. As an aid to the comprehension of relationships between structure and function in the central nervous system, sheep brain dissections will be performed.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: NEUROSCI 202-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 or BIOL_SCI 302-0; and be a neuroscience major.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures; discussion of research articles.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterm exams, final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Neuroscience, 6th Edition by Dale Purves et al.
ISBN -13: 978-1605353807, ISBN-10:1605353809 cost $135.95

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: none

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Students must have completed NEUROSCI 202-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 or BIOL_SCI 302-0 to register for this course. Must be a neuroscience major.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Neuropsychopharmacology treats brain disorders by adjusting the activity of specific brain molecules. These molecules largely localize to synapses, remarkable structures where signaling gives rise to thought and behavior. This advanced seminar course focuses on molecular mechanisms and aberrations of synaptic signal transduction and drugs that target them. Introductory historical perspectives will be followed by consideration of contemporary issues. Class discussions focus on readings from the research literature.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: NEUROSCI 202-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 or BIOL_SCI 302-0.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and seminar-style discussions of assigned readings, with optional term projects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Class materials will be freely available.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisite: Students must have completed NEUROSCI 202-0 or NEUROSCI 311-0 or BIOL_SCI 302-0 to register for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
How do animals learn? This course examines what neurobiologists know about how brain cells and neural circuits process experience to produce lasting changes in behavior. Lectures will involve in depth discussion of original research findings, with a focus on the latest molecular, neural physiology, and behavioral studies.
A key goal of the course is for students to think logically about the design and interpretation of experiments from the primary literature, as well as to critically think about how to address current questions in the field of learning and memory.

At this time, this class is intended for Biology Majors and Neuroscience Majors Only.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is a project-based laboratory to investigate the genetic roots of neurobiology and behavior in a simple model system. We focus on non-electrode methods to study neural circuits and behavior including mutant analysis, neuroanatomical techniques, and behavioral paradigms such as courtship, aggression, circadian and sleep behavior. We will use the fruit fly as a model system because of the amazing genetic tools available to study the fly nervous system and the conservation of basic neurobiological processes between flies and humans. During the first section of the course you will learn a variety of techniques to study the nervous system. You will then design a project using the techniques learned in class, to be completed in the final weeks of the course. This will be summarized in a lab report due during finals week.
NOTE 1: This course requires manual dexterity, steady hands, and good vision. You will need to handle flies while keeping them healthy, dissect their brain tissue, and troubleshoot practical problems. If any of these might pose challenges for you, please talk to the instructor before registering.
NOTE 2: You will need to come into the labs outside class time at least a few times a week to collect virgin flies. This is done at the beginning and the end of the day and it is an ongoing task. Later in the course you will likely also need to come to finish experiments. Time outside regularly scheduled class is 2 or more hours per week typically and motivated students are encouraged to spend more time. Prerequisites: NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0; or NEUROSCI 311-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0; or BIOL SCI 302-0.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0 (previously NEUROSCI 306-0); or NEUROSCI 311-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0; or BIOL SCI 302-0. Permission number from Neuroscience department required to enroll.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will acquire a deep understanding of:
1) Fundamental neurobiological principles arising from studies of the nervous system at the cellular and molecular level.
2) History and recent developments in neuroscience research.
3) Methods used to study the nervous system, including specific experimental techniques relevant to cellular and molecular neuroscience, the design, analysis and interpretation of experiments using specific techniques, and the strengths and limitations of those techniques.
4) Ethical issues raised by the growing body of information generated by neuroscience research, including the use of animals.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Persian 121-3 is the third quarter of a three-quarter sequence for students who have completed first-year Persian or have been placed in the course through the Placement Test. The primary goal of this course is to develop students' active and passive basic grammar and vocabulary while exploring contemporary Iranian culture. Class meets three times a week and will be conducted in Persian. Students are expected to be on time, to participate actively, and to prepare outside of class at least one hour daily. Intermediate Persian follows a communicative approach to enable students to produce natural language rooted in an understanding of culture. In this course, students will learn about sports in Iran. They will also talk about jobs, news, and immigration in Iran. Chapters 25, 26, and 27 will be covered.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Persian 121-1 or equivalent; or permission of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The learning objectives of Second-Year Persian:

  • broadening students' cultural knowledge of Persian by engaging with natural linguistic products such as daily conversations, texts (pieces of news, social media, and, by the end of the year, literary texts), films, and music videos;

  • conversing in colloquial Persian;

  • expanding students' vocabulary and knowledge of grammatical rules to be able to produce natural (both formal and informal) linguistic utterances;

  • developing writing skills by working on a written portfolio.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Following the communicative approach, grammatical structures and vocabulary are practiced throughout the course in context. This is an interactive course, and students are expected to come to class prepared to be able to participate in class actively.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class Participation; Homework; Three Tests; Writing Portfolio; Collaborative Presentation; and Oral Interview.

name: First-Year Seminar in Philosophy
topic: How to Live the Good Life

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Some academic philosophers today treat philosophy as a series of puzzles about abstract questions or thought experiments. But ancient philosophical traditions around the world engaged in philosophy with the practical aim of figuring out how to live well. In this class, we will carry on that practical approach. We'll think hard together about big questions that you might wonder about in your ordinary life: What does a successful life look like? What should we aim at and how should we pursue these aims? Should we try to be happy? Should we try to make the world better? Should we try to be good? Or are we too fixated on doing things? Would it be better to give contemplation, gratitude, or enjoyment a larger role? We'll think about these questions with the help of great texts from the past, the work of some contemporary philosophers, and journalistic reports and essays drawn from popular media. You will develop, refine, and argue for your own answers in both discussion and written work.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Think deeply and responsibly about ethical questions.

2. Become familiar with a range of views about how to live well.

3. Learn concepts that will allow you to think in new ways about what is worth valuing and doing.

4. Cultivate the practice of philosophical self-reflection.

5. Discover the personal and social value of philosophy.

6. Grow in five intellectual virtues: curiosity, clarity of thought, intellectual courage, intellectual humility, and charitable interpretation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The transition from the Medieval to the Modern era in philosophy began, roughly, in the late 16th and early 17th centuries and ended, again roughly, in the late 18th century. New methods of acquiring knowledge, along with a radically different conception of the world, permanently transformed the philosophical enterprise and the broader culture. In this course we will examine the views of some of the most important modern philosophers?especially Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, Bayle, Locke, Berkeley, and Hume?on the nature of God, causation, substance, mind, knowledge, and the material world. Additional readings will be drawn from Elizabeth, Galileo, Masham, Boyle, Shepherd, and Du Châtelet.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop critical reading, writing, and thinking skills while also learning about the major philosophical changes that created the modern world.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class introduces students to a variety of philosophical problems concerning gender and politics. Together, we'll read classic and contemporary texts that examine questions such as: what is gender - and how, if it all, does it relate to or differ from sex? What does it really mean to be a woman or a man - and are these categories we're born into or categories that we become or inhabit through living in a particular way under specific conditions? Human history all the way up to the present seems to be rife with asymmetrical relations of power that relegate those marked out as women to a subordinate position - what explains this? What would it mean to over turn this state of affairs - and which strategies are most likely to accomplish this task? And to what extent is it possible to grapple with all of the above questions - questions of gender, sex and sexuality - without also, at the very same time, thinking about how they relate to questions of class and race? Readings will include selections from Simone de Beauvoir, Iris Marion Young, Sandra Bartky, bell hooks, Patricia Hill Collins, Judith Butler, Talia Bettcher, and others.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be introduced to dominant historical philosophical paradigms for formulating rights claims and related concepts of freedom and recognition. In these contexts, students will be introduced to major thinkers associated with a western canon of significant historical arguments concerning sex and gender. The course offers an opportunity for critical evaluation by students of the strategies and vindications adopted by those traditionally denied rights. Students will be exposed to a number of approaches for critically assessing such claims and justifications as a history of strategic decisions. The class equips participants to ask whether these various choices ? and their conditions ? have been problematic or promising? Finally, the course will enable students to assess and situate a number of contemporary rights claims in the light of their understanding of this history.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: There is broad agreement that one of the guiding threads of Africana Philosophy is the concern for liberation of Black peoples from racism, colonialism, and gender violence in the African Diaspora. But even if this can be agreed upon many of the thinkers who belong to this tradition wrote from vastly different historical and geographical contexts and, thus, we cannot assume that they all agreed or were responding to the same problems. This course will introduce students to the Africana philosophical tradition via hermeneutics. By reading figures from the late 19th to the mid-20th century students will be exposed both to the breadth of ideas of what it means to be free and learn how to read figures that come from historical contexts other than their own. In doing so students will develop the critical resources to reflect on issues of freedom in the present.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop the skills to read historical texts from the late 19th century to the mid-20th century and apply them to our context. Through this they will become familiar with key thinkers of the African-American/Africana philosophical tradition and ask how these figures understood the universality of rationality, the necessity of political and social change, and what role race plays in both. Finally, this course will train students on how to write argumentative essays that take up these ideas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a gentle introduction to Metaphysics. Metaphysics is an effort to think rigorously about the fundamental nature of reality. Some examples of metaphysical questions we will discuss are: Does reality contain causes, or are they a projection of our representation? What is it to be a person, and what is it to be the same person at different time? Is the world deterministic? If yes, how does that affect our belief that persons have free will. What is time? Are there other possible worlds, and if so how should we think of them? Throughout the course we will keep in sight a fundamental methodological question: how is it possible for us to make progress in thinking about these matters?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students in the course will:

(a) Acquire knowledge of classical arguments on a range of metaphysical issues.

(b) Acquire the ability to analyze metaphysical arguments critically, rigorously and independently.

(c) Work on their ability to produce their own rigorous arguments on the metaphysical subjects in question.

(d) Acquire the ability to represent problems abstractly and think of possible solutions to them in terms of the abstract representation.

Among the questions to be addressed are: What is God? Can one prove the existence of God? Is there an inherent conflict between faith and reason? If God is all good, why do we experience evil? Is there any way we can overcome the lure of sin? What does it mean to love God?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to central concepts and problems in environmental ethics. We will devote particular attention to the question of moral standing, or in other words, the question of who or what is deserving of ultimate moral consideration. Topics to be discussed include the ethical treatment of animals, the value of non-sentient life, individualism versus holism in ethics, climate change and the ethics of geoengineering, and whether and why anthropocentrism might be a problem in environmental ethics.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain familiarity with core ethical and meta-ethical problems surrounding humans' relationship to the natural world, as well as philosophical methods for addressing those problems. Students will also acquire proficiency in reading, analyzing, and critically evaluating moral-philosophical arguments.

name: Climate Change and Sustainability: Economic and Ethical Dimensions

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is about our ethical responsibilities in the face of anthropogenic climate change. The course begins with an introduction to philosophical ethics, the scientific evidence in support of an anthropogenic role in climate change, and some advanced technological approaches to mitigating the effects of climate change. After these introductory sessions the class is split into two parts. We will begin with an exploration of how far reaching our ethical responsibilities are by questioning which things matter morally: are future-human beings, non-human animals, and ecosystems morally important? How do they compare morally to humans alive today? In the second part of the course we will focus on how individually specific our ethical responsibilities are. We will focus on a range of common behaviors relevant to climate change and ask whether and how we can ethically justify our individual participation or lack of participation in these behaviors. We will conclude the course by asking how our moral responsibilities with respect to climate change fit with our other moral responsibilities.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This course will give you a detailed introduction to central themes in the ethics of climate change, and their application to a wide range of real-world issues concerning climate change. First, you will learn about the three fundamental approaches to ethics and you will develop your own arguments using tools from these approaches throughout the course. Having done this, you will be prepared to enter any ethics class with a detailed familiarity with the basic concepts of philosophical ethics. Second, you will be introduced to a very important and broad research project in ethics by engaging directly with literature about our moral obligations to "distant" individuals and situations such as persons living in far away countries, persons not yet born, and future disasters. This will give you the tools to analyze many issues that are unique to climate change. And third, throughout the course you will examine contemporary real-world choices we face collectively and individually. In doing so, you will hone your understanding of the ethical approaches we discuss as well as your skills of argument analysis, and you will sharpen your own views on many practically important issues.

name: The Brady Scholars Program: The Good Society

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
What are the markers of a good society, and in particular of a just society? Instead of approaching this question from a purely abstract theoretical perspective, this course will pursue the matter in a concrete and focused way by attending to one of our society's principal impediments to justice, namely racism. We shall discuss questions that fall into four categories:

(1) What is justice? (2) What is race? (3) What is racism and how does it undermine justice? What are the different facets of racism? What are the mechanisms that sustain and perpetuate racism? (4) How do we combat racism? On what should we focus? Most of our authors will be philosophers whose work is in conversation with classic philosophical works explored in the two previous Brady seminars ("The Good Life" and "The Moral Life").

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Brady Program

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be expected to appreciate the complexity of the 4 main questions and to have a good sense of answers to them. (Again, the 4 main questions are: (1) What is justice? (2) What is race? (3) What is racism and how does it undermine justice? What are the different facets of racism? What are the mechanisms that sustain and perpetuate racism? (4) How do we combat racism? On what should we focus?)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course surveys various ideological traditions that have inspired the political visions and agendas of African Americans. Though white supremacy has negatively affected the lives of African Americans for centuries, the response to racial oppression has been far from monolithic. In challenging white hegemony and racial oppression, Black thinkers have addressed the contradictions inherent in the joint projects of egalitarianism and racial hierarchy. Some of the greatest contributions to American political thought emerged from competing ideological frameworks, such as the debate over accommodation versus full and immediate racial integration, nonviolence versus self-defense, and socialism versus capitalist entrepreneurship, just to name a handful of contests. In envisioning an optimal racial environment, generations of activists have inserted their concerns over other related social arrangements such as sexism, classism and heterosexism, and have consequently pushed Black and non-Black Americans alike radically reimagine American democracy.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To develop a robust and critical knowledge of key philosophies and debates in black political thought.


2. To develop an appreciation for how black political thought informs the study of contemporary politics, problems, and issues regarding race in the United States and beyond.


3. To hone personal skills in spoken deliberation and analytical argumentation.


4. To hone personal skills in analytical and argumentative writing.


5. To practice applying critical thinking to one's own life, personal politics, and commitments.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will explore some of the main themes in the philosophy of mind, with special attention to (i) the relationship between mind and body, (ii) the nature of thought and meta-cognition, and (iii) the nature of the emotions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: In this course students will be expected (1) to be able to articulate (in speech and writing) the main philosophical issues pertaining to the mind-body problem, the nature of thought and metacognition, and the nature of the emotions, and (2) to write two term papers developing their own views on one or more of these topics.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Prior philosophy course is highly recommended though not required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Suppose I am deliberating whether or not buy a plane ticket to visit an exotic country. Would I be rational to do so? Obviously, we have not said enough to answer this question. We can, however, ask a different, broader, ques- tion: what general principles and what sorts of informa- tion are required to determine whether or not my buying the ticket is a rational choice? This course will explore answers to this question, with special attention to their philosophical underpinnings.



The course has three parts:



Part I: we will motivate and develop a framework that philosophers (as well as gamblers, economists, mathematicians and computer scientists) have used to represent various theories of rational-decision making. This framework is probabilistic, but it will be a central concern to introduce it without presupposing more than high-school algebra and elementary logic (of the sort one learns in Phil 150, but which can be learned here as well).



Part II: we will elaborate on puzzles and paradoxes that have arisen surrounding the various theories of rational decision (we focus in particular on two famous paradoxes: Newcomb's paradox and the Allais paradox).



Part III: we will study how decision theoretic ideas interact with philosophical themes. This year, in particular, we will cover a recent explosion of work on the question whether decisions about whether life-changing decisions can be made on a rational basis.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students in the course will:



(a) Acquire knowledge of the elements of expected utility theory



(b) Acquire familiarity with classical arguments and paradoxes concerning those formalisms as well as the ability to analyze these arguments critically, rigorously and independently.



(c) Work on their ability to produce their own rigorous arguments on the subjects in question.



(d) Understand where some of the current frontiers of research are in this field.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is open to upper division students who have taken little or no philosophy.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An interdisciplinary investigation of reference from a philosophical/linguistic/psychological perspective, with the goal of explaining how speakers produce (and hearers comprehend) contextually-appropriate referring expressions in natural language. More generally, theories of reference attempt to answer the two interrelated questions: how do we acquire knowledge of the world through language? and what is the nature of the relationship between language and reality? Specific topics to be covered include: (in)definiteness, genericity, deixis/indexicality, the referential/attributive distinction, deferred reference, and anaphora.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
A course in linguistic meaning (e.g., LING 270, 370, 372),
A course in the philosophy of language (e.g., PHIL 253),
or permission of Instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To understand current theoretical issues in reference specifically and, more broadly, the philosophy of language, with the goal of explaining the basic principles of reference, i.e. how speakers can refer to the same object in real time using different linguistic expressions, and how the same linguistic expression can be used to refer to different objects on different occasions.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: ATTENDANCE AT FIRST CLASS MANDATORY.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Modern moral philosophy has tended to see a tight connection between morality and impartiality. Yet, our personal lives are shot through with partiality. We tend to give pride of place to the needs and interests of certain people?our friends, our family members, ourselves?to the relative exclusion of others. In this course we will explore different philosophical reactions to the apparent tension between the impartial perspective associated with morality, on the one hand, and the partiality that characterizes important personal relationships, on the other. Can this tension be resolved? Or must we admit that there will often be conflicts between, e.g., being a good friend or parent and doing the right thing?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: One previous philosophy course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will:

? Gain an understanding of contemporary debates about partiality in moral philosophy

? Be able to distinguish different forms of impartiality that moral theories may require

? Appreciate the possibilities for developing and refining historically significant moral theories in response to contemporary issues

? Further develop their skills in philosophical argument in both conversation and written work

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this class we will explore the epistemological dimensions of inquiry. Topics include the attitude(s) exemplified in the act of inquiring (including but not limited to agnosticism, suspension of judgment, and curiosity), epistemic norms of inquiry, the epistemic assessment of (the acts of and results produced by) inquiry, the rationality of inquiry, and the possible grounds for duties to inquire. Special attention will be paid to connections with related topics in philosophy of science.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: In this course students will be expected (1) to be able to articulate the main epistemological dimensions of inquiry, (2) to be able to frame one of the philosophical debates that has arisen in this connection, and (3) to defend a particular view on the debate in question.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
A century ago, in the winter of 1920/21, Walter Benjamin penned his essay "Critique of Violence," which has lost none of its fascination today, despite (or perhaps because of) its apodictic style, its opaque use of metaphor, and its erratic argumentation. During the last 30 years, it has become a common point of reference for an array of disciplines that are concerned with scope, shape, and function of the different forms of violence associated with the modern nation state. In this class, we will carefully examine Benjamin's original text, explore its philosophical and literary context, become familiar with the major positions of the reception of the essay, and discuss its political relevance today.
Reading might include, among others, authors such as Benjamin, Cohen, Kafka, Kant, Landauer, Sorel, Agamben, Derrida, Hamacher, Butler, and Menke.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of the seminar, you should

a) have gained a deep understanding of one of the canonical texts of continental social philosophy and literary theory;

b) have gained an overview of different accounts in critical theory of state violence and legal criticism;

c) be able to identify cases of state inflicted violence and evaluate them using the critical framework acquired in this seminar;

e) have improved your analytical and hermeneutical skills.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The seminar will trace issues relating to belief, doubt, and knowledge in the early modern period. Philosophers to be considered will include Descartes, Spinoza, Bayle, Hume, as well as secondary scholarship on their work.

descriptions.value: Department or Instructor consent

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will come to have a deeper understanding and appreciation of some of the central controversies and texts in early modern philosophy, especially as these relate to ongoing issues in epistemology. Students will also strengthen their critical reading and writing skills, while also gaining valuable experience in presenting their work to peers.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Some of the most pressing ethical issues we face concern our roles as individual participants in the collective activities and practices of groups to which we belong. This seminar will focus on questions about the link between collective patterns of action and the responsibilities of individuals who choose (or refuse) to participate in these larger patterns. For example, are there obligations that apply fundamentally to groups of people? If so, what are their implications for individual members of those groups? How should we, as individuals, view our personal contributions to collectively produced goods and harms? When can we be said to be complicit in the wrongs perpetrated by others, or in the injustices associated with social institutions and practices we take part in?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain a familiarity with contemporary philosophical debates concerning collective obligation and collective responsibility, and their implications for individual obligation and responsibility. They will further develop their skills in philosophical exposition, analysis, and argumentation, as these are applied to both conversation and written work.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is intended for graduate students preparing to enter the academic job market in the fall of 2020. We will work on putting together an effective dossier, focusing especially on cover letters, dissertation abstracts and writing samples.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Become familiar with standard elements of a dossier for application for faculty positions.

2. Develop a dissertation abstract, cv, and writing sample for inclusion in the dossier.

3. Create templates of cover letters for job applications.

4. Understand the standard timeline for academic jobs and have a plan in place for navigating it next year.

5. Develop a supportive community of peers who will enter the job market together.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Title: Perspectives on Global Warming

Description:
Global Warming is one of the most difficult challenges
facing humanity. We will examine global warming from a variety of perspectives, including
many of the following:
science, policy, economics, ethics,
politics, journalism, engineering, history, astronomy.

ISBN-13: 978-0198719045

Previous Editions?: No, use 3rd edition

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Maxwell's equations and wave propagation. Solutions to the wave equation. Wave interference and Young's slit experiment. Fraunhoffer diffraction. Particle wave duality. Wave mechanics and the Quantum Theory. Quantum oscillations. Identical particles, bosons and fermions. Hydrogen atom. Solids and degenerate Fermi liquids. Special Relativity.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To develop intuition for wave phenomena and to understand the basic principles of quantum mechanics and relativity.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three lectures, a discussion section, and a two-hour lab per week.

descriptions.value: One midterm, weekly problem sets, lab grades, a final exam

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter of a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based classical physics, with an introduction to modern physics in the third quarter. It is intended for science and engineering majors and premedical students. This course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in classical mechanics, including kinematics, relative motion, Newton's Laws, work and energy, linear and angular momentum, rigid body rotation, and orbital motion.

descriptions.value:

Prerequisites: MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, and MATH 230-0 or equivalent; MATH 230-0 may be taken concurrently with PHYSICS 135-1. Concurrent registration in the corresponding quarter of PHYSICS 136-1,2,3 (laboratory) is required. Prior physics is not necessary. PHYSICS 135-1,2,3 are sequential prerequisites.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based classical physics with an introduction to modern physics in the third quarter. It is intended for science and engineering majors and premedical students. PHYS 135-3 is the third and final section of the 135 sequence in General Physics. The overarching topic of 135-3 is waves in their various forms and manifestations. Specific topics to be covered are: -Mechanical waves -Sound waves -Electromagnetic waves and their applications in geometric optics -Interference and diffraction -Wave-particle duality of quantum physics and its consequences for atomic phenomena. -Special Theory of Relativity

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based classical physics with an introduction to modern physics in the third quarter. It is intended for science and engineering majors and premedical students. PHYS 135-3 is the third and final section of the 135 sequence in General Physics. The overarching topic of 135-3 is waves in their various forms and manifestations. Specific topics to be covered are: -Mechanical waves -Sound waves -Electromagnetic waves and their applications in geometric optics -Interference and diffraction -Wave-particle duality of quantum physics and its consequences for atomic phenomena. -Special Theory of Relativity

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Physics 140-3 is the third part of a three-course sequence in classical physics intended primarily for prospective physics majors and minors and other students with a special interest in physics. The course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in wave phenomena, including simple harmonic motion, mechanical and electromagnetic waves, and geometric and physical optics. This course will be taught in an active learning style.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
These are the class attributes listed in SES:
Prerequisites: MATH 220-0, MATH 224-0, and MATH 230-0 or equivalent; MATH 230-0 may be taken concurrently with PHYSICS 135-1. Concurrent registration in the corresponding quarter of PHYSICS 136-1,2,3 (laboratory) is required. PHYSICS 135-1,2,3 are sequential prerequisites.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will consist of lectures as well as extensive collaborative problem solving. Thursday enrichment sessions provide students with additional exposure to the course material, as well as review of relevant mathematical principles and techniques.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on participation in class activities, homework assignments, three in-class exams, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Online access to course text, Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Knight, will be available through MasteringPhysics. Access codes are available for purchase at www.masteringphysics.com.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to the foundational principles that are required for a modern interpretation of physical systems. The key concepts of quantum physics are motivated from seminal experiments, both of the early 20th century and in the modern era. Major topics include the wave nature of light and matter, the probabilistic interpretation of wavefunctions, one-dimensional potentials, and tunneling. Applications of quantum theory to modern topics such as statistics and atomic structure are introduced. The course will strengthen problem solving skills and tools, including complex numbers, series, and differential equations, to build intuition in modern physics, which differs significantly from the familiar expectations of classical physics.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites are PHYSICS 135-1,2,3 or equivalent; MATH 250 or PHYS 311-2 or equivalent (concurrent enrollment permitted)

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Acquire knowledge of seminal experiments indicating that classical reasoning is insufficient to describe the natural world, understand and apply the probabilistic interpretation of both quantum measurement and quantum theory, explain fundamental principles of quantum physics and implications for particles, photons, atoms , and solid-state materials, use critical calculational methods to understand quantum wavefunctions in one or more dimensions, give concise physical interpretations, and arguments for the validity of mathematical solutions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades are obtained as weighted averages of scores from online quizzes, problem sets, midterm exam, and final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: none (lecture notes will be provided)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Quantum Physics: A Fundamental Approach to Modern Physics (John Townsend, University Science Books)

name: Scalar and Vector Field Methods in Physics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Physics 332 is an introductory course in statistical physics. The goal of the course is to learn how the thermal behavior of macroscopic systems can be understood in terms of the extremely large numbers of their constitutive parts. Topics to be covered include the statistical interpretation of temperature and entropy; ideal gases; free energies and the chemical potential; phase transitions; Maxwell, Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: PHYSICS 135-1, 2, 3, and MATH 234 or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be expected to be able to identify and describe the statistical nature of concepts and laws in thermodynamics, in particular entropy, temperature, chemical potential, free energies and partition functions; and use statistical physics methods to solve problems involving a variety of physical systems.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: All four class meetings are mandatory, as both the lecture slot as well as the discussion will be used for both standard lectures as well as students working on problems in teams.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: weighted average of homework, class participation, in-class exam, and final exam scores.

descriptions.value:
Introduction to Thermal Physics, Daniel Schroeder
ISBN-10: 0201380277 ISBN-13: 978-0201380279

Previous editions: Not applicable
Online: No
Price Range: $27-$60
Other requirements: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is course 1 in a two-quarter sequence on classical electrodynamics. Specific topics to be covered:

Quarter 1 (PHYS333-1): Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. Electric charge, Coulomb's law, field and potential descriptions of electrostatics; Boundary value problems and analytical techniques for exact and approximate solutions of the Laplace and Poisson equations; Electrostatics in the presence of conductors and dielectrics; Steady currents and Lorentz force, field and potential descriptions of magnetostatics; Magnetic fields in materials.

Quarter 2 (PHYS333-2): Electrodynamics. Faraday's law and (Maxwell's version of) Ampere's law, Maxwell equations; Potential formulation of electrodynamics; Poynting's theorem and other conservation laws in electrodynamics; Electromagnetic waves; Electromagnetic radiation;

PHYS361-0 follows this sequence with discussion of special relativity and electromagnetism.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites for this class are a background in calculus based introductory physics (Physics 135-1,2,3 or the equivalent) and advanced mathematics beyond introductory differential and integral calculus.
Familiarity with basics of vector calculus (e.g. MATH 234) and past or concurrent enrollment in ordinary differential equations (e.g. MATH 250) are expected.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three hours of lectures, one hour of discussion per week plus weekly graded problem sets.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 40% for weekly homework sets and graded quizzes, 25% for the midterm examination and 35% for the final examination.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces the emergent properties and collective descriptions that arise when simple components of matter (e.g. atoms and molecules) are combined into larger systems with varying degrees of order. Topics from condensed matter physics will be selected with an eye toward relevance in modern technology, which typically may include electrons in solids, semiconductor and device physics, optics, magnetism, superconductivity, and nanostructures.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the second of a two-quarter course on quantum theory. We will develop the meaning of the theory, and how to use it to quantitatively understand atoms, spins, light polarization, ammonia, the hydrogen atom, Bell's inequality, identical particles.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: PHYSICS 339-1, Either MATH 250 Or PHYSICS 311-1,2. A strong ability to do practical calculations with calculus and familiarity with complex-valued functions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Review of special relativity and Newtonian gravity; Gravity as geometry of curved spacetime; Geodesics and conservation laws; Schwarzschild geometry; Post-Newtonian expansions and tests of general relativity; Gravitational collapse and black holes; Linearized gravity and gravitational waves; Cosmological models for the expanding Universe.

descriptions.value: This course will cover nonlinear dynamics, including fractal geometry, chaotic dynamics, dynamics of complex systems, and applications. We will focus on exploring these problems numerically through several computational projects - no previous programming experience is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the third of a three-quarter sequence of a graduate-level course on quantum mechanics and its applications to the microphysical world. Topics include: quasi-classical limit; Feynman path integral; EM fields & one-electron systems; identical particles and spin; the occupation number representation; variational methods; many-electron atoms; Thomas-Fermi method & density functional theory; diatomic molecules; polyatomic molecules; elastic scattering; inelastic scattering; quantization of the free electromagnetic field; interaction of one-electron atom & quantized radiation field; Klein-Gordon equation; Dirac equation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is an advanced graduate course in statistical physics which will cover topics on:

1. Stochastic dynamics, Brownian motion, Langevin theory, and Fokker-Planck dynamics
2. Fluctuations in thermodynamic systems and the origins of dissipation
3. Space-time correlations of fluctuations, linear response theory and the Fluctuation-Dissipation Theorem
4. Second order phase transitions, Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking and Landau theory
5. Universality, scaling and the renormalization-group theory of critical phenomena

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Completion of Physics 416 or its equivalent is required.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Course evaluation will be based on problem and project assignments.

descriptions.value: Reading materials will be assigned in class from the literature and in the form of course notes.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of the Standard Model of particle physics. Deep-inelastic lepton scattering, neutrino oscillations,
and collider physics. The experimental side of particle physics will be emphasized. Focus will be mainly on collider physics at the Tevatron and the upcoming Large Hadron Collider.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fluids: Euler's equation, conservation laws, potential flow, viscosity, Navier-Stokes equations, Reynolds number, thermal conduction, diffusion, surface and sound waves. Solids: kinematics, stress and strain tensors, linear elasticity (Hooke's Law), finite elasticity. Complex fluids: constitutive relations, colloids, Einstein viscosity, sedimentation, granular media, gels, liquid crystals.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Phyx 411-0 or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 90-minutes lectures per week

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The course will cover the novel physics of low-dimensional (0 < D <= 2) metallic, semiconducting and superconducting materials. I will cover some of the remarkable electronic states characteristic of 2D systems, including integer and fractional quantum hall states, topologically stable defects in 2D superfluids and layered superconductors, the vortex-anti-vortex transition in 2D superfluids, as well as novel electronic states of graphene (monolayer graphite). Quantum interference effects in Josephson devices, including resonant tunnel junctions and molecular magnetic quantum point contacts, will
be described.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will provide an introduction to problems in complex systems, including disordered materials and complex networks in biology, physics and social systems. We will focus on the emergence of functional behavior from microscopic interactions as well as on the appearance of phase transitions. We will cover key models of heterogeneous systems and networks, their connections to real life applications and strategies to solve them. Grading will be based on projects related to the course lectures; problems will be a combination of analytical problem solving and python programming. Students will be expected to do appreciable outside reading including research papers.

reading and can be downloaded from the internet. Python is available

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Syria: politics, society, and culture in revolutio

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class examines the 2011 Syrian uprising and ensuing civil war through the lenses of social science, journalism, film, and literature. Theoretical issues raised include the role of economic, political, and ethnic factors in the onset of revolutionary challenge, state strategies of repression, international influences on intrastate war, and the role of Islamist groups and ideology in patterns of violence and rebel governance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Khalifa, Khaled. 2016. No Knives in the Kitchens of This City: A Novel. Cairo: Hoopoe. 978-9774167812.
Khalifa, Khaled. 2019. Death Is Hard Work: A Novel. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux. 978-0374135737.
Khalifa, Mustafa. 2016. The Shell: Memoirs of a Hidden Observer. Northampton, MA: Interlink. 978-1566560221.
Pearlman, Wendy. 2017. We Crossed a Bridge and It Trembled: Voices from Syria. New York, NY: HarperCollins. 9780062654458
al-Sabouni, Marwa. 2016. The Battle for Home: The Memoir of a Syrian Architect. London: Thames & Hudson. 978-0500292938
Sattouf, Riad. 2015. The Arab of the Future: A Childhood in the Middle East, 1978-1984: A Graphic Memoir. London: Metropolitan Books. 978-1627793445
Yazbek, Samar. 2012. A Woman in the Crossfire: Diaries of the Syrian Revolution. London: Haus. 978-1908323125.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Feminism has taught us that the personal is political, and what is more personal than our bodies? This seminar explores how feminist thinkers and actors have brought the body into the political arena. We will engage with feminist theorizations of embodied experience from a diverse set of interdisciplinary texts, including black, Chicana, transnational and queer feminist work. With a focus on gender, race, and sexuality, we will think through questions of identity, difference, location, and voice. The second half of the seminar will use these theoretical framings to analyze political issues and activist movements that center the body, such as sexual assault, police brutality, reproduction, LGBTQ rights, and body positivity. Students will choose an issue or movement to focus their written work on throughout the seminar, ultimately culminating in a research portfolio to be presented to the class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials required

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Insurgency and Nation-Building in the Age of Revol

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the political problems, debates, and peoples that framed post-colonial movements in the American hemisphere. The course will begin with debates centered on the "New World" in the late 1700's, turn to insurgency movements during on to the Age of Revolutions in the 1800's, and consider the legacies of American revolutions in the 20th century. The goal of the course is to engage the political innovations that emerged from projects of American emancipation, including indigenous movements in Latin America, slave revolts in the Caribbean, and abolitionist discourse in the United States. Thus, the course decenters the United States in order to illustrate the hemispheric and post-colonial features of American nation-building. This course readings will cover post-colonial theory, indigenous studies, transatlantic histories, theories of nation-building, and studies of popular movements. Our primary cases will be in the United States, Mexico, Haiti, Colombia, and Peru.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course students should feel confident doing the following:

- Historicizing arguments to account for differences in the use and deployment of political terms, words, and concepts.
- Contextualizing political ideas in terms of rhetoric and audience. This requires students to reflect on the author's use of political language in relation to the intended readers or audience of the text.
- Engaging intellectual history to trace meaning "across" texts and contexts. For example, recognizing differences between nation-building discourse in the United States and the Andes.
- Illustrating what is "at stake" in the text. This requires students to account for the problems, issues, or events addressed by texts, peoples, and histories.
- Designing and sustaining a critical analysis of the materials and ideas discussed and related to the class."

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Paper, finalClass participationWriting assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

name: Introduction to Empirical Methods in Political Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to the empirical methods political scientists use to answer questions about politics, and the reasons why such methods matter. We begin by considering how we use data and information in social science in general and political science in particular. We then examine three basic strategies for overcoming the obstacles to reliable knowledge about the political world: experimentation, quantitative studies (statistics) and smaller case studies with a qualitative emphasis. This course will prepare you to take a more in-depth look into these methods in subsequent coursework.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

name: Introduction to Law in the Political Arena

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class examines the nature and functioning of the legal system. It is a large lecture course aimed at Freshmen and Sophomores. It satisfies distributional requirements for majors in many Schools, and serves as a gateway to further law-related courses in political science. Some of the topics it covers include: what is law, and why people obey it; the relationship between law and social change; crime, the police, and the prison crisis in America; how people get a lawyer and how lawyers make a living; civil justice and the litigation explosion; courts, judges, politics and corruption; Supreme Court decision making; and legal strategies for making change.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of the course is to help students think critically and analytically about legal issues and to understand the relationship between elements of the legal process and the institutional, economic and political forces that surround them.

descriptions.value: This course pursues three goals: first, familiarity with the principal theoretical frameworks that will be used in all further courses in IR, notably Realism, Neoliberalism, and Constructivism; second, familiarity with the history of international relations in the twentieth century; third, ability to engage meaningfully with the concepts and ideas - sovereignty, for example - that advance or obstruct our efforts to grapple with the forbidding global challenges, such as climate change, that confront us today.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How racist is the average American, and what makes some more racist than others? Why can't Democrats and Republicans just get along? Does a country's colonial experience shape its future political and economic possibilities? These questions, and many more, have been addressed by statistical research in political science. This course explores quantitative/statistical research methods in the social sciences, with the goal of helping students learn how to carry out statistical social science research of their own. To that end, we will review the basics of statistical theory and quantitative research design. We will also examine applications of these methods to various topics in political science. Throughout, the emphasis will be on practical, applied advice for constructing and successfully completing quantitative research in political science and related fields.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will be expected to know how to to design, conduct, interpret, and evaluate quantitative research in political science. They will be able to formulate relevant research questions, find data, carry out preliminary statistical analysis, and use regression and related tools to answer descriptive and causal questions about politics.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to the analysis of the United States Congress. The subject matter covers many aspects of Congress - from congressional elections and redistricting, to the power of committees and political parties, to the challenges of governing in an era of polarized politics. We will also explore how Congress interacts with the President. The course emphasizes how the goals of members, particularly reelection, shape the organization of the institution and the policies it produces.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite classes: POLI_SCI 220 or equivalent background in American politics

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, you will have acquired the following skills:
(1) Critically reflect on how institutional rules affect congressional outcomes
(2) Analyze the impact of elections on legislative behavior
(3) Evaluate the role of parties in Congress
(4) Discuss and describe the problems facing the current Congress

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The United States' population is becoming ever-more diverse. According to the Census Bureau, racial and ethnic minorities will comprise a majority of the population within our lifetimes?by 2042. This course will explore how diversity shapes policy debates and choices in the U. S., and also how policies in turn contribute to racial and ethnic diversity. The focus will be on the social issues facing our country now and in the future. We will cover such topics as immigration reform, school choice, residential segregation, and criminal justice.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will study how the U.S. 1980 Refugee Act, a national policy premised on human rights obligations in the 1951 International Convention for the Protection of Refugee and 1967 Protocol, meets the street in Chicago neighborhoods and other localities in the United States. As we learn about the politics of refugee resettlement by examining street-level bureaucracy, we will consider what local understandings of refugee policy can teach us about the meaning of integration as part of broader discourses on constitutional governance, federalism and civil society. We will also look comparatively at the perspectives, policies and ideologies of other countries in their refugee resettlement programs as part of the broader question of humanitarian governance and the role of Western Liberal Democracies. Through these explorations, students will gain insight into the complexities of refugee resettlement policy as a durable solution for refugees seeking protection. Students will gain exposure to narrative policy analysis, analyze data through GIS and have a chance to conduct archival and field research of Chicago neighborhoods.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- By engaging with primary and secondary sources on refugee policies in liberal democracies, students will gain perspective on the different ways in which governance of human rights obligations and norms take shape in national and local institutions.
- By conducting a political discourse and narrative policy analysis students will develop skills in critical thinking and primary source analysis
- By conducting field research students will develop skills of designing, planning and producing research and qualitative interpretive methodology.
- Through active participation in class and reflection on the readings, students will cultivate meaningful modes of engagement to advance learning.

name: Constitutional Law II: Civil and Political Rights

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course investigates the civil rights and civil liberties protected by the Constitution and defined by the U.S. Supreme Court. It will also examine the many controversies over what, exactly, the Constitution means, who gets to decide, and how. We will discuss, among other topics, freedom of expression, freedom of religion, privacy, equality, and voting rights.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required. Taught with LEGAL_ST 333; may not receive credit for both courses. Prerequisite: POLI_SCI 220 or 230.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Throughout this course, students should be developing critical reading, thinking, and writing skills; by the end of the quarter, students should be able to: understand the U.S. Constitution and Supreme Court cases; explain how doctrines of law have changed over time; analyze the assumptions of courts and policy makers; and understand how the Supreme Court responds to political, social, and economic factors.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Since the end of the Second World War, the US has been, arguably, the most powerful nation in the world; sometimes with competition, sometimes without. This class will examine the underlying logic(s) of foreign policy: the tools and ideas which inform these ideas; and the manner in which these policies are sold to allies and the public. We will focus on the nuclear strategy, the Cold War, the end of the Cold War, the rise of wars with non-state actors, and the return of Russia and the emergence of China. On occasion, a specific act, event, or war will come to the fore and there will be a deeper investigation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the comparative politics of the Middle East and North Africa. The first half of the course focuses on the historical and institutional context of politics and government. Here we examine the emergence of independent states, the consolidation of regimes, and patterns in the relationship between state, society, and economy. We compare explanations for the endurance of authoritarian regimes, examine the role of Islam in politics, and also look at the Iranian Revolution and Islamic Republic. The second half of the course concentrates on dynamics of mobilization and conflict. Here we explore the Arab uprisings that began in late 2010 and their aftermath, current challenges facing the search for stability and democracy in the region, the Syrian war, and the origins and evolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goals of this course are to assist students (1) to acquire basic knowledge about the politics of the modern Middle East and North Africa; (2) to engage in critical reading and analysis of a range of sources; (3) to employ scholarly theories and concepts to enrich their nuanced analysis of current events in the region and debates about those events; and (4) to develop an appreciation for how politics in the region is shaped by history and institutions on the one hand and a dynamic multiplicity of identities and interests, on the other. Assignments are designed to assess progress toward the achievement of these goals.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Throughout the 20th century, Latin America experienced dramatic changes in multiple dimensions of the political, social and economic spheres. The region witnessed revolutions, civil wars, and transitions in and out of democracy. Cities witnessed massive immigration from rural areas, fundamentally changing the structures of societies. Poverty rates dropped dramatically, literacy rates increased steadily, and public goods were provided to many regions formerly abandoned by the states. Countries' economic models went from depending mainly on the production and exports of raw materials (1870-1950s) to focus on industrialization by substituting imports (1950-1990s) and a relatively closed economy, to the reopening of the economy following the end of the Cold War. Change has been more the norm than the exception.

However, economic inequality and violence have been steady throughout this time in many countries in the region. This course offers an introduction to key topics of Latin American around these paradoxes: 1) high levels of economic inequality and 2) high levels of violence despite dramatic changes to the social, political, and economic landscape.

The course will challenge students to analyze how the complexities of current socio-political realities reflect the history of the region and how this informs both the commonalities and differences across countries.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students should be familiar with the main topics in the field of Latin American politics and be able to think critically about them. Students should be able to evaluate current events in Latin America as part of the broader historical context. By the end of the course, students should have comprehensive knowledge on a topic that interests them and that is relevant for the region.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will be thinking about how and whether constitutions shape national values and offer a framework for legitimacy and governance to hold together diverse societies and resolve deeply rooted social tensions and ethnic divisions. We will consider the constitutional responses of other democratic countries such as the U.S., Canada, India, France, Germany, Great Britain, South Africa and Australia to the challenges of capital crimes, right to life/abortion, terrorism, racism, gender disparities, religious discrimination. In learning about the varying traditions of written and unwritten constitutions, civil and common law and the foundations and structures of separation of powers and judicial review of the constitutionality of laws in these countries, students will learn to think critically about the U.S. Constitution and the different ways in which constitutional democracies provide for public order, counter-majoritarian governance, equality and protection of the rights of minorities through rule of law and question whether constitutional solutions can address the kinds of social and political problems we have today.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials will be available on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to politics in contemporary sub-Saharan Africa. The core questions framing the course are: What is African about African politics? How do colonial legacy and international political economy shape African states? How is politics practiced on the continent? What explains Africa's uneven economic trajectories and diverse patterns of conflicts? How to explain the large variation within Africa in the strength of the state, the levels of economic growth and respect for democratic institutions? What role identities (ethnic, religious and gender) play out in politics? What are the current dilemmas and questions in African politics? The course is organized around the following broad themes: the formation of the state in Africa; the practice of power, regimes types and forms of government, the role of religion, identity and politics; the challenges of development and the economic dimensions of African politics; authoritarianism and democratic experiments; elections; protests and social movements; violence, terror, and security; Africa in world politics. While the course is not designed as a study of individual countries, in exploring the themes and trends that dominate politics across Africa, we draw on case studies from a variety of countries on the continent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Acquire basic knowledge of politics in Sub-Saharan Africa;
- Employ major theories and concepts to promote a nuanced analysis of African politics;
- Contextualize and compare major political trends in African politics and relate them to political trends elsewhere.
- Apply comparative politics concepts to the study of African politics.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The decades following WW II are sometimes described by students of International Relations as "The Long Peace." Despite obvious tensions and a Cold War between the superpowers and despite major differences in ideology and economic policies, major power war did not erupt. Indeed, some scholars wonder whether such war has become obsolete. Be that as it may, by some counts, the past half century has seen more than 20 million deaths in many other conflicts. Among these conflicts, civil wars have been some of the bloodiest and costliest. This course will examine the causes behind such conflicts as well as study how such conflicts might be terminated or prevented altogether. Some of the causes of civil wars will be internal to the states in question, other causes might be due to international actors and external forces. Correspondingly some efforts to terminate or prevent such conflicts will reside at the domestic level while others will operate in the international arena.

The class will be a mixture of lectures and seminar style participation, culminating in a short research project that is of particular interest to the student and which will be designed in cooperation with the professor. Throughout the course, students will be expected to keep up with the readings and to actively contribute to the discussions in class.

Although our main attention will go to conflicts after 1945, the course is not focused on any specific geographic area or any specific war. Instead, the aim of the course is to increase your understanding of the phenomenon of civil wars in general. With this general theoretical knowledge of civil wars, the student will then design a research project of a case or cases that are of particular interest to the student. One-on-one meetings with the professor and graduate assistant will help you with the research design.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Goals of the course. After completing the course successfully students should be able to:
- Develop a better understanding of the various types of civil wars.
- Analyze the various causes of civil war and evaluate which cause or causes led to a specific civil war or wars.
- Evaluate different strategies to prevent civil war and strategies to terminate such wars
- Assess the tradeoffs of particular policy choices in dealing with civil wars
- Understand the elements of social science research, and constructively critique the extant literature and suggest improvements.
